speech.speaker: Bolkus, Sen Nick

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise to support this legislation and to place on record both the opposition's support for it and the opposition's concerns about a number of aspects of not only the legislation but also the government's response to the events which occurred at Port Arthur just a few months ago.

speech.para:
We see this bill as the next important step in the introduction of uniform national gun
laws. It is worth placing on record that much of the work that has been reflected in the outcome from discussions since the Port Arthur massacre has been built on the work that was done in the previous government by my colleagues the then Attorney‐General, Michael Lavarch, and particularly by the then Minister for Justice, Duncan Kerr. The nuts and bolts of the uniform gun laws legislation, the whole raft of measures that go to questions of licensing, classification and every other aspect of the legislation, bar one, were being prepared by the previous Minister for Justice in particular. That one exemption, of course, is the extension of the ban from what was proposed before Port Arthur to now cover the semi‐automatic weapons that are being covered in this bill.

What is reflected in this legislation is an approach to national gun laws that was, in fact, being prepared before the election. This bill appropriates money to the states for the purposes of the firearms buyback and to compensate gun dealers for loss of business. The bill will also compensate the states for the cost of implementing the resolution as agreed to by the Australian council of police ministers on 10 May 1996 and 17 July 1996. It is a fundamental piece of legislation which provides the umbrella statutory power for the scheme to be implemented. In endorsing the scheme, we support the legislation.

But there are a number of concerns that we have with the bill. These matters have been raised with the government, but the government has chosen not to support them. That is unfortunate, but it is the case. Our overriding objective in this particular process was to maintain a spirit of bipartisanship. As I said the day after Port Arthur, the opposition was keen to enter into a bipartisan arrangement with the government to ensure that the combined strengths of the major parties and other parties in this place would mean that those who would otherwise want to blackmail government into one position or another would have to take on the whole political process. I think that bipartisan approach has been important so far. It is that bipartisan approach which leads us to raise issues of concern today. But, once again, with the
objective of not trying to blow away that bipartisanship, we will not move amendments to affect, in particular, the agreements of the council of police ministers of the dates that I mentioned earlier.

We have a number of concerns. They are worth placing on record because I think the government may have to address them down the track. The first concern that we have is in respect of the amount of compensation to be paid by the Commonwealth to the states for implementation of the scheme. Our understanding is that compensation originally agreed to would cover some two‐thirds to three‐quarters of the costs incurred by the states, and we are concerned at recent suggestions that the government may seek to squib on this commitment and provide only some 50 per cent of the costs. That, of course, would be contrary to the expectations of state ministers and would throw a barb in the successful implementation of these reforms.

It is my understanding that there is a commitment from the office of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) that the limit will only be set once agreements have been reached with the states and territories. What I would like from Senator Vanstone as the representative of the Attorney-General is an undertaking to the effect that any agreement on the amount of compensation will be consistent with both the letter and the spirit of the resolutions agreed to by the police ministers; and, further, that the limit will only be set once an agreement has been reached with each and every state and territory, in accordance with the above terms.

That is an important factor to place on the table at the moment. Any weaseling out by the Commonwealth on commitments given in terms of cost coverage for the states is something we would be concerned about—not just because it may be seen to be a breach of commitment, but also because it may inject into this process a bit of ill will which is quite unnecessary and could be quite damaging to the way the scheme is implemented.

The other major concern we have is one that emanates from the way this issue has been handled in my home state, the state of South Australia. It is of real concern that in
that state the pressure from the backbench of the Liberal government has meant that the government has had to make concessions which are not in the national interest, concessions which do in some respects undermine the national operation of this legislation.

For instance, South Australia has sought an exemption from the national amnesty, which is to apply until 30 September 1997. Instead, for South Australia the amnesty will be in effect only until the end of this year. That, of course, throws it out of kilter with the rest of Australia. It will lead to a situation where, whilst it will be illegal to own a prohibited firearm all around Australia in the new year, you will be safe from prosecution in every part of Australia until 30 September 1997—with the exception of South Australia. That could create problems, for instance, with people who move to South Australia during this period not knowing of the different law that will apply there. Those problems are obvious.

But what concerns me is that the reason for the difference in timing demanded by South Australia is not so obvious, other than, as I say, unreasonable irrational pressure from the backbench of the government in the state of South Australia. I would have liked—and I am sure the Commonwealth would have liked—to have seen a scheme operating consistently across the country. But, as I say, in South Australia, for some irrational reason, the state government has chosen not to stay in line with the national response.

The direct impact of this is that the buy-back scheme will only apply in South Australia for a more limited period. Our concern is that, whereas all other states and the Commonwealth Attorney-General have deemed it appropriate to have a longer period to maximise the scheme's impact, in my home state it will not be able to operate for as long as we would have liked it to. We would have preferred the South Australian exemption not to have been agreed to by the police ministers. The result, as I say, is contrary to the principle of having a national gun law. But, because we are keen not to reopen the agreed position of the ministers, we raise our concerns at this stage and, of course, urge
South Australia to reconsider its irrational position on this.

The second problem with South Australia is an even more important one—and I do not know what has been driving the South Australian response in these matters apart from, as I say, irrationality on the backbench. South Australia will be the only state in the Commonwealth that will not compensate owners of unregistered prohibited firearms. This is bad policy—and it is so for a number of reasons.

For a start, unregistered prohibited weapons are the weapons that we most want to remove from the streets. Registered weapons can always be tracked down. But it is the unregistered ones that are most likely to be the ones that we want to remove from action, and these are the ones that the South Australian response will ensure are not brought forward. An amnesty covering as wide a range of weapons as possible is desirable; an amnesty covering unregistered prohibited weapons is something which we would have thought would have been essential. But South Australia has chosen not to go this far.

This is even more irrational because the Commonwealth is footing the compensation bill for these weapons. As a result of the passage of this act, there is no cost in terms of compensation for the buy back of weapons to be incurred by the state of South Australia. So I have to ask the Premier of South Australia, `Why aren't you going as far as the rest of Australia? Why are you allowing this loophole for South Australia, particularly when it will cost you nothing?'

The concern is there, the concern is real and the concern is that, because of the gutlessness of the Brown government, the firearms that we most want removed from our streets will not be picked up in South Australia. It is of concern to South Australians; it should also be of concern in the national interest.

Whilst the Attorney-General and the Commonwealth authorities have complained to South Australia about this position, I would have liked to have had this issue forced upon that state, particularly given the fact that the other states have agreed to the extension to cover unregistered prohibited weapons. Once
again, we would have supported an amendment to the bill effectively to force South Australia to provide compensation to all firearm owners. But to have done that, I think, would have led to a reopening of the arrangement at a critical time of the arrangement's implementation.

I will now discuss the federal government's response to the wider issues emanating from Port Arthur. We obviously agree with the response of the government which has given us uniform national gun laws. But we need to look at two other matters that have arisen out of Port Arthur, and we need to look at them in the context of what could have been a broader and more visionary response to this particular problem.

We have had instances in the past with Hoddle Street and Queen Street, and there were responses to those—and I will go to them in a few minutes. But the federal government's response here has gone to national gun laws, it has gone to review and tightening of censorship guidelines and review of the national mental health strategy. My concern is that these are issues that were chosen more because of their populism than because of good broad visionary policy.

In terms of censorship, there was some concern straight after the massacre that Mr Bryant had in his possession some 2,000 allegedly violent videos. As a consequence, newspapers reacted very strongly to that and claims were made that we would need to tighten up our censorship laws because they caused Port Arthur. But, with the exception of three or four videos, the rest of those 2,000 were predominantly 1930s and 1940s musicals—the Shirley Temples, the Fred and Gingers, the Judy Garlands and so on. A knee-jerk response was something that we could have done without at that particular time. Yes, we have embarked upon a review of censorship laws but we should not allow ourselves to act as cultural cops when we in the Senate revisit the legislation.

Another concern is that we targeted mental health when all the evidence seems to indicate that, despite the popular media response at the time, Mr Bryant was not a schizophrenic. When the Queen Street and Hoddle Street
massacres occurred, the then federal government set up a National Committee on Violence. That committee gave some 140 recommendations on how our society could tackle the issues of violence.

Those recommendations went to the following: organised crime; the use of drugs, legal and illegal; providing family infrastructure; providing education and support services to parents to provide safer family environments, recognising that all too often violence is within the family; resourcing anti-violence education campaigns; looking at domestic and family violence; and helping people with intellectual disabilities. There was a whole raft of measures going to the problems of youth, accommodation, access and support for conflict resolution services, and so on. The committee was also looking at the treatment of issues of violence in schools and in the workplace with responses such as education and training opportunities; looking at producing Commonwealth laws to tackle domestic violence and relationship breakdowns; and looking at training police forces.

What I am saying is that, when those massacres took place, the government at the time took a broad response. We said, `Well, let us recognise that the sorts of underlying problems that bring about the Port Arthurs and the Queen and Hoddle streets are not just simplistic ones; they are not just superficial ones. They go to the very fabric of society and of family problems.' My concern is that we could at this particular stage of our development have revisited the National Committee on Violence agenda and made an assessment of how far we have progressed since then and of how we need to build on that agenda. But we have not done that.

I think it is a lost opportunity for Australia that we have not revisited the broad spectrum of issues and tried to build on the government action of the past. Instead, what have we done? We have, in fact, cut back on some of the most critical areas that go to law enforcement and control of violence in our society. In the last 48 hours, we have seen cutbacks in a raft of law enforcement areas which are quite unreasonable in the circumstances in which the particular organisations that have
been affected are having to meet them. It is also unreasonable in terms of the growing incidence of not just crime but organised crime in our society.

When you look at what this government has done in recent days to the resource capacity of the National Crime Authority—particularly when it means that for my state of South Australia and for Western Australia in particular the resources will be about one-third of what they have been in the past—there will be cutbacks of some $11 million over the next three years. Cuts have been made to the Australian Federal Police—an organisation which is stretched in its capacity already; an organisation which has to meet growing demands; and an organisation which, together with the NCA and Customs, will have added responsibilities as we go towards the year 2000 Olympics.

Cutbacks to Customs will mean that our borders will not be checked as well as they have been, as well as they could be and as well as they need to be. Overall, some $130 million over the next four years will be cut back from our law enforcement capacity. I think that is something that this government will find very hard to justify as part of this nation's response to illegality and violence in our society. Not only do we find ourselves having lost the opportunity to build on the social policy response but also we find that, at a time when we need to build our resources against particularly the organised crime part of our society, those resources have had a monumental cutback.

para.break: Returning to the legislation, let me say that the opposition supports it. We recognise that the response of the government has been a strong one. We also recognise that we have a role to play in maintaining our bipartisan support for the legislation to ensure that we do not go down the American road when it comes to the use of guns in our society. At the same time, we do say to the government that this has been a lost opportunity in terms of how we could have broached other underlying issues in our society. Not only is it a lost opportunity but also it comes at a time when the government's ideological fixation on cutting back the capacity of federal govern ment means that our law enforcement agencies—agencies with their primary role being to protect families in our society—will be cut at the knees in terms of their capacity.

speech.para: In closing, can I say that we commend the government for going this far. The legislation is important. I am sure that, as we proceed towards the year 2000 and thereafter, the Australian public will be grateful that this legislation is on the statute books and that this parliament has been able to come together—to put political issues aside, to put party politicking aside—and agree to a bill which, despite some problems, is a major step forward for gun control in any Western society.

speech.speaker: Bourne, Sen Vicki

talk.start.para: —On behalf of all my parliamentary colleagues and probably the entire general membership of the Australian Democrats, I am happy to support the National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1996. The passage of the bill will take Australia just one step closer to fully implementing the resolutions of the police ministers' special meeting on firearms on 10 May. In relation to those resolutions, I would agree with Senator Bolkus that all agreements on levels of Commonwealth funding for compensation must be honoured by the Commonwealth. I, too, would be interested in hearing the response by the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, Senator Vanstone, to that.

speech.para: The Democrats have always supported tighter gun control. We have long called for the adoption of many of the measures which are now in the process of being implemented—and this bill will be part of that. We welcome the move to tighter uniform gun legislation. We congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), and, indeed, all our federal leaders, who are showing such a united front in support of gun control, as well as the state and territory premiers and all those other Australians who have worked so hard to ensure that these essential reforms are adopted. In conclusion, we are pleased to support the bill.

Other than at major capital city airports, where a local community has indicated a desire to acquire the airport lease, the Government should make every effort to ensure that the local community acquires the lease.

(b)
In order to achieve the maximum economic benefit from competition within the general aviation sector, the Government should maximise the diversity of ownership of airports within each capital city other than in relation to Sydney Kingsford Smith and Sydney West.

(c)
The draft EIS guidelines for the proposed Holsworthy site are entirely inadequate, particularly in relation to

(d)
Until a solution that is satisfactory for residents to the current aircraft noise problem in Sydney is implemented, including the operation of a second Sydney Airport, the Government should not proceed with the sale of leases at Sydney Kingsford Smith and Sydney West Airports.

Senator TAMBLING
(Northern Territory—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)
(11.48 a.m.)—Last evening when we were debating these airport bills, I had already responded to the comments of the Senate committee report on this important airports legislation and to the comments Senator Bob Collins made on behalf of the Australian Labor Party.

At the interruption of the debate, I was responding to the comments Senator Woodley made on behalf of the Australian Democrats. We had reached the point of talking about competition between airports. I had indicated that the government was going to do all that it could to encourage competition, but that it would in a direct sense occur only at the margin.

Nevertheless, that margin can be vital, as Senator Calvert observed. Even Senator Bob Collins implied that Alice Springs, Launceston and even Melbourne do see themselves in competition with other airports. You only have to pick up any newspaper to see that Victorians are desperate to allow themselves to own their own airport and compete with Sydney.

Senator Woodley raised the issue of the Federal Airports Corporation's profit. Yes, the FAC has done an excellent job in earning a profit, although its rate of return is not as powerful as he suggested. In part, this is because its assets remain undervalued. For example, the runways in Brisbane are on the books at only $25 million. So its returns are inflated by a low asset base. It is obvious that Democrat economics would not get past the auditor.

Let me say that the sale is not a punishment for the FAC, rather it is a culmination of a job well done. There is no longer a development need for local airports requiring cross‐subsidies of the kind referred to by Senator Bob Collins. The network approach has done its job. It is now time to harness the innovation skill of the private sector to take over the asset and improve services to the travelling public in the same way as private airports in the United Kingdom and elsewhere in Europe have done. We can be sure that services will improve because this bill allows service standards to be established and used as a
means of scrutinising the performance of new operators.

Senator Calvert raised the issue of local government rates being paid by on‐airport businesses. Currently, this is done by discretion by the FAC. Under the leases to be offered to private purchasers, this obligation should be picked up by the new lessee. I appreciate that Senator Calvert's concerns for the challenges to Tasmanians are particularly on behalf of the tourist industry that he is so closely associated with.

Senator Margetts foreshadowed amendments in relation to environmental issues at airports. The government has indicated a preparedness to consider these up to a point. It will be interesting to see at the committee stage how effective these changes are likely to prove. I think some are not wise from an environmental point of view, and we have attempted to provide advice on these.

I hope it will be recognised that giving states the ability to override Commonwealth environmental standards is not traditionally what green groups have sought and that seems singularly inappropriate here. Making the task of regulating to support environment standards difficult and riddled with delay is also less than helpful to the management of environment issues at airports.

Senator Crane outlined how effective the Senate committee process has been. This puts great credit on the positive approach taken by the government to the committee process in the Senate. Indeed, some of the issues raised here could and should have been given an airing in the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee rather than being rushed in at the last minute yesterday and perhaps today in the committee stage.

Senator Murphy wants to ensure that local bodies can control airports. We too have an interest in this area. As I noted yesterday in comments on Senator Bob Collins's remarks, I have spoken to the Tasmanian local government representatives and found them very understanding of the government's desire to have an open tender process.

Let me turn to the comments by Senator Harradine, who wanted to ensure that proper
oversight of prices occurs. I can assure him that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will put a strong focus on constraining aeronautical prices to keep them below the consumer price index over the next five years. Airport operators will definitely not be able to charge what the market will bear. Prices to airlines, their customers and the travelling public will fall in real terms over the five years. The only remaining question is: how far?

The government will not be regulating immediately to assure this. We have seen the Prices Surveillance Authority work well without mandatory regulation power prior to its incorporation into the ACCC. We believe that operators will respect the ACCC's view. If not, however, the government has said in the paper on pricing at airports, which is currently circulating and which was provided to the committee, that we reserve the right to impose by legislation the pricing policy if the ACCC believes that to be necessary. Thus the intent of Senator Harradine's concern is met. I can give him an assurance to this effect.

Senator Harradine also raised the issue of local government taxation applying to leases. We have already indicated an intention to ensure that leases reflect this. As well, Senator Harradine wanted to have our views on local ownership. I have already indicated that we share an interest and are considering options in this area within the context of an open bidding contest. I use the specific examples of Launceston and Hobart.

Finally, Senator Harradine raised the aerodrome local ownership program. In committee hearings, departmental representatives indicated that no ALOP existed anymore. A future policy question will be whether the equivalent of such a scheme can be applied to the airport lease sales. Obviously, if bidding interest is not strong and local communities remain interested in taking over ownership, the government does not rule out any option for the future. I can go no further than that at this point in time.

I also appreciate the interest that all senators, including Senator Calvert and Senator MacGibbon, gave to addressing the very
important considerations in this regard and to supporting this legislation.

I now turn to the amendment that has been moved by Senator Bob Collins for the opposition. That second reading amendment is in four parts, entitled (a), (b), (c) and (d). The first tenet of Senator Collins's amendment relates to the effort to ensure that the local community acquires the lease. I mentioned this issue in my response to Senator Harradine, but I would like to add a bit to it. The government has made clear its position on local community involvement in the leasing of airports other than major capital city airports. I mention, however, that I do not recall the previous government, the Labor government, suggesting this approach under its own proposals when we were considering them for the leasing of airports.

The second tenet, part (b), of Senator Collins's amendment relates to the diversity of ownership issue. The government has also made its position on this issue quite clear. There will be separation of ownership and control of Sydney with Sydney West from Melbourne and Sydney again with Sydney West from Brisbane. This will ensure that there is no private sector monopoly of the major airports on the eastern seaboard.

The government considers that the powers of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, coupled with the provisions of the Airports Bill, are more than adequate to protect the interests of the community and airport users. While the smaller airports effectively do not compete with each other or larger airports, the government, in conducting the leasing processes, will have regard to the support various parties have expressed for diversity of ownership being achieved.

The third tenet of Senator Collins's amendment relates to the EIS guidelines for the proposed Holsworthy site. I indicate that the government remains committed to building Sydney a second major airport of full international standard as a matter of priority, subject to the results of an environmental impact statement. In Labor's 13 years in power, they achieved nothing for a second airport. They fast‐talked and slow‐tracked development of an inadequate overflow airport development.
While Badgerys Creek remains the preferred site, the government considers it prudent to consider Holsworthy as an alternative in case Badgerys Creek proves to be environmentally unacceptable.

The government is committed to a thorough, objective and transparent EIS process with extensive consultation and independent auditing consistent with the recommendations of the 1995 Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney. The draft EIS guidelines will be finalised by the EPA after considering all comments by interested parties. I will certainly arrange for the issues raised in this debate to be referred to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill—in fact, I already did so yesterday in discussions with him—and the EPA for full consideration.

Let me say that the development of runway configurations and master plans is being addressed as a matter of priority. It is envisaged that the output from this consultancy will be made publicly available and will of course be a key input into the EIS.

The fourth and final point of Senator Collins's amendment is that the government should not proceed with the sale of leases at Kingsford Smith and Sydney West airports. The target is to issue a draft EIS by early 1997. All comments received on the draft EIS will then be fully considered and further information incorporated where required before the final EIS is prepared. The government will then be considering issues associated with the proposed airport based on the EIS and financial feasibility studies. The government will be giving further consideration to the leasing of Sydney and Sydney West airports once the site and scale of the development have been resolved.

The government is certainly not attracted to supporting the amendment proposed by Senator Collins. In fact, we encourage all senators to look at the very close and clear objectives that have been outlined for this legislation, to reject the opposition amendment and to then fully support the proper and principal proposals that have been put forward in both of these pieces of legislation—the Airports Bill 1996 and the associated bill.

proctext.para: AIRPORTS (TRANSITIONAL) BILL 1996

speech.speaker: Tambling, Sen Grant

talk.start.para:
—Before proceeding with the debate on the particular bills, I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to the Airports Bill. For the information of honourable senators,
this memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 21 August.

speech.para: The bill.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Clause 2, page 2 (lines 2 to 4), omit the clause, substitute:

para.tab: This Act commences on the day after the day on which a written agreement, signed by representatives of all local government councils which are located within a 20 kilometre radius of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) or Sydney West Airports, and certifying that a satisfactory plan to provide for equitable sharing of the noise and air traffic burden over Sydney and implementation in a way that cannot result in an inequitable or onerous noise burden in the future has been agreed to, is laid before both Houses of Parliament.

speech.para: The Airports (Transitional) Bill is a technical bill to transfer ownership. However, it is important to deal with some of the issues in bringing on the commencement of the bill in general.

Last year the coalition while in opposition effectively scuttled the ALP's airports transitional bill by putting an amendment that said management at Sydney airport could not be sold until the noise problem was resolved and the noise burden shared equitably. There is no such measure in this bill. Presumably, the coalition believe they have solved the noise problem in Sydney and the noise burden is now equitably shared. This may be news to the residents of Sydney. Personally, I do not think the noise problem has been solved. It has certainly not been solved to the satisfaction of people who live under the flight paths.

The coalition, by discarding its own amendment, has shown itself to be hypocritical. The amendment last year was obviously a spoiling tactic not designed in any way to actually address the problems of the real people who are suffering. All the tears shed by the coalition may have been crocodile tears and, now they are in power, the amendment has gone. The concern for the people of Sydney is not very much evident and you are ready to sacrifice them for the pleasure of selling off public assets.

break.para: My amendment asks you to take cognisance of your own words—your own supposed concern—to behave with integrity and to put your money where your mouth is. The amendment simply says that this bill will not commence and that you cannot sell off the airports until you have demonstrated that you have worked to solve the Sydney noise problem, or done it as equitably as possible. It requires you to do exactly what you as an opposition demanded the former government should do.

My amendment goes a bit beyond yours. For one thing, I ask that you not only attempt to solve the problem in the present but work out a way to ensure the problem is not simply deferred and that you solve it permanently. I ask that you solve it to the satisfaction of the real stakeholders, not to the satisfaction of government, parliament or the Treasury. The real stakeholders are not the Treasury or the buyers who hope to make money from this. The real stakeholders are the people who must live under the planes. I ask you to work to solve the problem to the satisfaction of the councils that lie under the flight paths.

Your amendment said the government should not sell the Sydney airport until they have solved the problem. Mine says you should not sell the management of any airport until you have solved this. I believe that, if you cannot solve the Sydney problem, you will not be able to solve the Brisbane, Melbourne, Perth or any other noise problem that may arise.
If you sell management of these other airports, even if you do not sell Sydney, the problem will eventually arise and you will have no model to resolve them.

I was concerned during the original debate, and put it on record, that we were only dealing with it as if it was a problem in one part of the country. It was defining itself in one part of the country but we had not worked out mechanisms to deal with it in any other part of the country either. There are problems of compensation, noise and safety everywhere there is an airport. Once you go to the point of privatising it, dealing with those issues becomes extremely difficult unless you have a management plan to do so.

If you can work a plan to solve the problem of Sydney, you will have a model for resolution. Both state and territory government, local government and the lessee companies will have a good idea of what to expect, which is fair, and you will be able to plan ahead to make resolution of future problems easier and less expensive. Sydney is therefore a test case. If you cannot resolve this problem, I do not believe that you should be allowed to recreate it under a regime where government has even less control—that is, after we have sold the leases to the airport.

The amendment is simple and modelled on your own. It says that the noise burden must be equitably shared and that it must be clear to councils that this equity can be maintained and that equity does not mean equal but increasing pain but, rather, that the noise problem should not become too onerous. It requires you to get the agreement of councils whose bounds lie within a circle of a 20kilometre radius of the airport and to table that agreement in parliament before this bill, which allows the sale of airport management, can commence.

I commend this amendment to the coalition and Democrats who put forward and voted for a similar amendment last year. But, in my opinion, the amendment last year was hastily written and perhaps had implications for safety which this specifically does not because it deals with working out a plan. It does not specify the plan regardless of safety. It says `. . . to work out a plan which is agreeable' and it looks at a plan for the future, which means that you can factor in safety as part of that.

Providing noise insulation should acknowledge that the noise problem is significant. It is a potential problem in any large city and should be resolved prior to relinquishing control and responsibility. There are other amendments to the Airports Bill which I will be putting later which deal with the specifics of noise management. However, this, I believe, should provide a model to deal with the future and not just Sydney. We are dealing with every FAC airport in the country and we are dealing with proposed increases in traffic which may increase the noise and traffic
burden to a great extent in many parts of the country.

People need to be assured that there might be some model to which to work to resolve these problems in a consultative way. And that is what I am asking today, that there be some accepted model and that there is some confidence in the community that they will be part of this process.

speech.speaker: Collins, Sen Bob

talk.start.para:
—Mr Chairman, for the benefit of the committee, it might be useful to indicate to the government, before Senator Tambling responds, that the opposition will not be supporting this amendment. I am well aware that Senator Margetts is well aware that this amendment is not quite as simple as she would like to portray it.
The amendment, in fact, permanently scuttles the bill.
—A good idea.

—Yes, I know, Senator, but I am part of a team here. It does, in fact, scuttle the bill. I have to say, Senator, with the greatest respect, that I would like to see you get a written agreement between all of the local government councils located within a 20‐kilometre radius of Sydney on garbage disposal, or indeed on anything else. I think that would be quite a challenge.

speech.para: In equitably sharing the noise burden around all of those councils, you would have some amazing flight paths around Sydney airport. They would look something like the magic maze at the Darwin show. It would be a little bit difficult, I think, for the 737s to turn corners quite as sharply as that. It would certainly provide a thrill for the passengers on board.

The amendment—and I know Senator Margetts knows it—is simply putting up a proposition that would never be achieved. In that sense, the key point of this amendment is not noise; it is getting written agreement from all the councils in a 20‐kilometre radius to anything. I do not think that is achievable.

speech.speaker: Tambling, Sen Grant

talker.name: Senator TAMBLING
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

talk.start.para:
—As Senator Collins has indicated, this amendment is simply not achievable.
It is unlikely that there would ever be written agreement on any matter which could be signed by all local government councils within a 20‐kilometre radius of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and Sydney West Airport. When the issue is aircraft noise, it becomes even less likely that there would be agreement. The government has already outlined the approach it will be taking.

speech.para: The real effect of this amendment proposed by Senator Margetts would be to delay the lease of airports, probably forever. It would frustrate completely the government's plans for leasing the airport by making the lease of every airport conditional on an agreement about aircraft noise being signed by Sydney councils. It is therefore not a high hurdle; it is an impossible dream.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —The amendment is not only about noise; it is about air traffic as well. I am well aware that there are a number of airports around Australia which are not frequently part of this debate but which have a problem with air traffic. You have only to drive south down the Mitchell freeway in Perth to find there are a great many small aircraft using Jandakot airport. That is a traffic problem as much as or more than a noise problem. The idea of such a model is to look at ways to have councils somehow involved with the plan. I think councils are sensible enough to know there are good plans and not so good plans. At least that ought to be taken into consideration when those plans are developed.

speech.para:
They were promised all sorts of things which governments said they could achieve in relation to the third runway. Many people felt that what did come about did not relate much to what they were promised in the first place. What people and councils are hoping for is a written agreement so there is something they can come back to when people make promises about the future. It does not mean aircraft going every which way; it means there is some participation in the process and that governments have to make an effort to listen to that concern and talk about what the issues and choices are. If, in the end, this means
utilising more than one airport, then maybe that is the best way to go about it.

Perhaps this is a lesson that we should be learning, that instead of involving councils and the community at a late stage in the process it is best to involve them at an early stage so they are part of it and have realised what the implications and choices are or are not, and the decisions they can make. I am sure there are ways of devising this process so that councils can see that there are optimum outcomes and that that is what they will be working for. I am sure it is possible to devise a system where councils can agree to an optimum outcome.

speech.speaker: Crane, Sen Winston

talk.start.para: —I will just make a few brief comments with regard to this amendment and the proposition put by Senator Margetts. I absolutely have to agree with Senator Tambling and Senator Collins. I draw the attention of Senator Margetts to the committee report. I must also express my concern, in view of the fact that we had state and local governments present evidence to our committee, that the Greens did not see fit to present their amendment to get a response from the state government and the councils which appeared—a significant number.

speech.para: I believe the concerns you raise about consultation and having input have been covered by those recommendations. I will not read them out now because we dealt with them yesterday. But I wish to point out that we did deal with that. The minister has accepted the importance of having local governments, state governments and their regional and state plans included in the consultative process. I believe the concern you have expressed, which is not really consistent with your amendment, has already been accepted by the minister in terms of the processes.

para.tab: Question put:

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —The question now is that the bill stand as printed.

—There is one point I want to make. It is my understanding that the majority of Sydney councils and Sydney constituents are not arguing about the privatisation or otherwise of Sydney airport; they are arguing about the noise problem. I thought I should add that basically there was an assumption there that the bill would have been scuttled if the amendment had gone through. I do not think that that was necessarily the case. There was an incentive for agreement to be reached, and I think the majority of councils around Sydney airport actually felt that the desire was to work to the best possible arrangement.

break.para: I could not tell you—and I do not know whether anybody has any information to say—that the majority of councils around Sydney airport do not want the airport privatised. My opinions on that might be different from theirs. I do not think we can assume that they specifically did not want the airport privatised. I thought I would make the point before we voted on the bill that it was unfair to assume that there would be an inbuilt criterion with any arrangement between councils that they would scuttle the privatisation. I think they wanted an outcome and they wanted the means to reach that.
Bill agreed to.

The bill.

talk.start.para: —At the time the Airports Bill 1996 was debated in the House of Representatives, the opposition moved amendments which would have reinstated the cross-ownership provisions included by the previous government in the Airports Bill 1995 and limited the scope of the ministerial exemption from consultation provisions on draft master plans and environment strategies. The minister indicated these proposals would be given further consideration before debate in the Senate.

break.para: The minister subsequently wrote to the Senate committee considering the airport bills to advise the government's preparedness to reinstate the cross-ownership provisions, the government's preference to remove the two exemption clauses—sections 71 and 117—and the government's intention to make a technical amendment to clause 14 of the schedule to the bill to ensure the provisions related to foreign persons, not foreign companies.

The Senate committee reported at the start of these sittings and recommended that the bills be passed, subject to these three amendments notified to the committee by the minister. I indicate that the government's amendments are consistent with the changes advised to the Senate committee.

I will now address the issue of cross-ownership restrictions. The amendments moved by the government will reinstate the cross-ownership provisions of the Airports Bill 1995 and so will achieve the identical position taken by the previous Labor government on the matter. This change is expected to meet the concerns which have been expressed to the government about the need for separation of the ownership of Sydney airport from Melbourne airport and Sydney airport from Brisbane airport.

The amendments will include in the bill a requirement that the airport lessee and management companies for Sydney airport and Sydney West airport be controlled separately from the lessee or management companies of either Melbourne airport or Brisbane airport. For this purpose, the bill as amended will deem a holding of more than 15 per cent of any of the paid up capital, voting power and rights to distribution of profit and capital to
constitute control. The bill will also provide that the minister may determine that a person has practical control when a person with an interest of less than 15 per cent or no interest effectively has control of a company.

With regard to consultations on draft airport plans, during debate in the House of Representatives the opposition proposed amendments to limit the power of the minister under clauses 71 and 117 to exempt certain draft master plans and environment strategies from the public comment processes established by the bill. The intention of the provisions in the bill was to enable the minister to exempt draft plans in circumstances in which it would have been unreasonable to require public comment and consultation, such as when proposed changes to a plan had resulted from public comment. The government considers that removing the clauses would be simpler than adopting the amendments which the opposition proposed during debate in the House of Representatives, as they are likely to be unworkable. This matter, as I mentioned earlier, was certainly flagged to the Senate committee and considered.

With regard to technical amendments to clause 14 of the schedule, clause 14 applies the 49 per cent limit on foreign ownership to holding companies for airport companies. The clause is intended to provide that the 49 per cent limit on foreign ownership will be applied on the basis of ownership of the holding company. Therefore, for example, a foreign person could own up to 49 per cent of a holding company, with the holding company in turn wholly owning one or more airport operator companies. Without a special provision, such as clause 14, this would not be possible, as the holding company would be characterised as a foreign person and so could hold most of the 49 per cent of an airport company. Commercially, this outcome would be unrealistic.

To ensure that clause 14 serves its purpose, references in it to `a foreign company' need to be replaced by references to `a foreign person', because the foreign ownership limitations in the bill relate to a foreign person rather than a foreign company. The government's amendments address the substantial
concern that was raised in debate and in the Senate committee dealing with the airport bills, and I commend these amendments to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will be supporting these amendments.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —I want to make some brief comments in relation to the government amendments and also to refer to some foreshadowed amendments by the Greens to this legislation. I will not delay the committee stage too much.

speech.para: In Western Australia, particularly at Perth airport, a number of concerns have been raised by people who have a link with and a fascination and a support for the bushland around that airport. I took the opportunity a few weeks ago, with Senator Margetts, some friends of the Perth airport bushland, some conservation groups and also the member for Swan, Don Randall, to do a detailed inspection of those bushland areas.

Many members of the conservation movement in Western Australia who are supporting the Perth bushland have indicated that they are opposed to privatisation, and of course that is their right. They are opposed to it, as they told me and have communicated to me in a number of letters, because they are concerned about conservation outcomes as a consequence of the privatisation.

From my own experience in investigating those sites, it would be fair to say that there are some unique qualities and some beautiful patches of typical Western Australian sandy based bushland which have been recognised by the Australian Heritage Commission in their listing on the national register. The problem is that areas like Mundey's Swamp—one of the unique areas that has been listed—have become overrun with weeds. It has had virtually no money spent on the management of it. Some of the other areas have been spoiled by fires from, we presume, kids getting in there and burning cars or having camps on Saturday nights and by lots of
litter—rubbish, broken bottles, used car bodies—scattered throughout them. It is an area that has some unique, natural qualities and because it is required to be a buffer zone for airport noise and other safety elements around the airport it will, in large part, stay as natural bushland for generations to come and should be considered worthy of rehabilitation and long‐term conservation.

There is a conflict with plans for the future expansion of Perth airport, particularly the development of a further runway when the traffic at Perth airport requires that to be built. The Federal Airports Corporation informed me that that may not be for some 20 or 25 years, based on traffic projections. Nonetheless, as all of us know, the construction of new airports is not only a very expensive business but also a very important business to get right environmentally, as we have seen with the controversy surrounding the Sydney West proposals. It is very important in this bushland around the Perth airport to achieve a sensible balance with the needs of conservation and to ensure that we have our biodiversity and remnant urban bushland protected for a whole range of values, one of the most important being to ensure that the very good people of Perth have the opportunity to see what their countryside looked like before it was developed for urban use. There needs to be a balance for the future needs of Perth airport as well.

It would be environmentally stupid to say that these areas could not be developed in the future, because we would then be required to find another patch of land somewhere near the Perth metropolitan area to develop another—probably $1 billion—airport facility. My own view, which I think is supported by evidence in many parts of the world, is that the privatisation process creates a unique opportunity to see private sector funds being channelled into important rehabilitation of those areas and into long‐term conservation. I think that sensible environmentalists, as I am sure most of them are, should see this as an opportunity and not as a loss for the environment. The successful bidder for Perth airport will be encouraged to submit plans for a whole range of operations at the airport and
I think the environmental plans that those tenderers put forward should form an important part of that process.

It is quite crucial, if we are seriously concerned about conserving the areas around Perth airport, that money is spent on rehabilitation. The weeds need to be controlled. Access by feral animals and access by the public need to be controlled so that particularly the flora and the fauna, the biodiversity qualities and the unique natural heritage qualities of the Perth airport bushland can be preserved and conserved for the future.

I conclude by saying that I will be working in conjunction with the member for Swan, Don Randall, and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, with whom we have already had a meeting to discuss this and who is very keen to ensure that the privatisation process is good for the environment, particularly the environment around the Perth airport. I encourage those people who care about the Perth airport bushland to be involved in this process. I encourage them to interact with the people who place bids for the Perth airport. I will certainly try to facilitate that as the process goes along. I certainly hope and expect that the outcomes for the environment around the Perth airport will be good ones. It should be a win‐win situation for the budget, it will be a win‐win for the travelling public and it will be a win for the bushland around the airport. I support the government's amendments.
Amendments agreed to.

debate.title: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by
Senator Kemp
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —The opposition does not oppose this bill. However, we do feel it necessary to make a few points. The principal act of this measure, the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act, was first dealt with by the parliament in 1991. Essentially, that occurred in the context of the emergence of quite a substantial overseas student services sector of the education industry in this country.

speech.para: Educational services to overseas students were threatened quite significantly by the emergence of some quite extraordinarily unscrupulous providers in the private education sector, some considerable difficulties in regard to the unevenness of quality of both the services provided and the support structures that were available for students, breaches by students of visa conditions, and the financial collapse of several private institutions with the consequent adverse publicity that occurred in overseas countries as a result of students losing considerable sums of money.

The principal act was aimed at trying to restore Australia's reputation for sound educational practice. In particular that act was aimed at overseas countries; it was to ensure that people coming to this country for educational purposes would be treated with some equity and some fairness. Of course, there was an understanding that Australia's reputation had to be protected in so far as the national government had a responsibility to
maintain high quality education and training within this country while, at the same time, balancing out that responsibility with those of the states—which, sadly I note, have yet to respond adequately, as a consequence of which this measure is required. Also, the principal act was aimed at ensuring taxpayers funds were not required to compensate any international students who had been let down by unscrupulous providers, and that unscrupulous individuals were not being subsidised by public moneys.

As far as concerns of the review process that was undertaken, the original report came out in 1992. However, in 1993, upon my becoming a member of the education committee, these issues were revisited. The report was, in fact, quite a good one and has added substantially to our understanding of these issues.

The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has relied quite heavily on the reports of the consultants Ernst and Young which sought to make a contribution to this debate by seeking an extension of the act for a further two years because of the states' failure to respond adequately; by recommending the simplification of existing legislation to ensure that better and more appropriate responsibilities of the Commonwealth be defined; that simpler provider accounts and auditing requirements be instituted; that expanded scope for exemption of detailed financial regulatory requirements be ensured; that there be adequate consultation between the Commonwealth and the states and industry bodies with a view to making sure that this matter was properly reviewed by 1 January 1998; and by ensuring that there be a sunset clause within the current arrangements.

It seems to me that the government's reliance upon regulation in this regard is the means by which the simplification will occur. As I understand, Minister, that is the mechanism which you are seeking to use; that is a regulatory framework. I am not altogether certain how widely understood that regulatory framework is. I would appreciate any comment the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator
Vanstone) would make in that regard. In terms of the changes, it is likely that there will be an extension of the financial matters in regard to the operation of the tuition assurance schemes, where groups of providers jointly guarantee, on behalf of each of their number, that the provision of tuition is paid for overall.

Of course, this is the real problem: that, in the current general climate of deregulation, as I understand it, there has been very little support amongst stakeholders in favour of industry self-regulation. The principal concerns centre on Australia's international reputation in the provision of education services and whether the industry currently has sufficient maturity to ensure self-regulation. These were the issues that the Senate committee examined and reported upon. I am just wondering, Minister, whether or not there has been any change to those circumstances. I look forward to your response in that regard.

As I understand it, stakeholder agreements between the Commonwealth and the providers would continue to have a regulatory function but that regulation entirely by the states or territory governments is not desirable nor is it feasible, given their record in this area. I draw your attention, Minister, to the consultant's report which stated:

. . . there was a need for some continuing Government role in regulation of matters relevant to international students for the foreseeable future and that there was no case for substantial changes to existing policy.
While the opposition does support these measures, I raise those concerns with the minister and I would ask her for a response.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—I thank Senator Carr for his contribution. The regulatory framework, as he probably well knows, involves a cooperative partnership between the Commonwealth, the states, the territories and industry bodies. At the Commonwealth level, the principal act provides assurances of education quality and financial protection to international students studying in Australia by registering providers of international educa
tion and training and by imposing financial conditions on private non-exempt providers.

speech.para: Registration at the Commonwealth level is based on state or territory approval of institutions and courses. Education providers contribute through the tuition assurance scheme, which guarantees that the student's tuition is paid for. I note that Senator Carr raised a concern about the maturity of the industry. I think there is a general understanding that the industry has matured quite substantially over the last couple of years and that the tuition assurance schemes offer an opportunity for that contribution to self-regulation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —Could the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) provide me with information on the number of providers who have been deregistered over the last three years for failing to meet the audit requirements or other provisions of the existing act?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I am just getting some of that information for Senator Carr. To the extent that it does not fulfil what you want today, we will be happy to get it for you as soon as possible. It is limited information that I can give you at the moment. There is a handful, not many, who have been finally deregistered. Quite a lot more have been suspended but, apparently, it often turns out that once people are suspended the suspension is short term. I presume that is because they get their act back together. If you want to give me some questions on notice of the detail and the time period you want it covered for, we will get it for you.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para:
—I do indicate some concern in so far as the provisions have been made for some time for this industry, and it is stated that there has been a growing maturity. But, as I understand it, a few years ago it was found that, in a
particular year, some 22 agencies had failed to meet the audit requirements and had been suspended. I am not altogether certain how many of those ultimately were withdrawn. Given that this is an industry that now involves some $1.9 billion in overseas exports, it is important that we do get it clear as to what is the level of maturity in this industry and the extent to which your officials have adequately supervised this arrangement.

speech.para: While it is said that this is a joint responsibility between the Commonwealth and the states for regulation of these providers, it ultimately comes back to the Commonwealth in terms of its international relationships to ensure that there is high quality provision and an adequate regulatory regime in operation in this country. I think it demonstrates yet again how inadequate the states are when it comes to the question of regulation and the protection of high quality provision of education services in this country.

I would like to know what the changes have been in regard to the enforcement of the audit provisions and the other registration provisions of the existing act; the degree of compliance that has occurred; and the extent to which some of the unscrupulous elements have been weeded out of the industry; what further complaints have occurred since the original act has been instituted; and, as a result, what changes have been made to improve and assure the quality provision in the country.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr is, of course, right: quality of provision is essential if we want to maintain that market. If, as you have put to me, it is correct that in previous years there were 22, all I can tell you is that, even without advice, I would have responded and indicated to you that I have signed a couple of them—less than five, I would have guessed. But I could be wrong; it might be six. If that rate reflects what happens over the whole year then there has been a substantial maturity.

speech.para:
I do not have the figures in front of me, so let us wait and see. If it did go from 22 down to a dozen and there was proper monitoring—
in other words, it did not drop to a dozen due to inadequate monitoring—we would have to say that the industry was maturing. But we will get all that information and give it to you as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

debate.title: HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by
Senator Kemp
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Neal, Sen Belinda

talk.start.para: —The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Amendment Bill 1996 is supported by the opposition. The original bill was introduced during the period of the last government. Essentially, it was brought in to ensure that third party personal claims were not paid out, that moneys owing to the Commonwealth for Medicare, and possibly nursing home costs, were repaid before the plaintiffs received their funds.

speech.para: Although essentially worth while and effective in having Commonwealth funds repaid, unfortunately the legislation had the unhappy consequence for many plaintiffs that, because of the time delay required for the assessment of funds owing to the Commonwealth, in fact they had to wait for very long periods. I am advised by members of the legal fraternity, in particular, that there is a huge backlog as we speak. Essentially, this bill resolves the matter by allowing 90 per cent of the funds to be paid out to the plaintiff and for 10 per cent to be retained until the assessment of moneys owing to the Commonwealth is made. Evidence suggests that, in the vast majority of cases, this will cover the money owed to the Commonwealth, which appears to be, on average, in the range of seven per cent.

break.para: I suppose there are circumstances, though you would think unusual, where the money owed to the Commonwealth will be in excess of that 10 per cent. In those circumstances, I have been assured that the plaintiff will be contacted and some convivial arrangement will be made for the repayment of those funds. I am told that there will not be any unfair pressure put on plaintiffs; that nothing will be repossessed that might make their lives difficult or generally cause problems; and that arrangements will be made, in an orderly fashion, for the repayment of anything beyond that 10 per cent.

Essentially, the opposition supports the legislation. There is, I understand, some retrospectivity in this bill. Generally, in a situation where the effect of legislation adversely affected members of the general community, you would have to be very concerned but, in this case, the retrospectivity acts to the benefit of those members of the public who are affected. That being the case, I am very happy to support it.

speech.speaker: Woods, Sen Bob

talker.name: Senator WOODS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

talk.start.para: —I am delighted that the opposition is supporting this bill but, of course, that is not surprising since it was a mess of your own making.
—Oh come on! Be pleasant for a change.

—I am being very pleasant. I could say a lot worse! The fact is that there are those unintended consequences, but I think there is a broad agreement that we are trying to fix things up for the benefit of the community at large. The support from the opposition is very welcome. This will be of benefit to everybody involved in the process—the government, the lawyers, the insurance companies and, of course, the people who receive compensation or similar payments. We are very happy that there is broad agreement about the importance of this bill.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: The bill.

speech.speaker: Woods, Sen Bob

talker.name: Senator WOODS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

speech.para: Leave granted.

speech.para: These amendments are designed to immediately clear the backlog of cases. Senator Neal has referred to the retrospectivity involved and this is one of the issues in which there is an element of retrospectivity. There is hardship going on, and it is being experienced by a number of people who are compensable.

Since the bill was introduced, much work has been undertaken in ensuring a more efficient and equitable system, and the further amendments improve the bill even more. These improvements are achieved by making the advanced payment process available to all cases, right back to the commencement of the original act on 1 February this year, rather than from the date of the passage of this bill. Since this backlog is quite significant, this will mean a significant benefit to a large number of people.

I would also like to give some assurances about recovery of debts by the Commonwealth, where the amount owing to the Commonwealth is greater than 10 per cent of the advanced payment and where the compensation payer makes an advance payment to the HIC. The settlement of any additional moneys owed to the Commonwealth is negotiated between the HIC and the person. There are a number of steps in that process which I think will allow a sensitive approach to that recovery. If there is disagreement after that process, there is a right of appeal to the AAT, and it is binding on both parties.

The question of 10 per cent might be an issue. Let me address that briefly. There may be a substantial number of cases where the amount owing to the Commonwealth is more
than the 10 per cent advance payment—that is, that the figure which has been chosen is not the correct figure. By way of a disallowable instrument, the minister can determine a higher percentage. That would ensure that, in most cases, the amount held by the Commonwealth would cover the debt and not place an additional burden on the person. Of course, if it goes the other way and the average amount owing to the Commonwealth is less than 10 per cent, the regulations allow the minister to decrease the advance payment percentage to be held. I think that is a very fair and appropriate method which allows flexibility and a commonsense approach.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

speech.speaker: O'Chee, Sen Bill

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Ellison, I seek leave to move a motion relating to the presentation of a report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Newly Arrived Resident's Waiting Periods and Other Measures) Bill 1996 be extended until 10 September 1996.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para:
—Madam President, may I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your appointment as President. I direct my question to Senator Newman, the Minister
representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. I refer to your Meeting our Commitments document, which was released with the budget papers on Tuesday, and specifically to the claim on page 3 of that document that you have met your commitment to maintain spending on funding for public hospitals. How do you reconcile this statement with your government's decision to cut funding to public hospitals by $800 million through a combination of cuts to financial assistance to the states and the cuts to hospital funding grants in the budget?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —I recognise that that is Senator Gibbs's maiden question and I welcome her to the Senate. I understand that some misinformation has been put about about the question of funding to the hospitals. Nevertheless, I am advised that the agreements with the states for hospital funding allow for increases in funding, and those commitments are being met. In addition, there are requirements under the Medicare agreement about issues such as cost shifting.

answer.para: The Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, has made it very clear that of recent years there has been massive cost shifting in the public hospitals of the states onto the Commonwealth. As a result, the Commonwealth has looked to see what it can do to regain some of the finances that are being used contrary to the Medicare agreement by the states.

Although the cost shifting has, in fact, increased by a substantial amount, the amount that is being clawed back by the Commonwealth, I understand, is simply a small proportion of the amount which the states are benefiting from by the cost shifting, which is not really endorsed under the Medicare agreement.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, from your understandable inability to reconcile the irreconcilable, can you undertake to provide an explanation to the Senate before we adjourn today?
—I think I just gave the Senate the explanation.
—My question is directed to Senator Hill. Can you inform the Senate as to the overwhelmingly favourable reaction by various groups to the Howard government's first budget.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —Certainly. It is certainly encouraging to the new government to see the way in which the budget has been received so favourably by an overwhelming number of Australians. It might be disappointing to the Labor Party, but it certainly has set the framework for growth, jobs and greater prosperity—and that is something to be applauded. I will just remind the Senate of a few examples of what has been said—and I do not state them in any particular order. I will start with the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry.
—Ha, ha!
—Well, Labor may not be interested in jobs, but we are. They said:

answer.para: The Federal Government has delivered on its promise to eliminate the deficit and put the Australian economy onto a solid foundation for sustainable non-inflationary growth.
This budget will be good for business confidence and for the entire Australian community.
This is the right budget for Australia's current economic conditions.
I would like to move to the National Farmers Federation, because the coalition is vitally interested in the wellbeing of Australia's rural community. The federation said:
. . . tonight's Budget is likely to boost business confidence, support lower interest rates, and provide the foundation ongoing low inflationary growth.

Just what we would want to achieve. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia, representing the owners of pharmacies in towns and cities throughout the country, welcomed the budget. In particular, it welcomed the announcement that they would be able to become Medicare agencies because, it said:
It will help many rural families who presently have to wait days or longer for Medicare rebates.

Further good news for Australia's rural community. What did the Council on the Ageing say? It said, specifically referring to
the residential care financial contributions that raised a mention in the Senate yesterday:

This money will benefit those nursing homes which have upgraded their buildings and meet quality standards . . . we still have $600m worth of renovations which are needed to upgrade nursing homes to an acceptable standard . . .
There are a number of moves in the right direction including accreditation of residential care, removal of some of the administrative burden to nursing homes and simplification of the payment system.

That is an excellent endorsement. The Motor Traders Association—the motor industry being vital to the Australian economy—commended the government on the reforms to the capital gains system, the rollovers for businesses that I spoke of yesterday. It also made special mention of the exemption on the sale of small businesses for retirement, which is something I had not mentioned yesterday. It has picked up the good points there. The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission said:

Measures which the government should be congratulated on are the introduction of a national strategy to prevent the incidence of child abuse; greater funding for marriage and relationship education; greater recognition of the role of those who care for the frail aged and the disabled; and initiatives to improve rural health services.
It is amazing. Practically every major interest group in Australia has welcomed this budget. The only ones who are opposed to it are on the other side of this chamber. The RSL said:
The Government has recognised the special needs of veterans, cleared up several anomalies in the legislation and made a very welcome commitment to funding the Australian War Memorial.
The Australian Council for Overseas Aid said:

talk.start.para: —Overseas aid!
—That's it, you see. You don't listen. The ACOA said:

answer.para: . . . despite the . . . cut to the aid program . . . the Howard Government's commitment to increase the focus on poverty alleviation has been met.

talk.start.para: —That is certainly an impressive list of endorsements for the Howard government. I know the Senate would be interested to know of any further people who wanted to endorse the Howard government.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —I could take up the whole of question time with the number of endorsements, Senator Boswell. The Housing Industry Association—housing needs a boost in this country—said:

answer.para: The budget elevates to a high priority family assistance, youth employment and small business—the planks of the Coalition's election commitments.

So there is another one. The Real Estate Institute spoke in similar terms. The Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants commended the charter of budget honesty—something that is needed after the dishonesty of the last government. The Minerals Council of Australia said that the budget established a secure basis for Australia's future economic success. I could go on.

I will finish with one that I did notice, and that came from the AWU. The AWU's Ian Cambridge commended the fact that we put an extra burden on higher income earners for the benefit of lower income earners—something that Labor was not prepared to do.

question.speaker: Hogg, Sen John

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I extend my congratulations to you on your election. I address my question to the Minister for Social Security, the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. In the Treasurer's speech on Tuesday night he said:

question.para: . . . the replacement of tax concessions with outlays programs will ensure that the community and the direct beneficiaries of the programs get better value for their tax dollar.

This was the Treasurer's justification for reducing the research and development tax concession and introducing a strategic assistance for research and development program. Why does this same principle not apply to the family tax initiative, which most families will access through the tax system?

talk.start.para:
—It is strange, isn't it; I do not want to be rude about a new senator, but he has not done his homework. The fact is that something like 45 per cent of families will be eligible, if they wish, to have this family tax initiative paid as a fortnightly payment by the Department of Social Security. Families which are on more than the minimum family payment will automatically
