have it paid out of the Department of Social Security unless they choose to have it taken out of their PAYE earnings. So, therefore, the premise on which the senator's question is based is false.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. On the basis of the Treasurer's position, would not the community and the direct beneficiaries of the family tax initiative get better value for their tax dollar if it were paid simply as an increase in the minimum rate of family payment, or is the Treasurer wrong?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —It will be paid along with the family payment. This government has not cut back on family payments in any way. It has increased the benefits to families.

answer.para: While I am on my feet, I will point out that, apart from those opposite, the only people who seem to have a problem with this budget are those on high incomes. I have noticed over a number of press releases, including one by Carmen Lawrence, that a number of people in the opposition seem to be spending their time advocating on behalf of the high income earners.

I can only presume that the problem they are facing now in opposition is that we represent the battlers. We have done what the battlers voted us in to do by providing family tax initiatives, by providing health tax initiatives and by supporting small business so that the children of the battling families can get jobs.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I, too, add my congratulations to you on your recent appointment. My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to the government's 16 July announcement of new funding arrangements and the future role and priorities of the ABC. What has been the ALP's response to the announcement? Do any of the policy pronouncements made by Senator Schacht since that time commend themselves to the government?

—On a point of order, Madam President. This is a question about the ALP. It should be directed to the ALP; it should not be directed to a government
minister. That minister, as far as I know, is not a member of the ALP—overtly, covertly or in any other way—and he is not in a position to answer the question. It is not his portfolio responsibility to talk about the ALP.
—Part of the question related to Senator Schacht and he certainly is a member of this chamber and a shadow minister, I understand.
—On the point of order, Madam President: are you saying that the minister cannot answer any part of the question other than that part that only deals with Senator Schacht?

interject.speaker: ALSTON

talk.start.para: —On the point of order, Madam President: it is unfortunate that Senator Cook did not hear the latter part of the question, which was:

interject.para: . . . do any of the policy pronouncements made by Senator Schacht since that time commend themselves—

talk.start.para: —Where did you get the question from?

interject.speaker: ALSTON

talk.start.para: —I just borrowed it from Senator Calvert. It is his question. It continues:

interject.para: . . . to the government?

It is quite clear that what is being sought in this question is a response to the quantity and quality of Senator Schacht's contribution to the debate about the ABC and an indication about whether we propose to adopt those suggestions.

talk.start.para: —On the point of order: can I ask what part of this question you are ruling in or out of order. It has been a matter of contention here for a long while as to whether ministers can comment on opposition policy or views. I suppose that during the life of the Labor government something like 500 points of order were taken and mixed rulings were given with some parts in and some parts out. Since this is the first time it has arisen, even if you are not in a position to articulate an exact ruling now, you might give it some thought so that at least there will be guidance there in future.

—Madam President, on the point of order, because it is an important
issue: there have been occasions when objections were taken by our side that—
—Ha, ha!

—I am simply saying this. The ruling from the chair was consistently that you could not simply ask the government what thoughts they had about opposition policy. They had to be related to government policy. In other words, your responsibility is to indicate what the government's attitude is to policy positions and pronouncements, and to indicate whether you are prepared to adopt them. Senator Ray would accept that, I am sure. That is why this question has no doubt been very carefully drafted by Senator Calvert in the way that it has been—to ensure that it is not simply to do with Senator Schacht's view of the world but to know whether that commends itself to the government.

—Senator Ray, I will have a look at it and come back. I know what I think it was when I heard it, but I think Senator Alston should answer the question in relation to matters that are within his responsibility, and I shall come back to you if I think there is anything further that needs to be said.

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —On 16 July I put out a 2½‐page press release which went into a great deal of detail about some proposals in relation to the ABC. It did not of course relate to just funding proposals. It related to the establishment of a committee of review by an eminent Australian, Bob Mansfield, to look at the roles and priorities of the ABC. It made it quite clear that we were honouring our election commitment because we had said that we would maintain existing levels of funding for the period of the current triennium. That is why—
—That's not what you said. For the life of the parliament you said.
—Look at the policies.
—Order!
—For the life of the parliament, Richard.

—Order! You will have an opportunity to raise matters in taking note
of answers. During this period you should listen to the answers that are being given.
—The point is that our policy document made it crystal clear that we would maintain the existing level of funding. That is why—
—You have been caught out lying, Richard. You are dead, Richard.
—That is why we did not, for this current financial year, do anything other than impose the two per cent efficiency dividend cut.
—You said for the life of the parliament, Richard.
—Senator Schacht!
—The ABC, therefore, maintained its current level of funding for this financial year.

answer.para:
Senator Schacht interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht!
—Well, he's lying.
—Senator Schacht, you will have your opportunity.

—We announced for the following financial year a $55 million reduction. If you look at the impact of that, you will find the ABC actually gets $9 million extra in this financial year and in the following year it gets a nominal reduction of $35 million, which, as a proportion of its total revenue, is about 5½ per cent. But we went on to talk about ATV and tendering out the proposals. We talked about taking back the unspent money for pay TV.

answer.para: So what was the response of Senator Schacht, who, after all, is the nominal shadow minister for communications? Twenty-four hours later he managed to put out six lines. What were they about? They were about ABC industrial action being totally justified. In other words, he thought he had better raise himself up, give the unions a bit of a free kick, bag management, as usual, and put out six lines—even though those six lines were fundamentally wrong.

talk.start.para: —You're the one who has lied, Richard. You're the liar.
—He said that we are attempting to interfere in the management and programming of the ABC.
—Senator Schacht, would you withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.
—He obviously was not aware of what Gareth Evans had said when he was the relevant minister.
—Order! Senator Schacht, will you withdraw that remark.
—I withdrew.
—He obviously was not aware of what Gareth Evans, as the relevant minister, said in 1988. He said:

answer.para: We simply cannot seriously or sensibly address the question of funding for the ABC without at the same time looking seriously and sensibly at its role and objectives.

So is Gareth Evans wrong? What did we then get after that? About three weeks later we got another effort. This time he managed to drag himself up to about half a page. What was it about? It was about bagging ABC management, expressing his concern about reports that ABC staff were under increasing pressure not to raise the issue. So he called on management to defend the right of staff.

So that is the level of contribution we have had about this debate. All the big issues are there—the level of funding into the 21st century, what the impact of new technology will be, the decisions that the ABC has taken that have gone sadly astray, whether we review the role of the charter.

talk.start.para: —You just misled the Senate on what you yourself said.

—But, no, there was not a single word about it. What did we get? He finally managed to call a press conference on 16 August, last week, to announce that he was launching a campaign to save Triple J. Of course, he had to do this in Adelaide; he did not want to stray too far from home.
—You broke your promise on that yesterday.
—Senator Schacht, you have interjected continuously.
—Because he's telling lies, Madam President.

—And what did he do? He said it was in danger of being closed down completely—absolutely wrong. Then he goes on and gets stuck into us. He says our family values policy is hypocritical. He says that we are ignoring young Australians, that our conservative platitudes are a patronising insult for Australia's young people. In other words, he does not believe in family values, he does not think the ABC should either and he certainly does not think the ALP should. So what do we have? Just anti-family rhetoric. That is the full extent of his contribution. So is it any wonder that Hugh Mackay, in Saturday's
Australian
, said this—
(Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask—
—Point of order, Madam President. I did raise—
—Order! Senator Calvert, please wait.
—I ask a supplementary question.
—Order! Senator Calvert, I am not surprised you could not hear me.

—I am thinning down a bit, but I did rise before Senator Alston finished his answer so I could raise a point of order. The last two minutes of Senator Alston's answer were just a diatribe against Senator Schacht, and nothing to do with Senator Alston's portfolio. He has, I think, grossly transgressed the guidelines that you laid out. I just reiterate, Madam President, that it probably does need a reassessment and guidelines issued on those sorts of answers. I do not expect a response now.
—Senator Schacht has grossly transgressed the standing orders throughout the whole of that answer.

—Madam President, on Senator Ray's point of order: your ruling on Senator Ray's point of order I do not believe addressed the substance of the contribution by Senator Ray, who asked you to take action in relation to the substantive issue he raised
earlier when the original question had been asked by Senator Calvert. Whatever your views might be in relation to Senator Schacht's contribution during Senator Alston's answer, the substantive issue raised by Senator Ray was completely different.

—I shall have a look at it along with the original question, which I undertook to do earlier. It was almost impossible to fully understand what Senator Alston was saying, with the constant barrage of noise from Senator Schacht. I shall look at the whole issue and report back later.
—I thank Senator Alston for his comments about the comments made by the shadow minister. I would like to ask you, though, Senator Alston—
—Senator Calvert, your question should be addressed to the chair, not directly to Senator Alston.
—Have any other members of the opposition opposite or in the other place had anything at all to contribute to the debate about the ABC since 16 July?

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Clearly the supplementary question that has been asked by Senator Calvert—the direct invitation to now comment on other members of the opposition—is not a supplementary question to the original one asked by Senator Calvert and, without doubt, transgresses all precedence in relation to question time behaviour in this place. I ask you, Madam President, given that Mr Howard particularly promised new parliamentary standards in the life of this parliament if the coalition were elected, to rule Senator Calvert's supplementary question out of order forthwith.

—It is my view that supplementary questions—and I have looked into this matter in the last few days—have strayed considerably from the original ruling that supplementary questions should arise from only the answer that was given. Looking at supplementary questions over a considerable period of time, it is very clear that that has for some time not been the practice—that supplementary questions have been asked supplementary to the original question and not
supplementary to the answer. To rule this out of order at this point would change the whole structure of supplementary questions as they have been asked and dealt with over the last couple of years or more. If that is what you want to do, then I think it is a matter that the committee should have a look at as to whether the fundamental structure of supplementary questions is to be changed.

—I raise a further point of order, Madam President. I thank you for your ruling in relation to the issue I raised on the supplementary question. I ask you to rule whether it is competent for Senator Calvert to invite Senator Alston to comment on matters that have been raised by other members of the opposition as a supplementary question or, for that matter, whether it would even be competent to be any sort of question—a primary question. I understand that you have made a ruling in relation to one part of the point of order I have taken. I ask you to rule now on the substantive issue of whether Senator Calvert's invitation, as contained in his supplementary question, is in order.
—Only to the extent that he may comment on government policy in relation to the issues.
—That's a shonky decision.

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam President. It is—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order about respect for the chair in this place.
—You just jumped in front of your deputy.
—It is a bit hard for me to ask you to require Senator Bolkus to withdraw, but he should withdraw that.
—I did not hear what was said.
—It is a good thing you did not hear, then.
—I don't think it is outside standing orders.

—I will have a look in the
Hansard
, if it is in the
Hansard
. Other than a noise, I did not hear the substance of it.

—There are some very important policy issues at stake here and I think the Australian electorate is entitled to know where both sides of politics stand on issues such as whether or not you think the ABC charter should be amended to include references to rural areas, whether it should include references to news and current affairs and whether it should include references to children's television—just to name three.

answer.para: I do not expect Senator Schacht to be terribly familiar with the Juneau report on Canadian broadcasting or even the recent changes to the BBC, but I would have thought that the opposition might have had something to offer on these very important issues. That is the great tragedy of this debate and that is why Hugh Mackay says, `Who is the opposition spokesman on the ABC? Would you believe me if I said it was Senator Schacht?' Quite frankly, I would not; because if you look at those press releases you see that the first two were obviously attempts to try to muscle in on the industrial relations portfolio. When he got the flick on that, the last one on Triple J presumably is an attempt to get the youth affairs portfolio. That does not help the debate on the important issues in this country.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. The whole plan of this question to Senator Alston is now revealed. Firstly, most part of the original question was out of order. Most part of the original answer was out of order. Most part of the supplementary was out of order. Now Senator Alston is out of order in not talking about his portfolio but having an unmitigated attack upon Senator Schacht. That is not the purpose of question time. You should sit him down now because we have enough evidence that there is no intention of actually asking a question on the portfolio or answering one.
—The time for the question has expired.

—My congratulations also, Madam President, on your election to high office. My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Senator New
man, your government is proposing to spend $3.5 billion on the family tax initiative. At the same time, you expect to save $2.6 billion from a range of initiatives to tighten up on social security and welfare. These include, according to the Treasurer, strengthening the activity test for jobsearch and newstart allowances and improving fraud detection and debt recovery. Can you detail to the Senate and to the millions of Australians whose wellbeing depends on government assistance the assumptions on which those $2.6 billion in savings are based?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —It is pretty clear that most Australians are concerned about the social security system and I have found, in the six months I have had this portfolio, that that has been one of the strong messages that have come from the wider community. It is a matter of some concern to me, because if people genuinely in need of income support are not to be demonised in our country then their receipt of benefits has to be regarded as being produced by a clean and efficient system where only those eligible for benefits actually get them. Having said that, there has been considerable evidence over some time that the more resources that go into protecting the system from fraud and abuse the more the system produces savings. So it is cost‐effective to put more work into trying to locate those who would cheat the system.

answer.para: The debate often gets bogged down in how many of this and how many of that. The fact remains that there are people who were abusing the system under the previous government, and they made some attempts to do something about it. But the senator is new enough not to know, for example, that it took Senator Patterson in opposition to discover that prisoners in gaols were being paid social security benefits when they were not entitled to them. In other words, we must have good and accurate information on which to base eligibility.

I would suggest that, even if some people in politics seem to like the idea of dead men voting, not many Australians like the idea of dead men getting pensions. There has not been any attempt, I have discovered, to do something in an efficient and orderly way
about finding out whether people are actually still on this planet—as to whether they should be getting the benefits that are being paid to them.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. Senator Newman has been asked to outline to the Senate the assumptions on which $2.6 billion of savings are based. I ask you to draw her attention to the substantive question and to direct her to answer it.
—Senator Newman, you should be answering the question that has been asked of you.
—Madam President, I would dispute with you as to whether I am answering the question. I am afraid I am answering it directly. The assumptions on which—
—I raise a further point of order. I would ask you to ask Senator Newman to withdraw that direct reflection she has made on the chair.
—I do not regard it as a reflection on the chair. She has said that she believes that she is answering the question. I have asked her to direct her answer to the question Senator Bishop has asked.

—I raise a further point of order, Madam President. Senator Newman disputed the ruling you gave in answer to my point of order, and I ask you again to ask Senator Newman to withdraw that reflection on you.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. Senator Faulkner has been hoist with his own petard. On the one hand, he is asking you to rule Senator Newman as being out of order because she has expressed a view to you after you have made a remark. And yet he expresses a view to you, you make a remark back and, because he does not agree with it, he challenges it again. If he is entitled to do it, Senator Newman is entitled to do it. Can he not see the equality here? What is the matter with him?
—Thanks for that explanation, Amanda. You have been a big help to the President.
—A big help. Senator Newman should be answering the question asked by Senator Bishop.

—Thank you, Madam President. As I say, I think I am answering it and certainly it is clear that the shadow minister, who did not ask this question, does not really understand the basis on which the government believes that these savings are available. There is a great deal of need to clean up this system after 13 years of Labor mismanagement. Some of the savings that we believe will be made under this $2.6 billion heading relate to the extraordinary complexity of the system that Labor developed over those 13 years.

answer.para: I was interested that we have had the former minister, Mr Baldwin, talk in these terms late in his stewardship of the portfolio. We have had Mr Latham make an excellent and interesting speech during the winter break, very largely on the areas that we are covering here in this question—which is quite interesting because as far as I know he has not yet been appointed to be the shadow minister for social security. So the leadership that one would expect the Labor Party to have on social security issues is not being given by the spokesman, who does not know—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Madam President. Senator Newman has been asked a very clear question: to provide to the Senate the assumptions on which $2.6 billion of savings were based. I think that has little to do with Mr Latham; perhaps it has very little to do with me. But the question is clear, and you should direct her to answer it.
—You should be answering the question, Senator Newman.

—Madam President, I appreciate that. The assumptions are quite clearly that the government is advised that there is that amount of savings over four years to be obtained from a system which we inherited from the Labor Party, including people such as those using maiden names as well as their married names to get two lots of entitlements and people using aliases, et cetera. I can assure the Senate that the system we have inherited has a substantial amount of work to do to clean itself up so that those
who get benefits in this country are regarded as being genuinely entitled.
(Time expired)

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Is it not true, Senator Newman, as the
Age
editorial pointed out yesterday, that essentially your government is taking from the poor to provide for middle‐class people?
—The answer is no.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the National Assembly of the Republic of Korea, led by the Speaker, His Excellency Mr Kim, Soo Han. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

para.emphasis: Mr Kim, Soo Han was thereupon seated accordingly.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Minister, having re‐read the coalition's 55 election policies and taking into account Tuesday's budget, it seems that over the three‐year term of this government you intend breaking $12.5 billion worth of promises. And that is more than twice the $5.4 billion of promises you claim you have kept. So how can the Prime Minister therefore award himself seven out of 10 for delivering election commitments? Why is it not three out of 10? Is that not a more appropriate reflection of the measurement?

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para:
—Senator Kernot, I have to say, has a
creative imagination. What I noticed was that one highly respected journalist awarded the opposition five out of 10 on its performance so far this week.
—That was generous.

—The journalist was generous! As I said yesterday, in many ways we should be applauded for being able to deliver on so many major promises—the promises to families; the promises on health care; the promises to small businesses; the promises to the elderly—to a background in which we were most grievously misled, as were all the Australian people, as to the state of the books. Because, Senator Kernot, you will acknowledge that we said during the election, `Open the books so that we can make all our costings pursuant to those figures.' What did we get instead? I quoted Mr Beazley yesterday. He said:

answer.para: We believe that we have both a surplus now and expect that surplus to improve, as figures indicated, over the next three or four years. We're anticipating moving into structural surplus.
It reinforced the sorts of things that Senator Cook had said in this chamber. He said—and he will remember, I am sure:
We are a government of energy. We are a government of vision. We are a government of renewal. Our budget will be balanced and in surplus. Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus.
When we came to office, Senator Kernot—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, on a point of order, standing order 194 on relevance: my question asked about your $12.5 billion worth of commitments you are not keeping. I am not asking about Mr Beazley's budget. I am asking about this government's proportion of election promises not met. When it is twice as much as you are claiming you are meeting, I am asking about the Prime Minister's ability to say he deserves a seven out of 10 rating. You are not answering that question.

—As I said, I do not accept the premise to that question. I said that it is the subject, I regret to say, of a very vivid imagination. I am saying we deserve probably nine out of 10 for having been able to achieve so much in all those major promises that we made—do you want to hear them again?—when they had to be calculated to a background where nobody told us that on the first day in office we would find that the books were $8,000 million in the red.

break.para: So we then picked up the responsibility not only to keep the promises that we made during the election but also to address that enormous deficit. What we have been able to do, and we stand here proudly claiming we have been able to do, is to, within the course of this parliament, get that budget into surplus. And that will be a fantastic achievement for the benefit of everyone who wants a job in this country; for the benefit of those who are in jobs, because Labor's record was not only high unemployment but also falling real wages; and for the benefit of small business so that they can grow because it keeps pressure off interest rates—something not only the Labor Party but, I would respectfully suggest, Senator Kernot should applaud.

talk.start.para: —Senator Hill, in Mr Howard's response to last year's budget, he quite clearly said he believed there was an $8 billion deficit and not a surplus at all. I seek leave to table from the budget papers the list—the $12.446 billion worth of broken promises.
—Is leave granted?
—I haven't seen it.
—Leave is not granted.
—Am I being denied leave?
—I thought I heard someone say no. Is leave granted for Senator Kernot to table the document she has referred to?
—Even though she hasn't given me the usual courtesies, yes.
—Sorry, I can't hear what he is saying.
—The comment was that he had not had a chance to look at the document, but he was not refusing leave.
—It is all from the budget papers but collated in the one table, unlike the budget papers. May I ask Senator Hill to look at it and decide?

interject.speaker: PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Yes.

interject.para:
Government senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para:
—You weren't going to put all your budget promises in the one page,
were you, and show how many you had broken?
—Order!
—Senator Hill, may I ask you, please, how you believe the Charter of Budget Honesty will break the ritual of unaffordable promises before election campaigns broken after election campaigns?

—Madam President, on a point of order: we ought to be very clear on what is being sought here. I understood Senator Kernot to say that this was a document from the budget papers. Having obtained leave on that basis, do I now understand that it is in fact a compilation of her own imagination about budget cuts? If it is, then she ought to seek leave on that basis.

—Madam President, on the point of order: in accordance with the standing orders of this place, Senator Kernot sought leave to table a document. Leave was granted in a churlish way by Senator Hill. Nevertheless, leave was granted. Then Senator Campbell came down and said to Senator Hill, `What a wimp you are, Robert. Deny leave.' That is what happened. And now the pretender to the throne, Senator Alston, gets up to try to undermine Senator Hill. Have the guts, Senator Hill, to stick with your word.
—Senator Faulkner! Address your remarks through the chair.

interject.speaker: CAMPBELL

talk.start.para: —Madam President, on the point of order, if Senator Faulkner can keep his mouth shut for long enough to listen: he was correct—

interject.para:
Opposition senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—The point of order is that Senator Kernot did seek leave to table a document. The point that was not made is that, even though you can do that under standing orders, there is a courtesy in this place that you show people the document and you do not misrepresent what that document is before that. Senator Kernot has not done that, and she was granted leave anyway—and that is the point. The only point you make is to misrepresent yourself because you could not lie straight in bed, Senator Faulkner.

interject.speaker: VANSTONE

talk.start.para: —On the point of order, Madam President, I do think it is worth clarifying one particular point and that is that Senator Kernot did say that she sought leave to incorporate or table a document listing the broken promises. Senator Hill then looked as if to say, `You haven't shown it to us,'—and I will be happy to apologise if I am wrong, but I don't think I am—and I think Senator Kernot said, `Look, it's from the budget papers.' The clear implication in her remark and the clear innuendo she wanted to pass to Senator Hill, who no doubt couldn't hear the whole conversation because he had to put up with this babble going on, was that all she wanted to do was table a page from the budget papers.

interject.para: While Senator Hill was being distracted by the riffraff on the other side putting their view forward, Senator Kernot, feeling a little embarrassed at the deception she had played, said, `Well, I've put these bits together from the budget papers.' In other words, she was never trying to incorporate a document from the budget papers—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I was raising—

—Order! Resume your seats for a moment, please. The present situation is that Senator Vanstone was speaking to a previous point of order which has not yet been resolved. I think that ought to be resolved, Senator Kernot, before we come to yours.
—In conclusion, Madam President, I simply wanted to clarify the point that Senator Kernot later sought to make it clear that what she really wanted to table—
—Senator Kernot?
—I want to raise the point of order—
—Order! Senator Vanstone is speaking to the previous point of order.

interject.speaker: KERNOT

talk.start.para: —She is reflecting on my motives.

interject.para:
Government senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Excuse me, I can take a point of order on the point of order.

—The point I am trying to make is that Senator Kernot later sought to make it clear that what she really wanted leave to incorporate was a document she put together which she assures us is from the budget papers. But as Senator Alston pointed out, there is no document in the budget papers headed `Broken Promises'. For someone who purports to represent the party that will keep the you know whos honest, that was a very deceptive line for Senator Kernot to play.

—Madam President, I was wanting to ask on the point of order whether it was appropriate for Senator Vanstone to be interpreting what I said and what my motives were. I would like to have the opportunity to speak to that point of order.
—You may now speak to the point of order.
—Thank you. Irrespective of other people's interpretations, it is true that I used the term `from the budget documents' and when Senator Hill—
—Shame!
—Order! It is necessary that I hear what is being said.
—When Senator Hill raised an eyebrow about it, I clarified that it is a compilation. Senator Hill now has it. He has had an opportunity to look at it. I now ask for leave to table this document.

interject.speaker: HILL

talk.start.para: —I gave leave about 10 minutes ago, Madam President.

interject.para:
Honourable senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Hill is now about to answer Senator Kernot's supplementary question, if he can remember that far back after all the interruptions.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para:
—I guess that, firstly, I should apologise to our visitors for the opposition in this place. It does not always happen but when an opposition is bereft of questions at an important time like this you have a circus. I regret that Senator Kernot was somewhat misleading in what she said. That is the reason you normally show someone a document you wish to table before you seek leave. Nevertheless, it is a Democrats‐produced document, a compilation of figures
taken from the budget—the budget figures might have been a starting point. I recognised it as such and I gave her leave to table the document.

answer.para:
Her question was, in effect: does the record of the last government demonstrate the need for a charter of budget honesty. The answer, obviously, is yes because the Australian people were deceived at the last election by a Prime Minister who was not prepared to open the books. Now there is a lot of criticism subject to that because promises have been made on the basis of figures that turned out to be false. That will not happen again, as a result of our decision.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Yesterday in question time, Mr Howard said, `We made promises to older Australians and we have kept those promises in full.' I ask the minister: can you inform the Senate when and where Mr Howard promised to remove dental benefits from holders of health care, health benefits, pensioner concessions and Commonwealth seniors cards? Can you inform the Senate when and where Mr Howard promised to cut $83.5 million from the lump sum advance scheme for pensioners and allowees? When and where did he promise older Australians that they would be worse off by 50c a prescription for pharmaceuticals; and when and where, after having promised a pension bonus scheme, did he tell pensioners it was just another disposable promise?

—I think it is interesting that the opposition is prepared to focus on something in this budget on which the government has a very good record; that is, the care of older Australians. I notice that the opposition spokesman made no mention of the fact that the government had made a commitment to maintain the pension at 25 per cent of total male average weekly earnings. Not only has the government honoured that commitment; it has done what the previous government did not do in all its 13 years, that is, make provision in the forward estimates for that pension rate to be maintained.

break.para: Of course, that may not be fascinating material for an opposition that ignored it while in government, but it gives security for future income for older people, and that has to be the most basic promise that you could possibly keep. In addition we promised, twice a year, to index the pension. And that is being kept. In addition, we promised low income retirees that they would have an effective tax rate comparable to that of pensioners. That we have kept. Despite what we heard from Senator Neal last night, we have increased by 6.7 per cent the funding for the HACC scheme, which is of course of very great importance to older Australians.

talk.start.para: —Increased funding, eh?

—Yes; interesting, isn't it? I told the Senate yesterday what exactly was going to happen to the HACC scheme; I did not in fact mention the increase. It will go from $423 million to $451 million, so that is more good news for older Australians. When you look at what has happened to older Australians under the previous government, we see in the aged care area, for example—

—I take a point of order. Madam President, I asked a specific question in relation to a number of budget measures, of when and where Mr Howard made certain promises. Could you direct this minister to answer the question?
—Senator Newman, can you deal with the answer to the question.

—Yes, of course I can deal with the answer. I am giving the former minister of the Keating government the information that he does not like to hear; that is the problem with it. You see, Madam President, the former government, when it was supposedly caring for older Australians, was ignoring a number of reports, including one that it commissioned from Professor Gregory, as to the care of older Australians in nursing homes. Professor Gregory said something like $600 million should be put into the aged care area if we were going to improve the standard of care for older Australians. Now that has to be about the most serious indictment of a government's stewardship—

—I take a point of order, Madam President, on relevance. I asked this minister a very specific question in relation to a small number of budget measures. She is reading from the wrong brief. I ask you to direct her to answer the question of where and when Mr Howard gave the commitments in my question.
—Senator Newman, you should be answering the question asked by Senator Faulkner.

—Madam President, I believe I am answering the question asked by Senator Faulkner; it is just that he does not like hearing the answer. As I said, we are now moving as fast as it is possible to do to provide improved accommodation for older Australians after the stewardship of the Labor Party over 13 years. We have got a significant backlog to deal with because of their failure to grasp the nettle.

break.para: In addition, we have had to face other decisions which are not as palatable. And why have we had to face those? Once again because of the stewardship of the Labor Party in government and their mismanagement of the government books. Why else are we faced with these difficult decisions? Having protected older Australians to that maximum I have just outlined, we have had to take some savings decisions that we would have preferred not to have taken if we had not had the books left in the state they were in. That is the problem.

However, on matters such as the advances, for example, that Senator Faulkner asked about, the advances are being maintained to one a year—$500 per year, per beneficiary. I do not think that is an unreasonable thing to leave in. When it comes to the pharmaceuticals issue—
(Time expired)

talk.start.para:
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Newman, where and when did Mr Howard promise to remove dental benefits; where and when to cut $83.5 million from the lump sum advance scheme for pensioners and allowees; where and when did he tell older Australians they would be worse off by 50c per prescription for pharmaceuticals; where and when, having promised the pension bonus scheme,
did he tell pensioners that he would just ignore that promise? If you cannot answer where and when Mr Howard gave those promises, perhaps you might have, Senator Newman, the courage to point out—
—Senator Faulkner, address your remarks through the chair.

—Through you, Madam President, if she cannot answer those questions, perhaps she might have the courage to point out to the Prime Minister that his assertion that the government has kept its promises to older Australians in full was utterly deceitful?

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam President. I do not know why Senator Faulkner thinks he has to bully in order to get an answer. I also wonder whether he thinks I am deaf because in fact if he keeps it up I will be deaf. Can I address the question of the pension bonus scheme? This government has not, in any shape or form, walked away from the pension bonus scheme. It will be delivered. It has not been delivered in the first budget because of the difficulties that we have been left with in the finances and because it is a complex issue which required my department to put in considerable man and woman hours during a very busy budget work‐up stage. So it is still there and it is coming forward. I am sure he will be disappointed to hear that.

answer.para:
In relation to the question of pharmaceuticals, Madam President, you might be interested to know that the research that has been done by a couple of government departments has indicated that pensioners are in fact on average claiming 31—
(Time expired)

talk.start.para:
—I address my question to Senator Short, the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. In regard to your response to my question on post‐consumer recycled paper on 28 May this year in which you told the Senate that the government's purchasing policy for recycled paper products encourages buyers to purchase goods and service with the least environmental impact, I now ask: is it true that for the common use arrangement for
purchase of tissue paper, BG85, unlike the current buyers' guide, the draft buyers' guide for tendering contains little or no information about the environmental purchasing policy; and that, of the eight criteria in the buyers' guide, only five non‐environmental criteria have a weighting, and that recycled content has a zero weighting; and that this draft is proposed to replace the current guide when the contract goes to tender later this year?
—I thank Senator Margetts for the question and also for giving me some notice just before question time that she was proposing to ask it.
—Don't worry, Jim, I won't do that to you.

—I bet you won't. I have sought some advice from the Minister for Administrative Services. In the limited time available, I cannot give you a detailed response to the first two of your questions, so I will come back to you on those. However, so far as the most important aspect of your question is concerned—that is, the third part—I can advise that, in the final version of the tender document to which Senator Margetts referred, information about environmental purchasing policy will be prominent, and that the assessment criterion for recycled comment will have a weighting.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Instead of `recycled comment', I think the minister meant `recycled content', but it is quite clear that that might be the problem as well. Note (d) on page 3125 of the budget paper says that the paper recycling assistance program is being withdrawn as part of the savings to the DEST portfolio. Does this not indicate the government's lack of commitment to paper recycling and to effective greenhouse measures? How is your policy on recycled paper reflected in information put forward to potential bidders? How is the information in bids used to assess environmental impact?

—We obviously regard environmental considerations, including recycling, as very important. We have made that clear over and over again and we will continue to do so in the future. I can only
repeat to Senator Margetts what I said in my first answer to her; that is, when the tender documents in regard to this matter go out later in the year, the final version will give prominent information and coverage to environmental purchasing policy and the assessment criterion for recycled content will have a weighting.

—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the
Notice Paper
.

speech.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talker.name: Senator PARER
talker.role: Minister for Resources and Energy)

talk.start.para: —I wish to table a Department of Primary Industries and Energy portfolio evaluation for the ethanol bounty scheme and seek leave to make a short statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The evaluation was managed and coordinated by a senior officer from the Bureau of Resource Sciences, who also undertook parts of the investigation. The Bureau of Resource Sciences and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics were engaged to undertake specific elements of the investigation. The evaluation was conducted under the direction of a steering committee with representatives from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy; the Department of Finance; the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories; the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism; and the Department of Transport. The committee was chaired by the assistant secretary of the electricity task force. It met five times during the evaluation.

speech.para: The recommendations in the report were unanimously agreed to by the steering committee. The committee found that, in light of the conclusions of the evaluation, the ethanol bounty scheme in its current form would not achieve its objective and should be discontinued at the current time. An important component of the evaluation was information provided by a number of key stakeholders, including representatives from industry, research groups and state and Commonwealth government agencies.

speech.speaker: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked today, relating to the 1996‐97 budget.

talk.start.para: —Were they answered?

—It is a very important point you make, Senator West, because there were no answers given to the questions put to Senator Newman today. What we are now very aware of is that the mumbo jumbo that Senator Newman did give by way of answer indicates clearly to this side of the chamber that she does not know what she is talking about. She does not know her own portfolio area. She does not know how to answer in relation to social security. She certainly cannot tell us the facts about health. She cannot tell us about changes in tax arrangements. And she certainly does not know any answers to specific questions in her own portfolio area. I note for the record that Senator Newman is not inclined to stay while this attack is being made on her.

speech.para: It is a clear matter for record that today, just like yesterday, Senator Newman does not know the answers to questions about HACC. She could not find the right briefing note and took until today to even get around to talking about that. Her answers today were of exactly the same order—no substance, obfuscation, personal abuse and anything to avoid substantive answers to the questions. That is because she is part of a government that wants to tell the people of Australia that the government has given them something good in this budget. They do not like to deal with what was so succinctly exposed, not only by Mr Beazley and Mr Evans and other people in this place but also by Senator Kernot today: you might have given people $5 billion, but you have taken away $12.5 billion. All those promises are broken promises.

Why on earth did you not tell elderly Australians that if they needed assistance with their dental care they would not be getting it? Where, in the run up to the election, did you
say that to people? You said, `We will not do anything to make life harder for older Australians.' But you have, Senator. It is going to be a matter of great regret as the people in the community understand what you have done by way of deceit, by way of broken promises, by way of damage to Australian families, and by way of damage to older Australians. The people are realising it now.

In today's
Bulletin
, 52 per cent of people said that, if they had the chance again, they would not be voting this way. You have polished deceit and obfuscation and misrepresentation to an art form, and the Australian people will not cop that a second time around. Senator Newman cannot answer her questions with any substance. She will duck and twist and weave rather than face the truth of the deceptions and lies the opposition told in the run‐up to the election.

What about elderly Australians being assisted by having to find at least $26,000 to go into a nursing home? What about Mr Howard saying today, by way of helping families, `If they can't find money, I expect their children to help them'? Families live in great fear that some of their older relatives might need to retire to a nursing home or hostel. They are finding it bad enough to deal with that without this great gift you have given them of having to pay $26,000 to even get in.

That is what you have done to those people. That is one of the problems. You have removed their access to dental services. You have increased the cost of prescriptions. Elderly Australians, who are more likely to visit the doctor, who are more likely to need prescriptions and who need dental care, are the people you have just abandoned with these policies.

This is a classic Thatcher, tory, conservative budget. That is what it is and that is exactly what you did not want to tell the people in the run‐up to the election. The people did not know that this is what you had planned to do to them. The price to Australia is the price of the numbers of people left unemployed and abandoned by you with these massive cuts. `Forget the unemployed. A big chunk of
unemployed is good for business. It keeps wages down and pressure on jobs. It is good for all sorts of things.' That is what you are planning to do by taking money out of the budget.

talk.start.para: —I am trying to think of a point of order, Mr Deputy President, to say how disgraceful those claims are. I ask Senator Crowley to withdraw those claims which are quite unfounded. They are not in the coalition's policy, they never have been and they never will be. We have brought down a budget which is caring, considering the circumstances we inherited from the Labor Party.
—There is no point of order.

—I am glad you rule that way. I knew you would, Mr Deputy President. What a disgraceful and pathetic attempt—to get on her feet now to face up to what her government has done. It has abandoned people and she is not here to answer those questions. She cannot even find the answers. She is not in here to tell us the answers.
—Oh, really? She is here.

—You might be a funny person, Senator Knowles, but you have no substance and nor have any of her answers to questions. You have a tory budget abandoning the young people, abandoning the old people and abandoning the unemployed.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I ask that you direct Senator Crowley to address her comments through you and not to direct them to Senator Newman.
—It would be good advice.

—It would be good advice. That just shows, Mr Deputy President, how desperate they are not to listen to what I have to say. I draw attention to the last thing. There is a lovely quote from Adele—
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Patterson, Sen Kay

talk.start.para:
—I rise today firstly to put on the public record that Senator Newman is here. Senator
Crowley said she had gone. That is appalling. Also, it is amazing that Senator Crowley would say that Senator Newman spoke mumbo jumbo. The answers that Senator Crowley gave when she was a minister were verbal fruit salad!

speech.para: I want to put paid to the untruths that are being bandied around, scaring older people about going into nursing homes. I find what Senator Neal said in the adjournment debate last night offensive and I find what Senator Crowley said today offensive. Let me put on the public record that the changes to nursing homes will, in fact, be along the lines of contributions that are made to hostels now, contributions which were brought in in 1988 by the then Labor government. The changes that we have brought in to nursing homes will not impact on full pensioners, who make up 65 per cent of residents of nursing homes.

For those opposite to stand there and say that people will pay $26,000 to go into a nursing homes is wrong, wrong, wrong, and they should know it is. Senator Crowley is just trying to scare older people. People going into nursing homes who can afford to make a contribution will do so on the same basis as people who go into hostels and can afford to make a contribution. For all full pensioners entering nursing homes this will continue to be the case. Entry fees will not be set by government. People entering a nursing home will negotiate an entry contribution with the provider. The government will ensure safeguards. Entry contributions will not be charged to full pensioners or existing residents. Anyone who has assets of less than $22,280 will not be charged an entry contribution. Entry contributions will not apply for short stays of up to six months, and that applies to many people who go into nursing homes. I can give you an example of my stepfather, who died in April. He was not in the nursing home six months, so he would not have been required to make an entry contribution.

The provider can only take out of that contribution $2,600 per annum over five years. The balance of that is then left to go back to the resident or back into their estate. So even to say that they are paying a $26,000
entry contribution is, in fact, a furphy. There will be no draw‐down for the first six months and the maximum that can be drawn down over five years is set at $13,000. This means that where the entry contribution is $20,000 or $50,000 the maximum draw‐down is $13,000.

How can you have sat over there for years and protected people who had huge incomes and not required them to pay an entry contribution to a nursing home? Millionaires were able to go into a nursing home and have no other additional cost other than the pension. That is what you did, and you let nursing homes degenerate. Professor Gregory said $300 million would be needed to bring nursing homes up to an acceptable level. That is what you let happen, while millionaires went into nursing homes paying no entry contribution. Now what you are saying is, `Don't let them pay. We can't let millionaires pay to go into nursing homes.' How ridiculous! All members of the industry have been saying there ought to be a contribution.

People who are on low incomes will be protected. If the Labor Party goes out telling older people that they have to pay $26,000, it will cause grief and distress amongst thousands of older people who should not be facing that grief and distress from being told fibs, lies and untruths by the Labor Party. I find it offensive, totally un‐Australian and appalling that they would do that to older Australians.

Let me just say how the contributions work, just to make it clear. The contributions will be based on a person's ability to pay. Let me say it again, just so the Labor Party can understand. It will be based on a person's ability to pay. It will not be that everyone pays $26,000. Pensioners will not be required to pay. People's assets will be assessed. Even now a lot of providers do not ask for an entry contribution, even though they are allowed to do it. A very small percentage of them—I think it is about six per cent—ask for the maximum contribution. It has worked well. There are checks and balances to ensure that people are not deprived. They make a contribution according to their ability to pay and it allows hostels to have capital upgrading.

break.para:
What has happened under Labor is that nursing homes have degenerated. In some nursing homes there are six people in a ward. That is antiquated and outdated and not the sort of aged care that we should be providing. Some nursing homes have four, five and six people in a ward, while people in other nursing homes are in a room with an ensuite. That is the sort of standard we are aiming for.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Neal, Sen Belinda

talk.start.para: —I took note of Senator Newman's earlier comment that this budget was a caring budget. All I can say in response is that, if this is a caring budget, she certainly knows how to kill with love. A few comments have been made by some people in the community who really do care—and they are not overwhelmingly supportive. I would like to read an extract of an article that appeared today relating to comments made by ACOSS. It states:

speech.para: Welfare groups yesterday accused the government of betraying unemployed youth and of unfairly hurting low income earners with spending cuts in the budget. The Australian Council of Social Service said that low income earners were the target of 30 per cent of the principal cuts. The ACOSS paper tallied cuts in labour market programs, social security, health and family services, Aboriginal affairs, education, and the justice system. It found that of the $11 billion in significant cuts over the next two years $3.4 billion would mainly hit low income earners

What did Mr Howard say in response to this? He dismissed the criticism, saying that he had `kept the core promises'. Obviously, there are a number of things that he does not consider to be core promises—and certainly Senator Newman does not either. She obviously thinks commitments to the elderly people and the less well‐off elderly people in our community are not core promises.

para.break: Let us look at what this budget has done to elderly people in the community. Look at the concessional pharmaceutical benefits. There have been cuts to those for pensioners and health card holders—an extra 50c each time. As we know, pensioners use a lot of prescriptions. They are probably the biggest users of prescriptions in the community. Is that 50c each pop, each prescription being compen sated for? No. It is being taken out of pensioners' pockets and they are not getting anything back.

speech.para: Where else have pensioners lost out? The Commonwealth dental scheme has been abolished—a scheme that was set up to deal with the waiting list of pensioners and health card holders. Before this scheme was introduced, the states had a scheme that had a 24-month waiting list. Do you know what that meant? It meant that pensioners who had problems with their teeth had those teeth extracted; there was no time to give them treatment. That is what we are going back to. Pensioners will have to either go in there and have quick treatment, a quick extraction, or, alternatively, pay for themselves. Has this loss to be suffered by elderly people been compensated for? No.

Let us look at HACC services. The minister, after a day, was able to work out what had happened to HACC services—or at least some part of it. She came in and told us that there would be more money in there. That is fabulous. But the only problem is that every individual will have to pay for those services. In the line items in the budget, it says `increase user charging in the home and community care program'. So what you are saying is that everyone who uses HACC services—the frail and the aged, the young and the disabled—will have to pay more in user charges. But that is not where the pain stops.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am being misrepresented by Senator Neal. Yesterday in question time I gave the lie to exactly what she is now claiming. I did not say that everybody would be required—and the government is not requiring everybody—to pay for HACC services.

interject.speaker: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —That is not a point of order. If you wish to claim that you have been misrepresented, you can do so at the end of the speech.

interject.para:
Senator Knowles interjecting
—

talk.start.para:
—Thank you! Unfortunately, that is not where the pain stops for the elderly; that is not where the broken promises
for the elderly stop in this budget. Nursing home entry fees! The more they squeal, the more you know it is true. You have introduced or allowed to be introduced nursing home entry fees. Yes, we do not know the exact amount of these fees because the minister will not tell us. None of the people in private industry know because the minister cannot tell them. But, on average, present entry fees for hostels are $26,000. So it is reasonable to assume that it will be much the same in relation to nursing homes. But, again, that is not the worst of it. The maximum they can charge you is $88,000. Minister, you may feel that it is caring to charge elderly people $88,000 to get into a nursing home—but, personally, I do not think it is.

speech.para: Where else have you broken your promises? You have also taken away the funds for the loans provision for capital works for nursing homes. The elderly do not need that assistance; we will take that money away and put it somewhere else. You are also having introduced nursing home fees of $34 a day for anyone who earns more than $1 over the pensioner free zone; they have to pay $34 a day or $12,000 a year.

That is not where the broken promises finish. The public health system upon which low income earners rely entirely—and in particular pensioners—has also been hit. Not only have you taken away $150 million a year in general purpose grants announced at the Premiers Conference, but you have also taken away in this budget—this `caring' budget—a further $230 million.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talker.name: Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

talk.start.para: —I notice that Senator Neal has repeated some of the claims that she made last night on the adjournment. I was hoping that I would have had the chance to answer some of those in question time today.
—You couldn't answer anything.

—I was not asked. Senator Neal has in fact repeated those inaccuracies again now. I want to deal with the facts as Senator Neal would have us believe
them. First of all, she went into some detail last night about the so-called savings in HACC. She has not had the decency to acknowledge that she was utterly wrong. That is why I mentioned today that there was a 6.7 per cent increase in HACC funding. Why doesn't she own up to that?

speech.para: Once again just now she has said something about loan moneys—remember the word you used, Senator Neal. She said that the provision for loan moneys for capital works in nursing homes has been abolished. First of all, they are not loans; they are grants. Secondly, they have not been abolished—get your facts right. However, Senator Neal, if you are really interested in this question they have been reduced in the budget papers because there is an expectation that a number of proprietors will prefer to take alternative forms of funding from the Commonwealth grants for which they currently have a commitment. It is up to the owners of the nursing homes as to whether they continue with the grants for which they have a contract or whether they move to another arrangement.

In addition, there was some talk about how much people are going to pay in by way of means testing. Perhaps Senator Neal has not worked out yet that there is going to be 25c in the dollar over the free area capped at a total of $60 a week—so much for your accuracies there! It is currently $26.05. These measures are tough, sure, but they are fair. I understand they have been looked at in every Labor budget so far but the previous government has not had the intestinal fortitude to do something about it, when we know that nursing homes have been so run down over the last few years.

As I said in question time, Professor Gregory has made recommendations about the amount of money that needs to go into upgrading the facilities at nursing homes. I am afraid that what we are getting from the opposition now is shouting, noise and misinformation. I notice that not only was there Senator Neal's speech last night but also Dr Carmen Lawrence has been putting out a mass of information that is supposedly fact but in fact is not true. It is misinformation—

talk.start.para: —Carmen Lawrence wouldn't do that, would she?

—`Women betrayed', she said. Who betrayed women but Carmen Lawrence anyway? There are so many things to answer. With the pharmaceuticals I promised that I would give you an additional answer and I ran out of time. You might be interested to know that the studies that the government has done show that, on average, pensioners are only getting 31 scripts a year. They get enough money under the new arrangements to cover them for 42 scripts, so they are covered, and if they run out of those then they end up on the free list. I think that you have not understood or you have deliberately misrepresented—I do not know which it is—the situation that people will find themselves in.

break.para: Once again, I point out that in this country we would not be in this position if your government had not left the books in such a mess and been so dishonest at the election about what situation they were in. It was very difficult for us to frame a budget that would be caring, compassionate and humane. I think that this government has done a fantastic job in maintaining those very important commitments to older people that I referred to in question time. It is no thanks to the former government that older people have been so protected.

The very fact that there has not been a cry from the nation, along the lines that Senator Neal and some of her colleagues have been making in this place, demonstrates how people recognise there was a need to take stiff measures for Australia to get its budget back in order again. The Labor Party does not like to hear that because it was responsible for the mess. But if Australia is going to get up off its knees again, we are trying to make sure that we do it as soon as possible and in the fairest way possible. Older Australians are not fools. They understand that we have to get it right for the sake of their children and their grandchildren. If there is any fault in this budget at all, we know where the guilty party is.

speech.speaker: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

talk.start.para:
—Senator Newman has made three
statements that I want to comment on: firstly, she said that the budget is caring in the circumstances and, secondly, she said that the measures are tough. I ask: which is it; is it caring or is it tough? Thirdly, she referred to the books being in a mess as she did earlier in this place in regard to so-called housewives. I know that Senator Newman has a very busy portfolio but I am sure she would be aware that over 100 economists signed a letter to the Treasurer, Peter Costello, pointing out that the kinds of measures you have now taken in this budget would be inappropriate for the overall state of the health of the economy.

speech.para: As we all know, economists do not usually agree, but over 100 economists did sign that letter about two months ago. I note that the government did not take any notice of it. It is distinctly untrue to say that the economy is in a mess, because we know that people do not believe this to be the case. There is a stable situation in this country. The kinds of measures that you have taken in cutting back—overwhelmingly in community services—are simply going to destabilise the economy, increase unemployment and have adverse effects on so many Australians.

I believe that I have the answer, if I can be so presumptuous as to suggest it, as to why there is such confusion here in this place on what the government has done in relation to the measures we have been discussing this afternoon. The answer lies here in your statement entitled More Choice for Women. You did table a statement—I am sure that is welcome in many quarters—but you did not maintain a 12-year precedent of presenting a women's budget statement that would have detailed to a considerable extent the measures of this budget and how they would impact on women and families.

I do not know whether you tried to develop a women's budget impact statement. It has become a tradition in Australia that has been admired internationally, that has been praised in the United Nations and that has been advocated by the Commonwealth Secretariat for all Commonwealth countries. Yet, on the first opportunity that you had as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of
Women, you abandoned this process of adopting a women's budget impact statement.

I know, having been where you now sit, that it is not always easy to win in cabinet and I sympathise with you in that regard. But I do say to you that I challenge the government to rethink its position. It is a very serious matter that there is now no document anywhere among the budget papers that actually demonstrates to us what the impact of your various budget measures is on 54 per cent of the population.

It is not too late to actually go back to your department about this. I know that the Office of the Status of Women has been subject to dramatic funding cuts. It is not too late to go back to the Office of the Status of Women and the various government departments that are responsible for many of the measures in this budget and ask them to do that analysis and then come back to this place and table a proper assessment of the impact of this budget on women. I would challenge the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to allow this to happen.

While the document More Choice for Women contains measures that will be welcome in some sectors of the community it is not comprehensive. For example, there is no mention of women with disabilities. There is no mention of indigenous women or migrant women. There is no mention of the fact that you are introducing the user‐pays principle in the area of family court counselling, as in many other areas. There will also be increases in user pays in other areas.

speech.speaker: Knowles, Sen Susan

talk.start.para: —I relish the opportunity of responding to some of the things that have been said today by both Senator Crowley and Senator Neal. For Senator Neal to come in here and start lecturing the government on what it has and has not done is akin to being slapped around the face with a wet lettuce leaf soaked in hot baby oil, I have to say. Apart from that, it shows the hypocrisy of what is really going on here. The fact of the matter is that the Labor Party's own secretary said:

speech.para: We could not run on policies because they the voters thought we were liars on policy.

That is what we are getting here again today. The fact of the matter is that you did nothing about fairness and equity. You left 600,000 children in families where neither parent had an income. You created the highest level of unemployment this country has ever seen. You created the highest levels of unemployment among women. You have the audacity to come in here today and talk about fairness. There were none of these measures in your policies for 13 years. What we have with this policy in this document in this budget is some fairness and equity being brought back in. Let me quote one of your colleagues, former Senator Richardson who said in today's
Bulletin
:

One idea I had which had no chance of ever being accepted by my caucus or cabinet colleagues was to charge an increased Medicare levy for high‐income earners who refused to take out private insurance. I was never comfortable with the thought of wealthy people elbowing battlers out of queues in public hospitals. "A crisis in public hospitals would occur within 10 years" was what they used to say three years ago. With public hospitals now unable to provide beds for emergency cases and some people dying because of it, with casualty and emergency wards overflowing and rejecting in some cases as many as 70% of those who come seeking assistance, with bed numbers being cut across the country, there is just a suggestion that the crisis might be looming a little earlier.

Everyone has to lose some battles but I wish I had won this one. Now the Liberal Party is putting forward the same idea. Even the thought that the Liberals are prepared to make the rich pay more when the Labor Party would not is enough to scare the hell out of me.

There can be no doubt about where the great majority will stand on this. The vast numbers of Australians earning less than $50,000 a year will reckon that those earning more and able to afford more ought to be paying more. They will be even more convinced of the worth of this proposal if the Coalition adopts the rest of my proposal as well.

That is a quote from one of your colleagues and a former Minister for Health. He sought to do what we have actually done. He sought to make the people at the bottom end of the scale, the low and middle income earners, more comfortable and able to gain greater access to health services. You should be ashamed that you did not do what we had the courage to implement in this budget. To suggest otherwise is simply to do what the
ALP secretary said you failed to do leading up to the last election. The reason people did not vote for you is that they believed that you were liars on policy.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time allowed for taking note of answers has expired.

speech.speaker: Campbell, Sen Ian

talker.name: Senator CAMPBELL
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

talk.start.para: —by leave—During question time Senator Faulkner made an accusation whilst making a point of order that I approached the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, and called him a wimp. At the outset, I refute that. I did not do that. I am quite happy to share with all honourable senators what I said to Senator Hill.

speech.para: I approached Senator Hill at the time Senator Kernot sought leave to table a document relating to the budget. What was clear to me from Senator Hill's body language was that he had not been extended the normal courtesy, which has been extended on virtually all occasions during the years I have been in this place, which is to ensure that when you seek leave to table a document you inform all senators, particularly the party whips and party leaders who are on duty, independent senators and others what it is that is to be tabled. That is a courtesy that is on almost all occasions extended to senators before leave is sought.

I went to Senator Hill and said, `Has Senator Kernot extended that courtesy to us? If she has not, that should be made quite clear to all senators during question time and while we are on broadcast.' There is one significant difference between how we on this side approach our leader to ask questions and discuss matters and how those on the other side do it.

talk.start.para: —Is this to do with your being misrepresented?
—It is, indeed, Senator Evans, and I will get to the point. When I seek to speak to Senator Hill, my leader, I approach—

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 190 it is very clear that no argument is allowed. I would contend that the senator is now straying into argument rather than explaining how he was misrepresented.
—I think he was straying into debate, but I was prepared to hear where it was leading.

—I will conclude very rapidly, Mr Deputy President, and I thank you for your tolerance. The debate was about an accusation made by the Leader of the Opposition that I approached my leader and called him something which, clearly, I did not. I am sure that Senator Faulkner knew that I did not say that and he deliberately misled the Senate.

speech.para: I make the point that, when I go to speak to my leader, I walk up to him and talk to him. Senator Faulkner has to speak to Senator Robert Ray between 50 and 60 times a day and has worn a path in the carpet. Next week I am going to go to Tandy Electronics and buy him an intercom system so that he can be personally connected to Senator Robert Ray.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The point I make is that that was very definitely debate.
—It certainly was, but I think Senator Campbell has concluded.
—I have, Mr Deputy President. I thank senators for their tolerance.

interject.speaker: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Order! The President has received a letter from Senator Carr proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

interject.para: The Government's betrayal of Australians who are reliant upon higher and other education training programs.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places
—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times for each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —This proposition goes to the question of this government's integrity when it comes to the issues of higher education and other educational programs. As I understand the talk around this town, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, explained to a number of people before the budget was brought down that, after the budget was brought down, she would be the most unpopular minister for education in the Commonwealth's history. I think that is one promise she has kept. There have been very few others that she has kept.

speech.para: What we see in these budget papers is an attempt to disguise and deceive, just like the election strategy of the Liberal Party from its very commencement. You promise anything, you say anything and you do anything you think is necessary to get you a few votes and then in practice you do very little of what you promised and what you committed to. We have seen again and again this strategy being followed. These budget papers follow that practice by suggesting that there are increases in education expenditure when, in fact, the opposite is the case.

Minister, as I gave your papers a bit more careful reading rather than just the superficial reading your press relations people would encourage us to do, I found that, over the next four years, the total cuts to budget programs administered by your department will amount to something in the order of $5.8 billion.
