That is $5.8 billion worth of cuts being administered by this minister in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. That would have to be one of the greatest levels of cuts that any Commonwealth minister responsible for
this department has had to endure in the history of this Commonwealth. Yet another great achievement!

The question is: is this just a case of the minister's incompetence or is it a case of the ERC imposing on her decisions that no other minister would accept and, therefore, is it just a failure to administer her department and to defend her constituency the way she ought to as the minister responsible for such an important area of government activity?

We looked at the detail very clearly. We were promised by this government before the election that it would maintain existing programs in the schools area. If I recall the promise made by Senator Hill in February this year, he said, `We will at least maintain Commonwealth specific purpose payments to schools in line with the forward estimates recurrent, capital and targeted equity programs.' When you look at the budget papers that clearly has not occurred.

When you look at the other higher education areas, the promise was simple: `We will maintain the level of funding for operating grants to universities and there will be no cuts in university places.' According to the
Sydney Morning Herald
, `Iron‐clad commitments have been given that the overall funding for universities would be maintained.' So it goes on.

The same pattern is emerging out of every area of activity undertaken by this department. As I read it, it is a very simple proposition. With Austudy the lies and deceit continue. For instance, the statement issued by this government says that the coalition government is firmly committed to maintain the level of benefits to eligible families which Austudy provides. You would think that that means that it wants to spend money on Austudy and maintain the level of benefits. Nothing could be further from the truth because, when you read the budget papers carefully, you find cuts in excess of $514 million being made to Austudy. So, with such things like case management of homeless students, you see that quite significant cuts have been undertaken—quite contrary to the commitments given before the election.

break.para: We see in the case of Abstudy and Austudy that the age of independence has been raised to 25 years. We see that the tightening of the various eligibility tests will produce substantial savings from the government's point of view. We see breaches being made in English as a second language and in TAFE programs. We see cuts to operating grants, to growth funding, to the states, to TAFE colleges and to the VET sector generally.

Of course, in higher eduction the case is abundantly clear. In relation to HECS funding, in total some $2.4 billion overall has been taken away from Australians and taken out of the higher education sector as a result of this government's programs—$2.4 billion! Nothing could be clearer: in terms of discretionary funds $214 million has been taken out; in terms of raising the independent allowance for students receiving Austudy payments, some $241 million; in terms of tightening the means test, $817 million; and in terms of lowering the threshold, $312 million. We see similar sorts of figures in terms of differential HECS. Some $623 million in operating grants will also be taken away from this sector.

So what we see is a government that has quite clearly been caught out, a government that cannot keep its word. In a whole range of areas—in the operation of universities, support to students and equity programs—quite clearly this government has not maintained its commitments and has quite clearly breached them. We see that not one extra dollar has been put into equity programs—not one extra dollar! What this government is seeking to do is repackage Labor programs, re‐announce them, reclaim them as its own and say, `Oh, yes. We're keeping our commitments.' That is not what it said before the election. In terms of up-front fees, quite a significant impact will be had upon the disincentive rates—that is, people being forced out of universities—as a result of the actions being taken by this government.

Aboriginal education is one of the clearest areas I can point to where fundamental breaches have occurred. These are not big sums of money at all but, in terms of the principles at stake here, in terms of the equity
arrangements entered into by this government and in terms of the importance of education in trying to provide a better, fairer and more productive society, this government has failed dismally. Quite clearly, it does not understand the value of higher education and it does not understand the importance of making sure all Australians do participate within it.

We were told that Aboriginal education would be exempt from the moves on ATSIC, that that program would be left apart from any changes. But what do we find today? We find—although we do not see this too clearly in any of the budget papers; that is part of the game, isn't it, making sure that as little information as possible explaining what is happening in the forward estimates is available—on page 8 of the budget statements, which deals with direct assistance in Aboriginal education, that there have been quite specific cuts to programs in the coming year. Of course, over the next four years these cuts will become even more pronounced. I notice there has also been a significant cut in tuition assistance. The vocational guidance program has been cut. The Aboriginal parents program has been cut. In terms of the Aboriginal education strategic initiative program, $1.5 million will be taken out next year, and this cut will grow to $31 million by the turn of the century.

What we are seeing will have quite detrimental effects on Aboriginal tertiary education assistance. This is quite contrary to the claims made that education would be exempt from cuts relating to ATSIC. This is another set of lies, more deceit, more deception. We all understand what that means in terms of equity, because we understand that education provides a vehicle for many people to change their life circumstances.

Of course, this is yet one more opportunity for the rich and powerful to maintain their influence in this society. The minister goes on and on about how hard life was under Labor, but her complaint was that we spent too much, that Labor did too much. She said the way to fix that up is to make the poor pay more. She has offered a few scholarships—a miserable 1,000 scholarships, I think. There
are 650,000 students in this country at the moment. What a miserable effort!

I have here a couple of letters I have received from some people who will suffer as a result of these cuts to programs. I will refer to them on another day.
(Time expired)

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr, with the greatest of respect, you did yourself no service whatsoever in that presentation. You displayed either a capacity to be deceptive with the truth or an incapacity to understand it—one or the other. I do not come to either conclusion, but I just invite you to check your facts next time you come in here to engage in a bit of blunder and bluster to clear your lungs of whatever hot air is there.

speech.para: You raised the point, Senator Carr, that you think it is all a pack of lies—the usual claim from the Labor Party. I just invite you to consider what your own national secretary said contributed to your losing the last election. In the cold light of day, after Gary Gray had had plenty of time to consider it, he said:
We could not run on policies because they—
that is, the voters—
thought we were liars on policy. We could not run on our record because they thought our record stunk.

So it is abundantly clear that the national secretary of the Labor Party understands that the people now in opposition are the people who are there in part—not solely but in part—because the community no longer believed them.

We in this chamber have some differences of opinion as to what way we should take higher education in the future, and I want to concentrate on that aspect in particular. Senator Carr mentions $2.4 billion and happily says to voters who may be listening to the broadcast or who might read his contribution in
Hansard
that $2.4 billion has been taken out. That is either a misunderstanding or a deception because it is simply not the case. When you put together a savings package—he may not know this but other members here would—part of that savings package comes from bringing revenue ahead and some of it
comes from, yes, making cuts—cuts against forward estimates; that is, what people were planning on spending in the future.

It is important people realise that the higher education sector, through operating grants and research, will actually get more next year than it got this year. In future years it will end up with less than it was expecting to get, yes. There are reductions. I make no bones about that. They are very small, though—one per cent next year against a forward growth estimate, three per cent the year after, one the year after that and one the year after that.

These are not significant savings to ask from a sector which cannot be immune from the savings task. People in higher education, whether they are going through it or teaching in it, are amongst some of the luckiest people in Australia. To ask a contribution of 1‐3‐1‐1 against their operating grant plans for the future is not a lot to ask.

The bulk of the savings in the higher education sector comes from two things. Firstly, graduates are asked to pay back more quickly than they otherwise would have—that is, to reduce the point at which they start to pay back their HECS contribution. Isn't this a lucky country, Mr Deputy President, where anyone can access higher education, as they ought to be able to, on their merit. They are asked to make a contribution and they do not have to pay that contribution until they start earning.

We support that system: a system introduced by the Labor Party; a system that acknowledges that, yes, there is a very public benefit in higher education, but also a private benefit; and a system that says to graduates who benefit from that, `You're going to have to pay something back. You're going to have to make a contribution.' We support that system.

We have had this enormous savings task to fill the Beazley bankcard. We have kept the promise to keep charges to existing students the same; their charges and their debt levels do not go up. I freely admit that we say to them, `I'm sorry; you're going to have to start paying back a bit earlier—when you're earning $20,700.' I hear people saying,
`That's too low an amount. Students couldn't possibly make a contribution then.'

People need to understand that people who get the benefit of higher education—as Neville Wran understood when he did the Wran report—are the luckiest people in Australia. They have an unemployment rate of 3.9 per cent; it is less than half the unemployment rate endured by other Australians who have not had that opportunity of higher education. Their starting salaries are higher than average salaries and their periods of unemployment are far less. We do not think it is unreasonable to ask for a contribution back and to ask now for a higher contribution back; other people may disagree.

But we need to understand who pays for higher education. There is no such thing as free higher education; there never was. We need to understand who is paying for it. In other words: when you put a contribution in through HECS, to whom are you giving it back? You are giving it back to low and middle income earners who by and large are paying for the privilege of higher education for people who still come from higher income levels.

It is important to understand that the households with the top 20 per cent of incomes enjoy 38 per cent of the benefits of higher education. The bottom 20 per cent of households enjoy only seven per cent of the benefits of higher education. So it is pretty clear who is getting the benefit. It is not unreasonable to say to graduates, `You're the ones who are getting a very substantial benefit out of this and we are going to ask you to make a bigger contribution.'

It is equally very fair to put some more equity into the HECS system. I accept it puts equity there for starters: everyone can get in on merit; no-one has to pay back until they have started earning an income. But they all pay the same. Teachers who have a low course cost and a lower income in later life than doctors who have a high course cost and a higher income are asked to make the same contribution as doctors. Members opposite might think that is fair; we do not think it is fair. We think a differentiated HECS contribution that acknowledges the benefits you are
going to get out of it and which has some interplay between the cost of your course and your expected later income is fair.

Of course, that is what Neville Wran thought when he did the report of the Committee on Higher Education Funding. He actually recommended to the previous government that they shift to a differentiated HECS; that they acknowledge that some people for the rest of their lives get more out of higher education than others. He, just like us, did not put forward a differentiated HECS solely on the cost of the course. That would have ignored the fact that nursing and science are expensive courses to run but that those people in those courses do not end up with the same private benefit, they do not end up with the high incomes that doctors and lawyers do. For that reason, we have put nursing on the lowest level that Mr Wran recommended and science in the middle. We think that is a very reasonable thing to do.

I do not think for one minute that we have let down the higher education sector. In addition to restoring equity to the HECS system in that sense, we have also allowed universities much more flexibility. We will allow Australian students to buy a place, just like an international student can. The students who do that will be made up of a number of people.

talk.start.para: —The rich ones.

—There will be people who, in years to come when they have planned ahead, will save to give themselves that opportunity. And, yes, there will be people who come from wealthier families who are prepared to buy a full cost place. People opposite that I used to hear chanting, `Make the rich pay,' will now not let them.

speech.para:
Do you realise that if universities take one per cent of their students from full fee paying students they will get an extra $17 million. As they take up two per cent and three per cent of full fee paying students in addition to their government funded load, with penalties if they try to sell places without filling their government load, every per cent they go up will pour more and more millions of dollars not into general revenue but straight into universities. So people opposite who want to
put a block on that are putting a block on putting more money into higher education.

There are people out there who are prepared to pay. If you do not want to let them pay, if you do not want that money to go to universities, then you argue that case publicly. I am happy to argue the case that if there are people out there prepared to pay, and if we let overseas students pay, why won't we let Australian students pay and why won't we let Australian universities have that extra income and put that income towards improving universities. You run your argument if you want and you ask yourselves whether you think it will be successful.

In addition, there are more flexibilities provided to Australian universities. Under the previous government, if universities made the mistake of over‐enrolling—which they often did, because you penalised them when they under‐enrolled—you would not give them the HECS contribution that you had taken from those students. You just took that HECS contribution and you put it straight into general revenue.

We want to change that. We want to say to universities, `If you over‐enrol, and we take a HECS contribution from those students, we'll give it back to you.' So the universities are going to be in a much better position if we can get this package passed. We have not let them down; we have given them the greatest opportunity they have ever seen.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para: —I rise today on behalf of the Australian Democrats to support this matter of public importance. In fact, yesterday I rose on a similar matter to point out the litany of broken promises by the coalition government in the area of higher education, some of which Senator Carr has already outlined.

speech.para:
What makes it even more offensive that this government has betrayed every promise that it made to the higher education tertiary sector is when we consider the remarks of the former higher education spokesperson for the coalition, Senator Hill. I would like to quote his comments from 27 November last year when he denounced the former Labor
government's poor record on higher education funding. He said:

Students are concerned because of the government's poor record in this regard. The government makes promises one day and breaks them the next. Students are as disillusioned as the rest of the Australian community in relation to this government's performance. Of course, there is another option—that they support us and we get elected; we will keep our promises and they will be better off.

As of Tuesday night's budget, Australian students and aspiring students—because let us remember that, even though this MPI refers only to Australians who are reliant upon higher education and other education programs, it should include those Australians who are aspiring to undertake higher education—are the very people who will be hit hardest by these measures.

Senator Vanstone has said today in the chamber that students in higher education are among the luckiest people in our community. Yes, especially the ones on Austudy! Wow, that is 68 per cent of the poverty line, on average: that is lucky! She has said that academics and general staff are `in clover', `in ivory towers'—all these expressions she has used. She has said that universities should not be for the `cream' of our society, that we should have open and accessible institutions—

talk.start.para: —Just buy your way in.
—It will be the cream, Senator Carr: the rich and thick are exactly who will be able to get into our higher education institutions, if these promises are blatantly breached, as they have been.

speech.para: The government promised to maintain Austudy at real levels; and what have we got? An independent rate age that has increased to 25. We have seen the introduction of stricter eligibility criteria and the removal of benefits for certain students, including homeless students. The government promised to maintain operating grants; and what have they done? Over the next four years over $623 million will be taken out of operating grants.

They promised to give the NTEU wage claim top priority; it would be addressed when they got into government. And what have they done? They have not put it on the bottom of the agenda; they are completely
ignoring it. And yes, they cleverly promised not to change the arrangements for HECS for existing students. I would like the minister to answer at some point the question of whether that includes moving the goalposts on the threshold. That was another promise: the coalition stated clearly that they would not lower the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their debts. And what have they done? It has been reduced from $28,000 per annum to $20,800. That means families on 88 per cent of the poverty line will be repaying the HECS debts. One‐income two‐parent families with a HECS debt will be paying it even if they have not reached poverty line levels. It is an outrage. There is a raft of promises that this government have blatantly breached in relation to higher education.

The government promised also that they would not allow a university system that was based on elitism or the ability to pay. Senator Vanstone has outlined her vision for higher education in this chamber today: you can purchase a place, buy a place. Look at the language we are using in this debate. We now treat students as consumers; we treat them as clients. What has happened to this parliament's, this government's or this nation's vision of education and training for not only young Australians but all Australians?

Senator Vanstone referred to the luckiest people, the people included in the Wran committee report. I wish the minister were here to correct me if I am wrong, but I understand the Wran report came down in around 1986‐87. It resulted in the introduction of the up‐front fee, the higher education administration charge—I know because I paid it; I wonder if the minister did—and then resulted in the higher education contribution scheme.

Wran was right: it was an elitist system in the sense that people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds could not access higher education or did not have the same access. Do you know what? In the last decade, what is the one target equity group whose participation has not increased in higher education? It is people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds.

So what is the answer to that? It is not increased fees and charges and financial and
psychological disincentives and barriers to enter education.

talk.start.para: —How about some free scholarships? How many did Labor give?

—Free scholarships? In fact, the terminology is wrong. They are not scholarships; they are exemptions, as I have been informed. And 1,000 per year for four years? Wow, whoopee‐do: 0.66 per cent of places will be available in scholarships.

speech.para: Yesterday I spoke to some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander representatives who explained that the chance of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person getting a scholarship at Sydney University would be one in 4,000. My goodness, what a generous offer those exemption scholarships are to young Australians?

Whatever people on the other side of this chamber may say, when it comes to lower socioeconomic groups, there is one fact that remains: the one target equity group whose participation has not increased in higher education this decade is people from lower socioeconomic groups. And what is this government doing? It is not only leaving them out to dry; it is increasing the barriers to entry and pursuance of higher education for those groups. It does not matter what you on the other side of the chamber say about scholarships; you cannot get away from it.

I also recognise that it is a sad day to see the hypocrisy that we deal with from both sides of the chamber because both sides voted for HECS, both have supported all above‐CPI increases to HECS and both introduced the loans scheme. It is not only this government that has to bear the responsibility for the entrenchment of user pays higher education in this country; it is also the former government, because it also lied to students. It saddens me today to see a degree of breathtaking hypocrisy, but I am glad now that at least the opposition have indicated their staunch, I hope, opposition to some of the regressive proposals that we see in the higher education part of this budget. I look forward to seeing the ALP opposition join with the Democrats to stop the more regressive measures so that at least we can go some way to providing a higher
education system accessible to all and publicly funded.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —I think the most important message that I can give in relation to both employment and education and training is that there are choices. What we have been presented with suggests that there are no choices. Higher education was presented as a scenario you choose. It is presented as a case of the arm or the leg: which is going to be cut off—as if there were no choices.

speech.para: If, in fact, a deficit is the most important thing that a budget should deal with—and I do not agree with that—why do you only choose to cut? If tax give‐backs are a large portion of the reason we have got into a budget deficit, why do you only choose to focus your efforts on cuts?

Working Nation was already slashed by $1 billion by the Labor government. It now faces massive cuts, starting with $400 million next year by the coalition. What is the important point here? It never was a new, big spending initiative. In 1993 on budget night, the Greens (WA) said, `There's something wrong with this budget. It's missing at least $5 billion. There's no funded labour program. It was left out of the budget.' Of course, it came up as Working Nation. That makes it easier to pretend that you are cutting from a program which was a big, new spending initiative. It never was and it has already been pared back to what it was before 1993. Now it will not be pared back from a big, new spending initiative; it will be pared back to the pre‐Whitlam era. Basically, this is the gift to young people in Australia.

What did the coalition promise youth before the election? Jobs! But what are they delivering? Harassment and blame! One way to do that is to tighten the criteria, increase the difficulties of living within one's means when one does not have a job and then blame the person. And you can call them a cheat, too, because you make the rules tighter.

talk.start.para: —Bludgers.

—Call them a cheat. Call them a bludger, as Senator Stott Despoja has called them, and then chuck them off the
system and say, `These people are acting illegally.' What a dreadful system: `Let's blame the victims and pretend we are being fair.'

speech.para:
There are choices. The choices in higher education have been forgone. We are once again returning higher education to its pre‐Whitlam days in which the rich retain their privilege in higher education and subsequent employment. Operating grants will be slashed. HECS will be doubled or tripled under the new tiers of differential HECS. Austudy will be means tested and tightened and the age of independence will be raised, saving—
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

talk.start.para: —I rise to contribute to this matter of public importance: the government's betrayal of Australians who are reliant upon higher and other education training programs. Interestingly, we could easily be debating today this government's betrayal of Australians. It is a betrayal because, as others have spelt out, particularly Senator Carr and Senator Stott Despoja, every promise in this area has been broken, with more abandon than any other of the broken promises, by this Howard coalition government introducing a classic Thatcher Tory budget. The budget will have a very dramatic impact on not only Australians but also Australian families and Australian society.

speech.para: It took an immense commitment by the previous Labor government to get the investment into education, higher education, training and skills programs up to the level it was. When we came into office, 37 per cent of children finished year 12; when we left, it was over 80 per cent. Some figures would put it in the high 70s, others into the 80s, depending on where you were in Australia: a massive turnaround. And there were 650,000 places in the tertiary sector when we left office.

Australians had begun to realise the importance of training, education and skills to the benefit of this society. You cannot talk about recovery of small businesses if people are not able to understand how to run a small business and if they are not skilled and trained to do it. You cannot talk about people taking
jobs in high technology if they do not have the training, skills and understanding to do it.

The dramatic cuts and the broken promises of Austudy and HECS have been spelt out very well indeed. But I am particularly interested to draw the Senate's attention to two documents that came down on the night of the budget: More Choice for Women and Strengthening Families. Interestingly, both these documents are absolutely silent on education, as though strengthening families does not need to address the question of education.

Yet sometimes the opposition wants to talk about the strain on families through the pressures to work and so on. One of the most important reasons families have a second income, as many thousands of women will tell you, is, `I've gone back to work particularly to ensure adequate education assistance for my children.' That is what they want. What has the coalition done? It has dramatically increased the costs of education on families and individuals. You have actually gone to the core of what families are on about in their investments in their own children's future and that of this country.

These broken promises in education not only cut the education sector and the fabric of our society but they cut what families are on about—families who are committed to improving the opportunities for their children. That has now been knocked for six by these vicious increased costs and charges on students and tertiary institutions.

In the other document that I cited, More Choice for Women, again there is no mention of education. Although Senator Stott Despoja pointed out there may have been evidence of no change in the population of university students, she did not highlight the evidence that one of the great dramatic changes in tertiary sector education is the presence of women. After at least a century of being denied access, forbidden and prevented from getting into secondary education let alone tertiary education, we created opportunities for women which they took up in droves. Even the figures earlier this year showed girls achieving extraordinarily well, achieving higher prizes and results than boys in our
schools to the point where people are now wondering about boys' education. Girls and women in tertiary sector employment are also achieving splendidly.

What has happened? Having just got in they are now going to find that the costs and the charges to maintain their presence are going to dramatically increase. So many of those women entered tertiary education because of our commitment to righting the injustice of the costs and the difficulties for women coming from inadequate training through secondary school. We set up those specific programs directed to equity and justice to assist people with disadvantages, Aboriginal people and, in particular, women. They embraced those opportunities with open arms.

It is no wonder you do not say anything about education in your More Choice for Women document. There is very little choice for women with these increased charges and the prospect of increased debts. That is what you are giving to women. Many women who are still advancing into tertiary education with some trepidation have to ask themselves, `Gosh, do I anticipate that I can cope with the sort of debt that I will have when I leave the tertiary sector?' No longer do they have to be able to earn $28,000 before they pay it back; it is now $20,000. These are people who are very well below average weekly earnings. They are struggling with all the other commitments that come with an income of $20,000. Yet they are now going to have to pay back their tertiary education charges.

These changes were guaranteed not to happen. There were to be no changes to HECS, no increase in costs, no cutback in services, no restrictions on places and no cuts to operational grants to universities. We have seen absolutely all those promises broken. The damage is already evidenced by the anger portrayed by vice‐chancellors, university staff and students.

Senator Carr said before that the only promise Senator Vanstone has kept is to become the most hated or disliked woman on the government front bench, if not in this country. She has also managed in the space of five short months to completely politicise the tertiary sector. Students who had grown
up knowing only a Labor government and wanting or being inclined to sheet responsibility home to a Labor government now know what the facts of a tory government are. It is so much worse. Given the opportunity again, 52 per cent—according to today's
Bulletin
—say that if they had known in March what they know now about Mr Howard's lies, his deception and his broken promises, they certainly would not have voted the way they did then.

That is what you have done in the tertiary sector. It is the government's betrayal of Australians—individuals, families and society. There are skillshare cutbacks and training cutbacks. A conservative mayor in the southern region of Adelaide said to me just the other day, `We would never have voted for this lot if we had known they would come into office and tear apart the fabric of the community.' That is what this debate is about.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Patterson, Sen Kay

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the matter of public importance concerning education. It is some time since I have spoken on this area and I am delighted to have the opportunity to highlight the misinformation that the opposition is peddling. It is peddling misinformation about nursing homes and education. The shadow minister for education and youth affairs, Mr Baldwin, released a press release on, I think, 21 August, headed `Government misleads on vocational education'. Let me just say that in that press release what the shadow minister did was mislead the public. The claims made by the shadow minister, Peter Baldwin, were scandalous but they are understandable, I suppose, given the figures you can expect from a graduate of Labor's magic pudding school of budget planning. The first claim Mr Baldwin made is as follows:

speech.para: On the face of it, the Budget contained an increase for non‐government schools of around $210 million over four years, while government schools faced a net cut of around $70 million over the same period.

Wrong. The budget papers reveal that for 1995‐96 Commonwealth spending on government schools was $1,124 million. In 1996‐97 that spending will be $1,167 million, an increase of $43 million or 3.8 per cent. Over
the next four years, spending will have increased by more than $240 million on government schools. There is no evidence that the states' contribution to filling Beazley's magic pudding fiasco will reduce funding to schools. It is for the states to decide how they make that contribution. In addition to the $305 million of extra funds for literacy, school to work, languages and civics, two‐thirds will go to government schools. On that claim he was wrong. He also claimed in the press release:
Federal expenditure on literacy—the need for which Dr Kemp has dishonestly sought to exploit as his own discovery—is $6 million less than Labor's commitment.

Wrong. The federal coalition focused on literacy because the previous Labor government had done nothing about it. We have not had a survey of literacy in Australia for the past 16 years but evidence gathered from some of the research that has been done is that literacy in this country has declined. Labor's commitment to literacy was to cut the funding for the early literacy program. When the minister asked the department, `What is going on about the literacy program,' the answer from the department was, `Minister, it was a program for which there was no money in the forward estimates.' What the government is doing is putting in $45 million of extra money.

Let me remind those on the other side that illiteracy is really one of the worst forms of poverty. Literacy opens the door to opportunity and achievement. What Labor was going to do by not having that spending or that funding in the forward estimates was take away from our children the key to opportunity that literacy gives. Literacy opens the door to the whole world. What the previous Labor government did by taking it out of forward estimates was take away that key, in particular from low income families with children, and adults who had difficulty reading. Another claim the shadow minister made was as follows:

The New Schools Policy, under which the Federal Government funds non‐government schools, will be abolished at a cost of $150 million over four years. This will be done in the name of choice and savings to the public purse, even though it could
well reduce choice and will be largely funded by a $128 million cut to government school funding.

Wrong; wrong again. Claims of changes to non‐government schools policy are not true. We have always maintained that we will fund school students regardless of whether they are in government or non‐government schools.

The new schools policy was a travesty. It has been eliminated because it took away and restricted parent choice. It failed damnably. Under the new schools policy the percentage of students in non‐government schools kept increasing. The policy discriminated against parents whose children were in low cost non‐government schools that were established in the early 1990s. The policy was abolished in the name of choice but, if parents do not exercise the choice to send their children to non‐government schools, there will be no change in funding for government schools. So the shadow minister was absolutely wrong.

Another claim that the shadow minister made was that, on the face of it, the budget contained an increase for non‐government schools of around $210 million over four years, while government schools faced a net cut of around $70 million over the same period. Again, that is wrong. The budget papers reveal that in 1995‐96 Commonwealth spending was $1,124 million, and in 1996‐97 there will be an increase of $43 million.

para.break: One of the other issues that have been neglected by the previous government is in regard to young people who are leaving school who do not go on to university, young people who fall between the stools. The minister has indicated there will be a $187 million school to work package, a package which supports and assists young people who are going into the work force from school. The program will involve $80 million to expand vocational education and training in secondary schools; $40 million for workplace training opportunities for students; $38 million for up to 200 work placement coordinators to facilitate structured workplace learning opportunities for students; $23 million for implementing vocational education in schools, including employing extra teachers and professional development for teachers to ensure they have up‐to‐date industry experi ence; school based paid apprenticeships and traineeships, and $6 million in the next two years for a jobs pathway guarantee program to support the transition from school to work.

speech.para: The program is part of the federal government's new modern Australian apprenticeship and traineeship system, continuing the reform and streamlining of Australia's trainee system. It will allow students to combine their secondary school certificate with practical work skills and qualifications recognised and valued by a broad range of businesses. That is what employers are asking for. They are asking for young people who come out with literacy skills, who come out with a good basic education, and also come out with an understanding of work and training and skills that will fit them for the workplace. That is what we are doing; not creating mickey mouse jobs but training young people, giving them the sorts of skills that will make them work ready.

Another area involving training is the professional development of teachers, an area that has been neglected. Teachers are a group of people who have in their hands an enormous responsibility. When I was teaching I saw it as a great privilege to be able to teach young people. These teachers require a continual upgrading of their professional training and experience. The features—
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Forshaw, Sen Michael

talk.start.para: —Unfortunately, my allotted time has been cut, but I have to say it is a small price to pay when we consider the massive cuts that this government has implemented in the area of education, and particularly higher education. This is a government that really does not understand the importance of higher education to Australians and to Australia.

speech.para:
This is a government that has a minister in charge of the higher education portfolio who believes she can determine higher education policy and higher education funding by having a fireside chat. This is a minister whose approach to this most important of portfolios is to sit down, invite the vice‐chancellors of the universities in and then proceed to try to have an auction sale by saying to them, `Look, we have to have some
cuts; what would you want—five per cent, 10 per cent or 15 per cent?'

There has been a total abrogation of responsibility by Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, from virtually the first day she took over the portfolio when she tried to transfer the decision making processes from herself and from her own department on to those persons charged with the running of universities. Of course, they did not buy that because they knew what was going to come; they were not going to sign their own suicide note.

Since then we have seen this minister implement one of the most disastrous education policies that one could ever witness. I say to all those government members and senators in this parliament, who in many cases have been the beneficiaries of the great reforms implemented by Labor governments—commencing with Whitlam and going through to Hawke and Keating—in the area of higher education, that they should think seriously about what they are doing to the future of young Australians.

With these massive expenditure cuts, you will be reducing by around 30,000 the number of university places that will be available. The government is turning back the clock. In our period of government we almost doubled the number of places, from 350,000 to 630,000. In one year you will reduce that substantially. You are ripping around five per cent out of the higher education budget. You are placing at risk the future of regional universities—universities in northern New South Wales, in western Sydney and in other states such as Victoria and South Australia particularly. Just as those universities have got off the ground, have got the capital investment and expenditure in them and are attracting more students into higher education, you are threatening their very existence. For instance, of 16,000 student places in regional universities throughout Australia that will go by the board, approximately 2,400 of them are in New South Wales. That will mean a massive reduction of $24 million out of regional universities in New South Wales.

The same story is told throughout all the other states. What is this minister's response?
She says, `Oh well, they can get in by paying full fees.' You know that students in those areas, families in those areas, are not going to have the capacity to pay full fees to take up places in universities. This government's ultimate disgraceful approach to regional higher education can be seen when you look at the statement delivered by the Hon. John Sharp on budget day entitled Rebuilding Regional Australia. You will not find one mention anywhere in that document of the word `education'. Education in regional Australia is not important to this government.

speech.speaker: Schacht, Sen Chris

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate—

(a)
notes the broken promise of the Coalition Government and its minister to maintain funding to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC);

(b)
notes:

para.tab:
(i)
that the Government's $209 million cuts to the ABC over the next 4 years will destroy the ABC as Australians have known it,

(ii)
that this cut is motivated by the desire of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to destroy the independence of the ABC,

(iii)
that this cut, in particular, will reduce broadcasting services to the smaller states, rural and regional Australia and the youth of Australia, and that other services which may be affected include ABC fine music, television, drama, Radio National and the State orchestras, and

(iv)
with grave concern, the appointment of the Mansfield review of the ABC, with restrictive terms of reference which are clearly aimed at destroying the independence of the ABC; and

speech.para:
(c)
strongly supports the maintenance of the ABC as a broad‐based independent national public broadcaster.

Today in Senate question time we saw an extraordinary performance by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) in attacking me for putting out a statement exposing the hypocrisy of the government in breaking their election promise. Senator Alston was asked what would have to be one of the most clumsily worded
dorothy dixers ever heard in the Senate. In my view, the way it was worded greatly embarrassed the new President, Senator Reid. The minister was asked to comment about statements I had put out regarding the government's cut to the ABC's funding. The supplementary question was even worse, asking, `Minister, would you care to comment on any other shadow minister you would care to think of?'

The President said that she would look at the issue of what constituted relevant questions under the standing orders. We in opposition look forward to her comments and her ruling as a result of that very stupid Dorothy Dix question and the remarks made by the minister. The minister was trying to cover his tracks—that is the best way I could put it—on the broken promise of the coalition.

During the election campaign, it was reported on page 5 of
Better Communications
of 18 January 1996 that, `The coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC' and that, `The coalition will maintain the current prohibition on advertising and sponsorship on ABC television and radio.' On the night of the election, after it was clear that the coalition had comprehensively won the election, Senator Alston, as the incoming minister, was interviewed by Jim Middleton on ABC television in front of viewers across Australia watching the telecast. Jim Middleton said:
First of all the commitment close to home about the ABC and commitment to maintain funding in real terms over the term of the coming parliament, does that stand?
Senator Alston said:
Absolutely.
Mr Middleton asked:
Even if you discover on Monday that the budget's bottom line is much worse than the government's been saying?
Senator Alston replied:
Oh yes. I think John Howard's made it very plain that we want to maintain—honour—all our commitments and the ABC is a very important part of that.

In all of these remarks by Senator Alston there is a clear, unequivocal commitment to maintaining the funding of the ABC. When Senator Alston subsequently had to announce
the $55 million cut in the ABC's budget over the next three years—starting next financial year—he tried to explain, in an interview with Kerry O'Brien on
Lateline
, that he was not talking about the triennium; he was talking only about the coming year. But that is not what he said in response to Jim Middleton on the ABC on election night.

Senator Alston has been caught red‐handed in misleading the Australian people throughout the election campaign and on election night about the coalition's commitment to the ABC. Since election night, we have seen a concerted, deliberate campaign not only by Senator Alston but by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and the Treasurer, Mr Costello, in attacking the ABC politically. Senator Alston started off by attacking the management qualities of the ABC. Yet only last year, in the report of a Senate committee which he chaired, he gave the management of the ABC a big tick. The report, which Senator Forshaw has with him now in the chamber, is called
Our ABC
.

talk.start.para: —It was their title.

—It was their title. Senator Alston chaired the committee and signed off the report, saying that the management of the ABC was okay. Once he became minister, once the political attack started, he began saying that the management had a lot to answer for. That was followed by remarks by Mr Howard, which I think are the most serious remarks, outlining the political intent and outlining what the coalition really thinks of the ABC. Several times—it was not an accidental slip of the tongue or a Freudian slip—Mr Howard said that the ABC coverage was biased, that it was too politically correct, and that you heard only one view on the ABC. Subsequently, coalition spokespeople have been reported as saying that, for example, there is too much emphasis on Aboriginal affairs on the ABC. Mr Howard has apparently said that himself.

speech.para:
What Mr Howard would like is to have any issues that are uncomfortable to him, or that do not make Australians feel relaxed and comfortable, taken off the ABC altogether. He does not want issues reported and then have people on both sides of the argument put their
view. Mr Howard really wants to get down to an almost Orwellian view that nothing that is controversial or uncomfortable to his view of society ought to be reported. That is why he is making those remarks.

Then, of course, we have the Treasurer, Mr Costello. When the National Commission of Audit report was released—which, in most areas, the coalition ran 100 miles away from and ignored completely because it had too many uncomfortable things in it for even Mr Costello to contemplate—it made a suggestion that the funding for the ABC as an institution be removed and that all programming money be put out to competition. This would gut the ABC and would mean that we would no longer have a national broadcaster. That was their recommendation. It was not covered in detail in the report. There was no great explanation about it. It was almost a one‐paragraph throw‐away line, but Mr Costello chose to emphasise those remarks in his statement at the time of the release of the audit report. He chose to say that ABC management is not up to the mark.

We clearly have a pattern. First of all there was a softening up of the public debate by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Communications and the Arts attacking the ABC. The next stage of the program was the announcement of the efficiency dividend cut of $10 million to $11 million a year which has been applied to all agencies—this was immediately a breach of their election promise. But then, of course, we had the sudden announcement, announced boldly and coldly by Senator Alston on behalf of the government, that there would be a cut of $55 million a year starting from next year and that every year thereafter that cut in the base funding would continue.

So over the next four years of outlays—this is not an estimate on our part, but an absolute calculation—when you put the efficiency dividend cut in, plus the $55 million a year for the following three years, it totals $209 million. Yesterday and the day before Senator Alston was attempting to say that I had that figure wrong in my statement. I think he also tried to say it today. Yet today's Melbourne
Age
has a report on a statement by Mr Brian
Johns, Managing Director of the ABC, which absolutely confirms the figure I put out in my press release as correct. He says:
Based on the Government's forward estimates, the ABC's funding will be $200 million worse off in today's dollars over the next four years.

Senator Alston is trying to explain to people that the cut only has one year and thereafter it is restored. I do not think he understands that, compared with what we had put in the budget for future outlays and what we had committed ourselves to and what people had expected for the next triennium, there will be a $209 million loss to the ABC. This is not just tinkering and removing a little bit of fat from the edge. This is the deepest and most significant cut to the operation of the ABC since it was formed in the early 1930s. This is going to destroy the ABC as a national broadcaster covering a broad range of programs to a broad range of Australians in all sorts of areas.

Only yesterday in the Senate adjournment debate my colleague Senator Ray paid great tribute to the ABC radio coverage of the Olympic Games from Atlanta saying that it was excellent, that the quality of the broadcast and the commentators were a real credit to the ABC and that it was very informative. He pointed out that, if you make the big cuts to the ABC, the organisation will lose its institutional skills, its memory and its backup to have available the people with such a broad range of skill in broadcasting 30‐odd different sports at the Olympic Games.

The ABC does not just broadcast for a few elite or a few significant minorities; it broadcasts for everybody across Australia. That is in the charter. When the Labor Party was in government back in the 1980s it put legislation through this parliament that gave the ABC a broad based charter for all Australians. That is the charter this parliament adopted. It is the existing charter. But what do we find? On the same day as they announced these drastic cuts to destroy the ABC they announced the appointment of Mr Mansfield to review the charter.

One would have thought they would have put the review first and then justified some cuts. This is the classic case of putting the
cart before the horse. They have put the cuts in anyway, irrespective of what Mr Mansfield may find. Mr Mansfield has terms of reference that almost predict the outcome of the review. They are narrow. They are aimed at restricting the ABC from being a broad based national independent broadcaster.

I do not know whether Mr Mansfield realises what he has stepped into by accepting the invitation of the government to conduct this independent review. Mr Mansfield has had a long, successful history in Australian industry. He was the chief executive of McDonald's fast food chain when it was going through its most expansionary period. He then became chief executive of Optus when it started to become the second telecommunications carrier. Then, for a short period, he was chief executive of Fairfax until he fell out with its foreign owners when he tried to run the company as an Australian company.

We have to be honest, and I do not think Mr Mansfield would dispute this: Mr Mansfield does not have much of a history or interest indicated in Australian public broadcasting. Nevertheless, he has had broad experience in industry and he is conducting this review. I suspect he was more than a little surprised at the immediate public reaction around Australia to the announcement of the cuts in the ABC, the appointment of himself and those rigged terms of reference which the government gave him.

There have been rallies of tens of thousands of people in Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne, Adelaide, Fremantle, and so on. I attended one in Fremantle. What was striking about those rallies was not that a small group of people from one segment of our community turned up but that—and this is from my observations at the rally in Fremantle—the group that turned up was notable in its diversity. There were people ranging from those who were clearly what I would consider to be coalition supporters to those who would be well to the left of the Labor Party. There were young people, old people, ethnic representatives, working class people, retirees, and so on. You name it, they were represented in the audience.

break.para: At the end of the meeting after the guest speakers had spoken, those people had a chance to make their views known. I had never heard for a very long time such passion from all these people when they stood up at the microphone and articulated their views. `Leave the ABC alone', `Restore the cuts', `It's our ABC', they were saying to the government, and in particular to Senator Alston—`Leave it as it is'.

We know that some members of the coalition consistently complain about ABC bias in some form or another. We all, as politicians, complain about bias when we do not quite get our press release read out the way we would like. That is the nature of the beast. That will always be the case. But from time to time there have been just as many people in the Labor Party who have been upset about the way the ABC has covered something as there have been on the other side.

However, what I think is most noteworthy is that all the surveys show the bulk of the ABC traditional audience being coalition supporters. Despite the so-called bias that Mr Howard goes on about, coalition voters are the ones who overwhelmingly are the listeners and viewers of the ABC. Despite Mr Howard's concern about bias, they continue to listen to and watch the ABC. I believe that coalition voters by these actions have told Mr Howard: we do not think the ABC is biased because we like listening to it and watching it. Absolutely, and in one fell swoop, those surveys have destroyed Mr Howard's own argument about bias.

para.break: I would say also that in non-metropolitan Australia, in regional Australia, probably 90 per cent of listeners to the ABC, particularly in some rural areas, would be coalition or National Party supporters. What I have seen sometimes of ABC rural and regional radio, the local radio station, in western New South Wales or in the Riverland area of South Australia is that, because the local federal member and state member are overwhelmingly coalition members, they get an extraordinary run of their statements being broadcast—as they should. From the Labor Party point of view, we do not get an equal say; unfortu nately, of course, we are not the elected members in those areas.

break.para: But to say that the coalition is being harshly dealt with by the ABC in rural and regional Australia is hypocrisy; it is just madness. All the evidence goes to the opposite. I ask rural Liberal members and anyone from the National Party, in particular: give us examples of occasions when your press release was not run, when you did not get a chance to make a comment on the ABC regional morning news service when you had something sensible to say. They cannot give one example.

talk.start.para: —I can. I was interviewed. I was told they would only run the interview if I bucketed the government.

—I apologise. I accept that in the case of Senator O'Chee there would obviously be an exception. The quality of his press releases and public comments is even too hard for the ABC in the rural areas to give a run to. But that is Senator O'Chee's quality, not a fault of the ABC. That would be your fault, Senator O'Chee.

break.para: One area where some people in the coalition—not all, but some—get themselves stirred up is programs, innovative programs like the new Triple J network which has spread across Australia. We have Mr Bradford, the member from the Gold Coast area, publicly asking that the ABC completely close down Triple J because occasionally it uses some four-letter words—occasionally. Triple J occasionally talks about things about which he feels uncomfortable, and so on. But I say to Mr Bradford, the coalition and everyone else: do they realise that each week 2.5 million to 2.8 million young Australians listen to Triple J? What an astonishing performance; what an astonishing consumer reaction, if you want to put it that way. The young people of Australia have voted with their ears: they want to listen to Triple J.

Where are the biggest audiences for Triple J now occurring? On the regional network that Triple J, under the policies of the previous government, was able to spread throughout Australia. We were very proud to be able to give Triple J the chance to become a national network station. Young people in the rural areas are voting with their ears by
turning on Triple J. They find that Triple J is talking about issues that are relevant to them and their lifestyle—issues that are important to them.

But Mr Bradford, a back bench Liberal member, I will concede—and thank goodness for that—wants to close it all down. Does he realise that of the total ABC radio audience each week Triple J has half? The audiences of all the rest of the ABC radio stations comprise about 2 million people. Triple J is the other half of the total audience—which, again, is an amazing success.

The other point about Triple J which I want to mention is that it is not just about passive listening, the putting out of music. It is about promoting young Australian rock-and-roll popular music; it is about developing Australian culture in popular music. I am told that Silverchair, that popular band from Newcastle for young people, first got its break on Triple J—and I have to admit that, as I turn 50 this year, Mr Acting Deputy President, it may be a bit beyond my league.

talk.start.para: —Are you turning 50 this year?
—Yes.
—Well, well, a baby boomer.
—That is right, I am the classic baby boomer, Senator Patterson. I have to say that my musical tastes still reflect the late 1960s and early 1970s as far as rock and roll is concerned.
—The Seekers and things like that?
—No, not the Seekers. There was a member of the Seekers who went on to be a Liberal member of parliament. I was a bit suspicious about it.

break.para:
I want to just mention Silverchair because they got their break when they were played live on Triple J across Australia and developed an audience who went out and bought their records. As a result, they went international and have sold millions of records in the United States. They have brought income into this country that has helped our balance of budgets. That young band from Newcastle is
an export earner for Australia. It is the equivalent of a large-sized company bringing in millions of dollars. That one company has brought more dollars into Australia in export earnings than it cost the ABC to run the whole of Triple J for one year. It is an extraordinary performance.

What do we see in this budget? We see not only the attack on the ABC generally but also the fact that the money we gave through Creative Nation last year to promote and unearth new rock‐and‐roll bands in Australia for Triple J has been abolished in the budget. Talk about being blind to the opportunities to promote export earnings, because Australian rock and roll music—popular music—has a reputation round the world, not only in North America and Europe but also in Asia. It is a major export earner of which we should be very proud.

The ABC is one of those institutions in Australia that everybody has a view about. From time to time we all admit that we disagree with it. It is open to endless criticism; it is open to argument and debate; and it has management inefficiencies. In any organisation as big as the ABC and with a budget as large as it has, there is no doubt that somewhere in the organisation there will be a manager who is not doing his job absolutely the way he should be. There will be some wastage of money and that should all be looked at. They should always be aiming to improve the management and the structure. There may be too many middle managers and more money should be put into actual programs—all of those arguments—but we have to say that Senator Alston said last year that the management was basically okay.

We have to recognise that the ABC is one of those institutions that create a national character and a national binding of Australians together. In a modern society, with all the tensions and all the difficulties that are around, it is very important for us to support those institutions that maintain and develop the national character and the national identity of Australia. I cannot think of any organisation that does it more than the ABC. There may be some that equal it, but there would be none that surpass it in creating that national
image and in helping to identify that national character.

The ABC does it not only on the cultural side but also by the very presence of its current affairs and news services so that information on major events is broadcast around Australia. The reporting of this parliament today will be shown right around Australia so that, no matter where you are, the national parliament can be seen on the television or heard on the radio. I might not like the way that they have reported my speech today or whether they even reported it, but the point is that it is the institution that spreads the word and that gives out the information in a very effective way. If you damage the ABC, you damage the very fabric of Australia and the way in which that national identity, that national unity, can not only be preserved in the end but also be enhanced.

I think the government has made a catastrophic error in announcing these cuts. I think it did it on a petty, vindictive basis to get even with the so-called perception of bias in the ABC. But I do not think the government realises the consequences of what it is doing to the country of which it is now the elected government.

An example of what I think is the support for the ABC in all quarters is that about four weeks ago I was driving one Saturday night back to my home from country South Australia and I turned on ABC FM fine music on the car radio. They were broadcasting live the final of the Sydney International Piano Competition—a world-class event which went for four weeks involving something like 40 or 50 pianists—

talk.start.para: —How involved was former Senator Bishop in setting that up?

—I will come to that. I am glad you mentioned it because I was going to certainly mention it. They broadcast the recitals of all the competitors on that network across Australia. So it was not just the people lucky enough to be in Sydney who heard it; it was right across Australia. On the night of the presentation when they gave the prizes out, I want to acknowledge here that I think seventh prize was sponsored by former Senator Bishop, now Mrs Bishop.
—She was one of the people who set it up.

—Of course. I then find it even more extraordinary, Senator Patterson, that the coalition would put at risk the ABC and its future and such a network as the ABC FM fine music network. The interesting thing is that, when the announcer thanked everybody and in particular thanked the ABC fine music network for making this a national event, the applause from the audience for the ABC was bigger than even for the actual winner. I find that a very interesting indication. I suspect that the bulk of that audience listening in the Sydney Opera House were overwhelmingly coalition supporters like Mrs Bishop; yet, when they had a chance to show their support for the ABC, they applauded long, loud and hard. When the organiser was interviewed later on, he again made the point that the Sydney International Piano Competition could not exist if it were not for the ABC, which has made it an international event.

break.para: These are the programs; these are the cultural things that are under attack by this drastic $55 million a year cut to the ABC budget. It costs $3½ million to run Triple J across Australia. Even if you did knock that off, you would still need another $52 million savings somewhere else. ABC FM fine music probably costs $4 or $5 million a year to run. They are the savings you are going to find in closing down all of those sorts of programs to get to the total of $55 million.

The amount of $55 million is more than the total cost that the ABC spends each year on Australian drama. No more Australian drama on ABC television? That would be catastrophic. We all know that Australian TV drama now has a world reputation in that the producers, the writers, the actors and the directors who learnt their skills in the ABC television drama department are now recognised as being world class.

I was told the other day that one of our Oscar winners, Mr Semmler, the photographer for
Dances with Wolves
, started his career as a cameraman for the ABC in Riverland, South Australia. He went on to win an Oscar and is now one of the world's top cinematographers.
Where did he get his training? He got it in the ABC. If there had been no institutional structure he would not have got training.

In my view, one of the great heroes of modern times is writer and journalist Neil Davis, the Australian who died in 1985 covering a coup in Bangkok. He stayed behind to watch the North Vietnamese army roll into Ho Chi Minh City. He covered the war in Cambodia. In the end he covered too many wars and unfortunately and tragically was killed. Where were his beginnings? They were in Hobart where he learnt his job as a photographer for the news service in the Hobart studios of the ABC. He went on to become one of the most recognised war correspondents and photographers in the world.

That is what the ABC did for people. It provided the infrastructure and institution. What are we going to do when you destroy the structure of the ABC and remove that institution? You will diminish Australia substantially. You will remove our national identity. You will remove the cultural input of an organisation that has been so effective in developing an Australian character.

It is astonishing that for petty political reasons and base motives, led by the Prime Minister, the ABC is now going to lose $209 million from its budget over the next four years. I say on behalf of the opposition that we will campaign endlessly to get that decision changed. I think we can get it changed because, in the end, too many Australians, including coalition supporters, will not let this drastic, catastrophic attack on the ABC be successful.

speech.speaker: Patterson, Sen Kay

talk.start.para:
—I rise to speak on the motion moved by Senator Schacht relating to the ABC. I find it interesting that Senator Schacht is speaking about this today and is indignant about the fact that there have to be cuts to a large range of services and government programs when I think about the waste that occurred when Labor was in government. Sometimes the amounts must have seemed small to the Labor Party, but they added up to the sort of amount that we are now looking
at taking out of the ABC's budget. I note that Senator Schacht is now leaving the chamber.

speech.para: I think of the millions of dollars that were lost in the Midford debacle and the millions that had to be paid out by the public as a result of his ineptitude as a minister. Another example is the $5 million, which I pursued, that was spent in selling the disability reform package. The company was insolvent when it got the contract. I could give example after example of the mismanagement that we endured under the previous Labor government.

We are now being called to account for that. We have a responsibility to the next generation. One of the reasons I came into parliament was that when I was growing up—and Senator Schacht and I are about the same age—the world was my oyster. Whatever I wanted to do I could do. As I got a bit older I saw those opportunities slipping away for young Australians—the sorts of kids who now listen to Triple J. They do not have the same opportunities that many of us in this chamber had when we were growing up.

This is because we have wasted golden opportunities. The Labor Party wasted quarter after quarter of growth. It took no advantage of that. We have been left with a budget deficit. We have a hole of $8 billion to $10 billion. That is the reason we are discussing this today. No‐one likes to be involved in looking at programs and deciding where cuts have to be made. Even the Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bernie Fraser, indicated that it is possible to make adjustments of $4 billion in each of the next two years.

We admit that the ABC is one of Australia's primary institutions with a very significant and valued role to play in the Australian community. The government wants the ABC to continue doing what it does best. We will ensure that it remains an independent national broadcaster delivering quality programming to audiences as efficiently as possible.

For the opposition to come in here and say that we are going to destroy the ABC is absolutely wrong. Belts will have to be tightened. An assessment will have to be made of the various programs. A process has been put in place to do that, and I will discuss
that in a moment. We have to tighten our belts and the ABC cannot be quarantined from that.

Before I move on to discuss the cuts that are being put forward, I will quote what Gareth Evans said about cuts to the ABC in 1988 when he was Minister for Transport and Communications. Senator Schacht has not mentioned that the Labor government made cuts to the ABC. Gareth Evans said:

While there has been some decline in funding for the ABC over the past two Budgets, as compared with the peak year of 1985‐6 . . . this does not reflect any loss of affection for the ABC or any decision to squeeze it harder than anyone else—the absence of new policy approvals has been a function of the pressure which has been applied universally to government departments and agencies.
We have inherited a problem that resulted from the previous Labor government's mismanagement. The words Gareth Evans used in 1988 when outlining cuts to the ABC apply now. He said:

This does not reflect any loss of affection for the ABC or any decision to squeeze it harder than anyone else . . . a function of the pressure which has been applied universally to government departments and agencies.
This comment from Gareth Evans rebuts completely the motion put forward by Senator Schacht. It is exactly the point that the government has been trying to get across.

The ABC will receive around $530 million in 1996-97 and $500 million in 1997-98. I have to say that we are taking a $10 million cut here in Parliament House. We do not walk around saying, `Parliament will have to close down because we have taken a $10 million cut.' We have had to tighten our belts, make some savings and adjust to that.

The funding I outlined before—the $530 million in 1996-97 and $500 million in 1997-98—represents a very strong commitment in a time when financial restraint is necessary. It seems extreme to argue that $½ billion a year in funding for a quality national broadcasting service is destructive. That $½ billion will not mean that the ABC will be destroyed. It puts paid to the opposition's claims that the cuts will destroy the ABC.

break.para: Since the introduction of triennial funding in 1988, funding has been relatively stable. It has declined marginally as a result of the efficiency dividends in 1988-89 and 1989-90, but it is possible to address these cuts—and many people have indicated this, even from within the ABC.

The opposition is making the claim that we have got in it for the ABC because we think that it is biased. I try not to think that, but it is very hard sometimes when you have David Salter, an ABC employee, saying last Sunday:
Broadcasting philosophies come and go. Governments come and go. We will get the bastards.
I do not think that that is an appropriate term to use in the chamber, but that is what he said. He continued:
Two years from now we will be as strong as ever.

In the May 1996 Green Guide I was quite amazed to find a little quotation about the 1996 election. The Green Guide said in the box entitled `The file on "Lateline"' under the subheading `The toughest show to do':

The 1996 federal election. At 6.45pm, Anthony Green and his computer called the win for the Liberal Party. "I said nothing, and Kerry (O'Brien) said nothing. It was almost as if we couldn't comprehend it."
That was Maxine McKew.

I know people in the industry—and this is true for any industry—have a position, but I think they have an obligation to keep those views to themselves and to behave in a non-partisan way. It is exactly the same responsibility as other people have. For example, if teachers in tertiary institutions have a particular philosophy, my view is that they should educate the students, give them the various options and give them the skills to choose. To try to inculcate them with your views is not appropriate.

Let us face it, we can cope with that. The Labor Party sometimes cries foul that the ABC is biased and that there have been all sorts of complaints from various avenues. I ask that the ABC attempt to present its information in the most non-partisan way possible. But to say that we are having a go at the ABC because we think it is biased, as has been claimed, is totally inappropriate.

The government made a commitment to maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC. Senator Schacht has said that we have not kept that commitment. Despite the pressure to make budget savings—and some areas have been asked to make those savings immediately—we agreed to maintain ABC funding for the remainder of the current triennium, less the generally applied two per cent cut in running costs, which the government clearly signalled in
Meeting our commitments
, which was released on 15 February.

So we told people that there would be a two per cent across‐the‐board cut—and that represented to the ABC a $10.8 million ongoing reduction—and then we announced a reduction in the ABC's funding of $55 million in 1997-98, which is the beginning of the next triennium. We have kept our commitment to maintain their funding until the end of that triennium unlike what we have had to do in other areas. That again was not mentioned by Senator Schacht.

As for long-term guarantees, we did not see the previous Labor government giving long-term guarantees to the ABC. I would like to read to you what Senator Schacht said in this chamber on 24 February in 1988. I think sometimes he forgets what he said—we all forget, and it comes back to haunt us—during the debate on a matter of public importance regarding the ABC. If you stay here long enough, what comes around comes around. Senator Schacht said in that debate on 24 February:
It is all very well for the Democrats to claim that the ABC is being reduced by funding. This Government—
sic—

has to make tough decisions about priorities right across the board in the running of this country, providing money for many different worthwhile projects. It is no good for the running of this country if, to make oneself feel good, one says that the ABC will get another $100m, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation will get another $50m, et cetera. Once one goes through that list, sane economic management of this country will come to an end.

He has answered his own question. I could not have said better what Senator Schacht said here. You just cannot keep saying yes and
nod to every program the government runs. It is not sane economic management, as he says. Let me tell you that we have not had sane economic management of this country for the past 13 years. Thank heavens the Australian public had the good wit and the will to elect us to implement some sane economic management. If we get it right—and I am sure we will—the ABC should be thinking about how to expand its programs in the future. But, for the time being, it is difficult for us to do that given the legacy that we have been left by Labor.
