I agree with what Senator Schacht said on that occasion: the government does have to make tough decisions about priorities right across the board in running the country and provide money for many projects which are worth while. We promised to improve the economy and the situation of Australia for all Australians, and that is what we are doing. We are making these cuts not because we want to, not to fix our mistakes, but because we have to, it is economically responsible to do so and, finally—and this is more to the point—to make up for, to correct, the mistakes of Labor's mismanagement. We did not enjoy making the cuts; however, we have to overcome the irresponsibility of the previous Labor government and get Australia back on track.

I also remind the opposition that, had they been honest about the state of the economy before the election, we could have allowed for it in making our policies in relation to funding for all areas, including the ABC. In light of the fact that it is budget week, I remind the chamber of the deception of the previous government in hiding the immense size of the budget deficit until after we came into power. In the May budget last year, in 1995, Labor announced a surplus. I can remember the headlines. There was euphoria about a surplus of $720 million for 1995-96 and a headline surplus of $3.4 billion for 1996-97. What a joke! Do you remember that, Senator Herron and Senator Panizza—a $720 million surplus? That is what they told us and ran out and told the press.

They now have the gall to come in here and talk about our management when they were
so far out of the ballpark it did not matter. They were off the planet. Then they had to do a bit of rejigging. In December 1995 we got a bit of a course correction. If those opposite had been on a spaceship orbiting the earth, they would have been off to Mars. That is a popular place to go at the moment, and that is where this opposition ought to have gone a long time ago, because they put Australia so far off course it did not matter. We were right off course. They had a bit of a rejig, they got themselves back in line and they told the public and the financial markets that, oops, they made a mistake, that we did not have a $720 million surplus—only a $115 million surplus. So we went from having a $720 million surplus to a $115 million surplus. They rejigged it to get back on course a bit.

From this point on, when the coalition realised things were going from bad to worse, we called on Labor to release updated Treasury estimates of the budget position. Labor maintained that this could not be done, arguing that the figures were not available, still leaving us to believe we were going to be in surplus. We had some doubts about that, but what did Mr Keating say? `Trust me.' Unfortunately, the Australian public did for far too long, but then they saw the light. The figures were not available right up until the week of the election. That argument was used right throughout the campaign.

As it turned out, Labor were hiding the truth. The figures would have been available but they wanted to maintain the deception that we were still in surplus. On Monday, 4 March, two days after the election, the Prime Minister, John Howard, and the Treasurer, Peter Costello, were fully briefed by Treasury. On 12 March, the Treasurer, Peter Costello, released the revised Treasury budget estimates for 1995-96. These revised estimates revealed that the budget for 1995 had moved from a surplus of $720 million to—we were on Mars—a deficit of $280 million. How on earth can you have a budget surplus of $720 million and then in February—not even the end of the year—be $280 million out of kilter? And you have the gall to stand over there and criticise us for reining in spending.

It is not only that. There is another issue. An article in the
Financial Review
a week or two ago said that this issue would be forgotten on budget week. Not only do we have Beazley's black hole but the government's public debt trebled over the past four years, under the former government, to almost $100 billion—more than half of the grand total of $185 billion. Also, during 1995-96, we Australians and taxpayers paid $10 billion in interest payments. People out there in the community understand that our paying $10 billion a year is making no dent at all on what we owe. People who have a mortgage on their house know what their interest payments are and that huge repayments, especially at the beginning of paying off their mortgage, seem to make no dent in the capital.

What we have done is borrow money for recurrent spending. This is not money borrowed for infrastructure that is going to make a difference; this is money borrowed to pay for recurrent expenditure. It is like paying for fairy floss: it disappears. We have nothing to show for it, nothing to build on. We are paying $10 billion in interest. If we had reduced that debt and our interest payments were less, we would have half of that money. We would have the money to pay for the ABC and to do the things that we would have liked to have done in government. Until we correct that situation we will be paying that $10 billion year in, year out.

We on this side have no intention of permitting that to continue. If we did that, we would be selling the next generations of Australians short. They are the ones who will be left to repay that debt. With fewer of us working, with fewer of us contributing to taxation, as the population ages, we will leave the next generation with a debt and an interest bill which they will not be able to jump over.

Senator Schacht can stand there and talk about kids listening to Triple J. I would love them to be able to listen to Triple J. My staff listen to Triple J. When my younger brothers get into my car they turn on Triple J. Those young listeners of Triple J will inherit a debt if we do not do something about it. And this government is determined to do something
about it so that, when those young people who listen to Triple J are our age, they will not be in the situation we are in now.

Even before the recent announcement that we were going to have to make some cuts to the ABC, the ABC Managing Director, Brian Johns, had acknowledged that there was a need for a fundamental restructuring of the organisation in order to assist the process of creative renewal and to position the corporation for what will be a radically different media environment. Many of the hard decisions the ABC has recently made are the result of the corporation's $13.5 million budget blow‐out and not the government's $10 million funding cut. In fact the ABC issued a press release on 31 March outlining this.

One of the other moves that the minister has made to acknowledge the problems facing the ABC in addressing the tightening of their belt is in relation to the fact that the ABC will need guidance and assistance on those activities which are the community's highest priority. Acknowledging that, the minister has established a review of the ABC under Mr Mansfield to redefine and to reposition the future direction of the ABC.

This morning I was listening to the ABC and heard Mr Mansfield being interviewed, which should give many of the people who have concerns great comfort. He was talking about a lot of aspects. He talked about the need to address the issue of rural and remote areas. He talked about a number of concerns that have been expressed to me by people who are avid listeners of the ABC, and obviously Mr Mansfield is going to address those.

The terms of reference of the review stress factors such as the importance of the independence of the ABC, that it be a high quality service and the importance of services to rural and remote communities and other significant groups not well served by the broadcasting services. The outcome of the review will be reported to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Richard Alston, by the end of next year. In making its report, the review will be seeking the views of ABC
audiences, the public broadcasters themselves and other interested parties.

With respect to some of the aspects of the review, this review will reposition and redefine the national broadcaster for the 21st century. This is something that is absolutely vital, as we see enormous changes taking place in information technology, especially in the area of broadcasting. The government's priority is to ensure that quality programming is delivered to audiences as efficiently as possible. The government has made it clear in the terms of reference and directly to Mr Mansfield in undertaking the review the priority it places on services to rural and remote communities as well as to children and other significant groups not well served by other broadcasting services.

The review is timely. The ABC is facing major challenges in maintaining its output across the current range of its activities. As I said before, these difficulties have been acknowledged by the ABC Managing Director. The review will provide the opportunity for a wide range of views about the ABC—a broadcasting organisation that is broadcasting in a changing environment.

It has been 15 years since the last independent review of the ABC—the Dix review. The broadcasting and communications environment has changed immeasurably. Not only is there greater competition amongst broadcasters but there has been a significant increase in the nature and availability of other forms of audiovisual entertainment.

The government has had to make difficult decisions in achieving the necessary reductions in Commonwealth funding, following its revelation about the budget blow‐out, as I mentioned. In examining the ABC and the very significant future funding pressures which its many activities are likely to place on the budget, the government has decided that the current level of funding cannot continue indefinitely.

The reason we have put this review in place is to make sure that as many of the programs and services of the ABC as possible are maintained and are delivered in an efficient way. I want to read out what Mr Gareth Evans, the then minister for transport and
education, said in a debate on the ABC's future.

talk.start.para: —When? What year was this?
—He said it at the ABC Friday Club on 26 February, 1988. You thought I would not know, but I do know.
—Oh, really! Eight years ago!

—Mr Deputy President, I will respond to that interjection. We are now talking about the function and role of the ABC. Some of the goals and roles, irrespective of whether it was 1988 or it is 1996, have not changed. There have been some developments of course and there have been some changes. He said:

break.para: . . . nobody has suggested that the Government and Parliament should not have a decisive role in defining the ABC's role and objectives, as set out in its legislative Charter. And however much we might all hope that resources and funding problems could solve themselves without having to be the subject of any kind of political involvement, the reality is that the Government and Parliament will go on being involved, year by year, in decisions that are obviously crucial for the ABC's future, and in particular its capacity to translate those Charter objectives into real‐world activity.
He also said in that same speech:
We simply cannot seriously or sensibly address the question of funding for the ABC without at the same time looking seriously and sensibly at its role and objectives. . .

That is exactly what the coalition is doing in setting up this review: looking at the roles and objectives of the ABC. So, in conjunction with having to address the budget constraints that are placed upon us, what we are doing in a responsible way is putting into place a review—with enormously wide consultation input from the community—of the various roles of the ABC, the various groups to whom the ABC appeals and the groups of people it reaches to ensure that with a budget of approximately half a billion dollars the very best service is given to the Australian community through the services of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

As I have already mentioned, the government has the task of getting Australia back on track by overcoming the debt and economic
mismanagement left by the previous Labor government. We did not create these problems but we will be responsible. We will do what is best for Australia and fix the mess that Labor has left us with. The ABC is one of Australia's primary institutions, with a very significant and valued role to play in Australian life. We recognise this and, as a government, we remain committed to the ABC. I look forward to the findings of the review, which will shape the future of the corporation. We will ensure that it remains an independent broadcaster delivering quality programming to audiences as efficiently as possible.

speech.speaker: Bourne, Sen Vicki

talk.start.para: —Senator Patterson has just enlightened us with some quotes from former senator Gareth Evans. I would like to requote something that has already been said. It is a quote from the current minister, Senator Alston, from election night when he was on the ABC election coverage. Jim Middleton of the press gallery asked him, `Do you maintain your commitment to the ABC continuing real funding over the life of this parliament—that is, three years?' The answer from Senator Alston: `Absolutely.' Then Mr Middleton came back with: `What if you find out that the budget is much worse?' And the answer was: `John Howard has made it clear we are honouring all our commitments.'

speech.para:
After all of that, on Kerry O'Brien's
7.30 Report
, Senator Alston said that he saw no contradiction between that and in fact doing the complete and utter opposite. I do see a contradiction, an extreme contradiction. And, what is more, most Australians see a very solid contradiction in that and they are very upset, extremely upset, about that contradiction.

What this government is doing with the ABC funding is taking away the independence of the public broadcaster through funding cuts of this magnitude. Have no doubt about it: they are enormous. When Senator Patterson said that the Labor Party is not innocent in this, she was dead right. The last government cut down on the ABC too.

The ABC is one of the few organisations in this country that have just been cut and cut and cut. They have been cut and then given
extra duties in their charter by every parliamentary party in this parliament. They have been given one‐off allocations of funding to carry out those extra duties and, after those one‐off allocations of funding are gone, they are told, `Keep carrying out the extra duties but we are not giving you any more money to do it with.' The ABC is one of the few organisations in this country that have been consistently cut over years and years and told to do more with less.

It is all very well to say that we have to trim off more fat. There is no more fat on the ABC; there just is not. We are trimming muscle, skin and bone; we are starting the amputations—it is pretty ugly. So here we have the ABC now being told, `Okay, carry out your own execution. We are not going to tell you—oh, we are going to tell you a little bit about where that execution is going to come from.'

I will just read from the budget statements. On page 3.131 of budget paper No. 1, there are a few reductions. The paper says `Cessation of extension of the "Unearthed" new music project', so `Unearthed', which, as Senator Schacht told us, is the project which goes around Australia and finds new youth music and is very successful, has gone. `Cessation of extension of Radio Triple J coverage': so if you cannot get Triple J now, just forget it; you are not going to get it in the future. This is despite the fact that Triple J is extraordinarily popular with young people. If those young people do not vote already, they will do so very soon. Just keep that in mind. Radio Triple J has an Internet site: let me say that it had an Internet site up until this budget. That has gone too. So the ABC is being told a few of its own execution points, but it is not being told all of them.

On page 3.132 you see: `Reduced Budget Funding for the ABC.' It is to be down $55 million in 1997‐98, down another $55 million in 1998‐99 and down another $55 million in 1999‐2000. This government is saying to the ABC, `You be your own executioner. You chop off a leg or an arm, or maybe a couple. You decide which ones; it is not our fault. And when it comes to the next election we will blame you for it.'

break.para: The government is reducing independent funding for an independent broadcaster and that of course simultaneously increases the power of already powerful media barons that we have in this country, because they own almost all of the rest. So we have one large independent media body which has an enormous diversity of interests inside it. And there probably is a bit of bias here and a bit of bias there: a bit of bias for the ALP on this side and the Liberal Party on that side; and the Nationals here and the Democrats there—goodness knows who else.

The point about the ABC is that that is all allowed to exist inside the one organisation and there are very few people who can order anybody in the ABC to do anything in an editorial sense, and they do not do it; they would not get away with it. If somebody came to the people on
Four Corners
and told them they would not be running a particular story because somebody did not like it, then the next story on
Four Corners
or the
7.30 Report
would be about somebody coming to tell them not to run the story because somebody did not like it. That is the way it works on the ABC. That is why bias is such a silly thing to say about it.

With the level of concentration of media ownership in Australia, it has really dire consequences and it is absolutely stupid and short‐sighted to cut down independent funding to an independent broadcaster because a government that increases the power of media barons, which is what it does if it does that, increases that power over itself. You are giving people power over yourself. Does the government really believe that media barons are going to be any more favourable to it compared with the so‐called political bias that it believes it is subjected to by the ABC? We all believe we are subjected to bias. In certain circumstances, we all are. I could name a couple of programs I really did not like that I thought were biased against me. Maybe they were but there were a lot of other programs that I did not think that about, that I thought were absolutely fair and reasonable. And that will happen with everybody and every party. I can name you whole newspapers that I think
are biased against me, and they probably are too.

We will go back to the motion of Senator Schacht. Let me reiterate what the coalition said in its policy statement, in Better Communications. Let me recommend to coalition members and particularly to Senator Alston that he reads his own policy document, because it is a very good one and there are a lot of policies in there that I think changed people's minds when they were deciding how to vote. I will just read out a few things:
The Coalition will maintain the existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC and SBS, and retain triennial funding.
It supports the ongoing extension of Triple J into regional Australia.
There's a good one:
It supports the ongoing extension of Triple J into regional Australia.
But, according to budget statement No. 1, it has ceased the ongoing extension of Triple J into regional Australia. What a pity. Continuing:
It will ensure Australia Television has a long term future in the Asia Pacific region.
It will fund the ABC and SBS directly for its transmission costs.

There's another interesting one. The budget for the National Transmission Authority has been cut by $28 million because its functions have been given to the ABC. So the government is not spending $28 million to fund the NTA. But guess what? It is not giving that $28 million that the NTA actually costs to the ABC to carry that out. The ABC will have to find that somewhere too.

So the ABC's funding will not drop by just that $55 million over the next three years. Its funding will not go down by the ridiculously called efficiency dividend—at which point does it become inefficient when you are down to a zero budget? Its funding has not just been chopped by that. It has also been chopped by that $28 million that it will have to find somewhere if it is to carry out its own transmission costs which the coalition promised in its election document to fund directly. Back to the election promises:
It will provide $6 million for the captioning of ABC and SBS news services.

Guess what? It did provide money for the captioning of ABC and SBS news services. I do not have time to read through this to see whether it was $6 million; but there was some money for that in the budget. There you go, there is one promise that may have been kept to a certain extent. I am very pleased to see it. Continuing:
The Coalition is committed to maintaining the ABC's comprehensive radio network.

If it is committed to maintaining it, I do not know how it is going to do it with $55 million less from its running budget this year and next year, another $55 million the year after and another $55 million the year after that. Continuing:
It will maintain the current prohibition on advertising and sponsorship on ABC television and radio.

There's a good one. I heard recently that that is open for negotiation as well. It might be open for negotiation through the House of Representatives, but I certainly hope that it is not open for negotiation through the Senate—it certainly will not be through me.

These are strong policies and they are good policies. I am absolutely positive that they caused voters to decide to vote for the coalition. What a mistake that was. If there is a double dissolution, I can tell you people will not forget that. The coalition will have to keep going the full three years for people to forget what happened here. People love the ABC with an absolute passion. You would be surprised how much they love the ABC.
The Australian Democrats are committed to the maintenance of the funding for the ABC—on the existing triennial basis. We are still looking for ways that we can help achieve that.
The ABC is one of the strongest and most relevant organisations in Australia today. I go back to the coalition policy document Better Communications:
. . . this vast network provides a diverse range of programs and performances of cultural value and intellectual integrity.
That is very true. It continues:
The ABC has a proud record of offering high quality and diverse programming across a broad spectrum of human interests including news, current affairs, drama, sport and the arts.

That view is shared by most Australians. Responding to a recent AGB McNair poll on 26 June, 61 per cent opted for the maintenance of government funding for the ABC at existing levels, and 24 per cent on top of that declared the funding should be increased. Eighty‐five per cent is a powerful majority supporting the work of the ABC. It includes regular and occasional ABC audiences as well as those who never utilise the services of the national broadcaster. It is seen as terribly important to all Australians and Australian life—and so it should be.

I was deputy chair of the 1995 Senate Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations which exhaustively examined the ABC inside and out. We saw the ABC—and this is in the report—as `sound and providing an independent, diverse and vibrant service'. What is more, looking at our recommendations in that report, the ABC have rectified all the problems that the committee identified except for the one in which they cannot help themselves—adequate government funding. In that report we identified that government funding of the ABC was not adequate. Senator Alston ought to remember that because he chaired that committee which found that government funding of the ABC was not adequate. It will be a lot less adequate after this budget.

The ABC has had more than its fair share of cuts. There is the two per cent efficiency cuts, the loss of a further $10 million and associated staff reductions. This is not to mention the proposed program cuts to both radio and television. How can a government which states it is fully committed to the national broadcaster—which we heard about again from Senator Patterson—whip out the machete and the firebrand and slash and burn the way it is doing?

para.break: We heard from both former speakers about Mr Mansfield's inquiry which seeks to `redefine the role of the ABC', which can probably be read as `seek to make amendments to the ABC charter'. I hope it is not the case that this inquiry has been set up to guarantee certain outcomes. Having met Mr Mansfield, I must say—I talked to him for about an hour or so—I find him an honour able man, and I would be very surprised if that was the case. I do not believe he has been told to come out with a certain outcome. I believe the outcome he comes out with, within the terms of reference, will be all his own work. I hope that is the case; I think it probably will be.

break.para: But we can see a couple of problems: the terms of reference are narrow and there are no public hearings, so the inquiry will not hear in a public manner from supporters of the ABC. I can tell the government now that there are far more supporters of the ABC than there are detractors.

I hope that it does not happen but it could be the case that an apparent lack of support for the ABC might then be defined as an argument against the ABC—and the only apparent lack of support would be because submissions are not public because there are no public hearings. So that might lead to the desired conclusion, in the government's mind, that the community wants to downgrade the ABC and divest it of some of its programs, some of its production and some of its services.

I can tell the government now that the community does not want the ABC downgraded. To show this we can look at the Friends of the ABC rallies all around Australia. They were testimony to that. I went to the Sydney rally in the Domain. It was massive. I got there just before the entertainment started. It was a festival atmosphere but the people I was talking to were really worried. I must say that most of the people I saw and talked to I think were probably coalition voters. I think this is a very big mistake on the part of the government.

Changes to the ABC charter are not necessarily a bad thing. We have to look at multimedia, convergent technologies and interactive technology. These are things that are rapidly descending on us and something we all have to take note of—including the ABC. The problems occur with changing the charter if attempts are made to diminish it, and in particular to diminish the independence and scope of the ABC, ensuring that fewer people can hear and enjoy the ABC.

ABC programs contribute enormously to Australia's sense of national identity. They inform and entertain us and, most importantly, they reflect our cultural diversity. Who else does that? Rural and remote Australians, inner city suburban residents, and older, younger and alternative listeners all rely on the ABC for news, entertainment, information and debate over crucial and important issues, issues that affect every single one of us.

The ABC consistently delivers high quality Australian product for television and radio. It consistently wins industry awards and accolades in Australia and overseas. Let me remind senators of a few of the television programs that have won awards. They include
Janus
,
Phoenix
, the
Damnation of Harvey McHugh
,
Four Corners
,
Frontline
,
Foreign Correspondent
,
7.30 Report
and
Lateline
. They are just the TV programs and that is not a comprehensive list of those that have won awards. Then we should look at radio. I do not have the list with me; I gave it to the Senate last time I spoke on the ABC. But ABC radio equally has won awards for any number of things.

There are other programs that are highly popular and that have set benchmarks that commercial channels attempt to match. Remember
Towards 2000
before it became
Beyond 2000
on commercial television? What about the educational dimension of important programs like
Play School
.
Play School
is an important program. It wins awards and is something that parents around Australia can barely do without. What about
Bananas in Pyjamas
—something we have actually sold to the USA, a nigh on impossible task.

The ABC was the forum that began the huge growth in lifestyle programs. The ABC is our greatest source of innovation and independent broadcasting. It has a significant impact on public and informed opinion. It creates debate and discussion and, most importantly, is not manipulated by anybody. Australia needs every single program and every single production on every single ABC network.

The debate about the ABC is not really a debate about money and jobs—but they are absolutely crucial. What the debate is really
about is the independence of the ABC and the editorial integrity of the ABC. It is about appropriately funding the ABC to enable it to do the things enshrined in its charter: provide news, information, educational programs and a national perspective to cater for intellectual and cultural needs as major, but not sole, priorities.

Let me finish by saying that I was one of the participants in the
Late Night Live
program. Senators will probably remember that Phillip Adams of the ABC did a series of
Late Night Live
programs around the country. I was one of the participants in the program in Canberra in the Old Parliament House. Mr Mansfield was there. I think it is to his credit that he turned up. Mr Ian Sinclair from the other place was there—and it certainly is to his credit that he turned up because it was a difficult one for any member of the coalition.

They had booked the old Senate chamber, thinking they would get a few hundred people. In fact, thousands of Canberrans turned out on a freezing night, quite late. They turned up at Old Parliament House and were participants in
Late Night Live
, talking about the future of the ABC. The feeling inside that chamber was absolutely electric. Nobody who was there would have forgotten it in a hurry.

The range of ages of people who were there, all of them ABC supporters, and the range of backgrounds of the people who came up and talked to me later were enormous—from young families to teenagers, then all the way up to what used to be known as the blue rinse set. There was a very large contingent of every single age group. That is something we all have to remember when we are considering what we are doing to the ABC. I honestly believe that the government has made an enormous mistake targeting the ABC. And the ABC has been targeted. It is no use saying, `Yes, we all have to bear the pain.' We do all have to bear the pain but why should the ABC have to bear more pain than anybody else? There must be a reason for it.

Targeting the ABC is not a sensible move on the part of the government. People are not going to forget this, particularly people who work for the ABC now and who will have to
find other jobs if they can, if these cuts go ahead—and there are so many cuts across the board in Australia that it is going to be very difficult—and particularly people who listen to the ABC now. If that is 85 per cent of the population this coalition government is in big trouble. This is something people will not forget. People love the ABC. It comes out again and again when people are asked what they think of the ABC. They have an enormous affection for it and they want it to be there.

It is a bit like Uluru—they want it to be there whether or not they see it; it is there if they need it. They know that sooner or later they may need the ABC. They are not stupid; they know that media diversity in this country is being diminished day by day. This is a ball that was started rolling like that thing out of
Raiders of the Lost Ark
—and it is very difficult to stop it. Once you have gone past a critical point with media diversity it is very difficult to bring it back. The only thing standing in the way at the moment is the ABC. It is the only thing that will continue to stand in the way.

But if we take away funding we take away independence. We take away what we value most about the ABC and what we need most in this country for it to give us: an independent voice in the media. The incredible stupidity of doing such a thing is almost beyond me. If the government persists in doing this, it will rue the day they decided on that course. That cabinet meeting where it was decided that the cuts to the ABC would be vicious and destructive, and would finally finish off the ABC and make sure it did not do nasty things to this government, will go down as a really black day in the annals of this government. If this government continues these funding cuts, it will regret that at the next election and it will keep regretting it until the ABC is put back together again.

talk.start.para: —I totally agree with what Senator Bourne has said. I think, in terms of this motion, the attack on the ABC is again just another indication of how the Howard Liberal government has ratted on the people of Australia.
—The coalition government.

—Senator Watson said the coalition government, and that is a very interesting point. I think the National Party count for nothing. The coalition policy on communications prior to the election is very interesting. Perhaps we should have picked up a few indicators about exactly what you were going to do from the policy. It says:

break.para: We will establish Australia as an information hub for the Asian and Pacific regions.
Hub goes with wheel: we had a wheel to start with, you certainly made it a hub, and I think we will get down to the bearings very shortly if we are not careful. The policy continues:
We will avoid at all costs the creation of information haves and have nots.
What do you know about that? It says:
We will ensure that people in regional and rural areas are not left behind in accessing new communications, services and so on.

That is why I make the point about the National Party being irrelevant in this government because if they were relevant you would not be doing this to the people of Australia. It is a Liberal government and the Nationals count for nought: therefore we have this ABC cut, and you are going to tear the guts out of them completely. That is just what you are planning to do.

As I said, I have listened many times to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) saying that he would bring to this parliament a new level of honesty. I do not know about the level of honesty. I will tell you what he has brought—a new level of dishonesty. If nothing else, that is exactly what you have achieved—a new level of dishonesty. Mr Howard said:
I will go on publicly saying it.
I am going to go on publicly reminding him of exactly what he has done and what he has done to the Australian people—

talk.start.para: —No, spud, you won't!

—Oh, yes, I will. Not on this occasion, Senator Panizza, but I will have plenty of other opportunities, I can assure you, to remind the Liberal government and the people of Australia of exactly what
you have done. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.speaker: Watson, Sen John

talk.start.para:
—I present the 345th report of the Public Accounts Committee entitled `An Advisory Report on the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996, the Income Tax Transitional Provisions Bill 1996, the Income Tax Consequential Amendments Bill 1996' and seek leave to move a motion and incorporate my tabling speech in
Hansard
.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
Report 345, An Advisory Report on the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996, the Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1996 and the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996

Mr President, it gives me great pleasure to table today Report 345, which is the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' inquiry into legislation to replace the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
This report details the JCPA's review of three Bills currently before the Lower Chamber. The Bills are:
• the Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996;
• the Income Tax (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1996; and
• the Income Tax (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1996.

The Bills are essentially the same as ones introduced and referred to the JCPA in the 37th Parliament. Unfortunately, that Committee did not have an opportunity to complete its inquiry before the general election was called. However, the evidence it gathered was not wasted and has been considered by the current Committee.

The fact that these Bills rewrite existing law does not diminish their importance. There are few pieces of Commonwealth legislation that affect more Australians than the tax laws. It should be a matter of considerable concern, therefore, that the most significant of these laws—the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936—is in danger of collapsing under the weight of its own complexity. This problem is recognised by all—from taxpayers to the Tax Office.

The Act is in desperate need of a comprehensive overhaul. It is over 5,000 pages long, cannot be easily read or understood, no longer has a recognisable structure and has had amendment piled on top of amendment over the last 60 years. The costs to business and individual taxpayers of trying to understand and comply with this law ranges from $3 billion to $6 billion annually. Any reduction in these compliance costs, therefore, will be a significant microeconomic reform.

The defects of the 1936 Act have been known for some time. Indeed, in 1993 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in Report 326—a landmark report on the administration of tax law and the operations of the Australian Tax Office recommended that the tax law be simplified.

The then Government accepted that recommendation and the Tax Law Improvement Project was born. The purpose of this project—known by all as TLIP—was, and is, to restructure, renumber and rewrite in plain language the income tax law. The Bills before the House essentially provide a new framework for the tax law, into which future packages of rewritten law will be slotted.
On the whole, the new legislation has been well received by the tax and accounting professions, industry groups and academics. It became clear to the

Committee during the inquiry that any improvements to the Bills would represent fine tuning rather than a major rethink. This stands as testimony to the efforts of the Bills' drafters and TLIP's extensive and comprehensive consultative and review.

While there may be general support for the contents of the legislation, there is certainly not support for its scheduled commencement date. As the Bills stand, they are due to have effect from 1 July 1996, clearly making them retrospective in application. The Committee acknowledges arguments that, in practical terms, the 1996 Bills are not retrospective
because they are only rewriting existing law and not creating `new' law.

However, it is unacceptable to the Committee that taxation legislation of any form be retrospective. For this reason, the Committee has strongly recommended that the commencement date for the legislation be changed to the first of July after enactment. Some argued that the commencement date should simply be moved back a year—to 1 July 1997. The Committee disagrees, for there is a risk that the legislation will not be passed by that date and become retrospective again. The Committee's recommendation removes any possibility of this occurring. I might add that this recommendation is consistent with a similar recommendation made last year by the JCPA when it reviewed TLIP's progress up until then.

The Committer has made a number of other recommendations associated with the phase-in of the new Bills. The Committee has recommended that these and subsequent Bills by TLIP commence progressively. This will minimise the impact that the transfer to the new law will have on taxpayers. The Committee also believes that the Australian Taxation Office needs to make a public commitment to rewriting promptly Public Rulings that will be affected by the new legislation. Similarly, the ATO will need to ensure that any technical errors or unintended consequences are addressed speedily.

In addition, the Committee has recommended amendments to various clauses that reflect the concerns of tax professionals and industry groups. In fact, the process of amending the Bills before us still goes on. The Committee has recently been briefed on proposed government amendments to the Bills concerning company tracing provisions. However, there was not time to consider these in any detail. TLIP has also recently advised the Committee that it will be correcting several technical errors in the Bills. The Committee looks forward to seeing these changes made.

One of the main objectives of the rewrite process is to reduce the long term cost of tax compliance. In the Committee's view, it is unlikely that compliance costs will come down significantly until such time as the underlying complexities of tax policy are addressed.

There is a clear sense of frustration that unworkable sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 are being perpetuated in the 1996 Bill. Unfortunately, addressing these concerns is beyond TLIP's current mandate. In practice, however, TLIP's mandate could not have been expanded without the rewrite process becoming bogged down in policy debates. Having said that, the Committee acknowledges that there needs to be more substantial simplification of the law.

There remains, therefore, the continuing need to address the `small p' policy complexities being highlighted by TLIP. The success of the Committee's review process suggests that a parliamentary committee may be an appropriate forum to examine these issues. This is partly in response to a perception that the Treasury is unresponsive to concerns about these matters when they are raised.

Therefore, the Committee has recommended that the Government fund a parliamentary committee to review the unworkably complex sections of tax law. This could be performed by the JCPA, a Joint Standing Revenue Committee or a Joint Select Committee.

In fact, the Committee believes that tax simplification requires more than just a rewrite or a tidying up of policy complexities. What is ultimately required is a wide ranging review of tax policy at the Federal and state level. Only after such a review can compliance costs truly come down. The Committee urges the Government to consider this.

On a final note, the Committee would like to thank all those individuals and organisations which have provided written and oral evidence and advice to both the previous and current JCPA. Some witnesses have given evidence twice to assist the new Committee come up to speed on the issues. We also thank the various officials from TLIP who have briefed the JCPA on a number of occasions.
On behalf of the Chairman, I would also like to thank my colleagues on the Committee who undertook the inquiry for the efforts they put in to it.
Mr President, the Committee believes that the efforts of all have generated a sensible and well informed debate. The result should be better legislation.
Thank you.

speech.speaker: Short, Sen Jim

talker.name: Senator SHORT
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer)

talk.start.para:
—I present a response to the 345th report of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts on the income tax bills. I seek leave to incorporate the response in
Hansard
and to move a motion in relation to the document.

speech.para: Leave granted.

The response read as follows
—
STATEMENT BY THE ASSISTANT TREASURER, THE HON JIM SHORT
TAX LAW IMPROVEMENT PROJECT
Mr President

On behalf of the Government I thank the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its Report No. 345 and express our appreciation for the time and commitment which Committee members, and their
staff, have invested in its preparation. I include in that appreciation the time and interest invested by the many professional organisations and individual persons who made submissions to the Committee.

The Joint Committee has taken a continuing interest in the rewriting of the income tax law. In November 1993, the Committee tabled its Report 326 An Assessment of Tax which recommended, among other things, the setting up of a broadly-based Task Force to rewrite the income tax law. The Tax Law Improvement Project was announced in the following month.

In November last year, the Committee tabled its Report 343 Tax Law Improvement: A Watching Brief in which it endorsed both the consultative way in which the project was proceeding and the intention to deliver the rewritten law progressively.
The Income Tax Assessment Bill 1996 and 2 related Bills, which are the subject of the Committee's latest report, are the first major instalment of the rewrite of the income tax law.
The Government is pleased that the Committee endorses the Bills and reaffirms its support for the progressive delivery of the new law.

Rewriting the income tax law so that it can be more easily understood has important micro-economic benefits for all Australians. Clearer law is inherently fairer. The Government wants to secure these benefits as quickly as possible.

The Government originally intended that the new law would apply for the current income year, as earlier versions of the Bills have been public since they were first introduced in November 1995. However, we recognise that the proroguing of Parliament in February created some uncertainty in the community about the reintroduction of the Bills and there has been unavoidable delay to the Parliament's consideration of them.

I note that the Committee has recommended that the commencement of the Bills be postponed until the income year following Royal Assent. The Government believes that a definite start date needs to be conveyed to the community, so that it can plan with certainty.

In light of this, the Government has decided to defer the commencement of the new law until the 1997-98 income year (which for most taxpayers will start on 1 July 1997). This decision will give everyone more time to ensure a smooth transition to the new law.

The Committee also recommends a small number of minor technical changes to the Bills, none of which involves any change in policy. I can inform the Senate that the Government accepts those recommendations and will make those changes.

Rewriting the law will also require the Commissioner of Taxation to update his public rulings to
reflect any changes in the new law. Taxpayers need certainty and are looking for an assurance that rulings obtained under the old law will not lapse simply because there has been a change to simpler language. I note with approval that the Committee endorses the Commissioner's proposal to negotiate, with the tax professions, a suitable process and timetable for rewriting affected rulings.

In a task as large as that embraced by this project there is always a danger that inadvertent errors may occur. I recognise the concern that any such errors be swiftly corrected. Again, I note with approval that the Committee endorses the process recently negotiated by the Commissioner and the tax professions for identifying and dealing with such errors.
The Committee's other recommendations raise wider issues which will require closer examination by Government.

Mr President, I am also taking this opportunity to announce a major improvement to the new law which will overcome a longstanding practical problem. The Government has decided to amend the Bills in the House of Representatives to introduce new, streamlined arrangements for allowing public listed companies to trace who beneficially owns their shares.

Companies that maintain continuity of their beneficial ownership may carry forward unused deductions, as tax losses. However, the existing processes for identifying ownership have been notoriously difficult and time consuming because of the varying ways in which shares can be held. In rewriting the losses provisions, the project members and corporate representatives have worked hard to resolve these difficulties. The new arrangements, which will improve certainty and bring about significant compliance cost savings, demonstrate the Government's commitment to supporting new ways to reduce excessive compliance cost burdens on business.

These amendments address longstanding concerns of the corporate sector. The amendments were referred to the Committee, but the Committee was not able to consider the proposals before completing its report.
Finally, Mr President, I repeat my thanks to the Committee for its report and look forward to a speedy passage of the Bills by the Senate when they arrive in this place.

speech.speaker: Sherry, Sen Nick

talker.name: Senator SHERRY
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —We are a more creative nation than this budget recognises or permits. We are a more united community than this budget will encourage. We are a nation of greater integrity than the shattered election pledges this budget contains—pledges that were given so forcefully and in such an unqualified manner by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) only a few months ago.

speech.para:
This is a budget of betrayal—not just a betrayal of election promises but a betrayal of the Australian promise itself, the promise of Australia working always towards a more fair, more just, more inclusive and united society.
The message of this budget is: don't be sick; don't be old; don't expect to go to university; if you are unemployed, too bad; and, if you are young and unemployed, forget it.

At the last election John Howard told Australians that they could trust him. He told Australians that, whatever budget numbers he inherited, all promises would be delivered. This budget breaches that trust. There is a long list of broken promises—promises made to mainstream Australia and made to battlers, promises made to students, promises made to the elderly, promises made to state and local governments. No contrived dribbling out of bad news for mainstream Australia and the battlers prior to the budget's presentation can hide that fact.

The new morality of this government is that there are core promises and non‐core promises, although no such distinction was made before the election. Core honesty; non‐core honesty. Would you take that from your kids? John Howard inherited an economy that he said `. . . was better than good'. Indeed he did. It was an economy with inflation that had been averaging two and a half per cent; an economy that had been growing by four per cent a year; an economy which created 700,000 jobs over the last three years; an economy which saw our exports, particularly those of manufactured goods, grow and diversify. He inherited an economy with a very small public sector by international standards and a budget outcome better than any in the industrialised world, bar a couple.

Compare all that with the economy we inherited back when we came into government. The unemployment and inflation rates were over 10 per cent and there was a $25 billion budget deficit in today's dollars. This government placed a dead hand on the economy when they took office. A core reality of this budget is that the dead hand is still there, so much so that Treasury officials observed in the budget papers that `. . . possible confidence effects, while significant, do not fully offset the direct short‐term effects of the measures resulting in a small net contractionary impact on activity in 1996-97'. That is Treasury‐speak for saying that this budget not
only does nothing for growth, but it will reduce it.

Instead of undermining growth, the government should be promoting it. With more growth the budget could be restored to balance without the need for savage cuts to valuable public programs. Higher growths destroys the case for savage budget cuts. By keeping growth up, by aiming for sustainable growth at the four per cent we averaged during our last four years in office, we also bring unemployment down. Unemployment, not the budget, is the No. 1 problem facing Australia.

The Treasurer says that saving is our No. 1 problem. We have no argument that Australia has long had a saving problem; we did more to solve it, with the introduction of our national superannuation scheme, than any previous government. And now Mr Costello places a huge question mark over that achievement.

We have no argument that Australia's longer term economic interests are well served by restoring the budget to balance. That is why we, alone among post‐war Australian governments, delivered successive surpluses in the late 1980s. But we say that the best way to restore the budget to balance is through a moderate program of budget cuts over the whole life of this parliament which do not harm valuable public programs, which do not harm growth, and which provide hope rather than despair for the jobless.

Mr Costello makes a virtue of the fact that this budget holds growth back so that in three years time, and with massive budget cuts, the surplus will be $1 billion. It suits the government to have low growth because low growth makes it appear as though bigger cuts are needed to restore the budget to balance. But, with average growth close to four per cent, it would be possible to achieve balance without savage budget cuts.

On the government's own admission, these cuts are not necessary to reduce the debt ratio: that would have happened anyway. And so far as reduction of the current account deficit is concerned, that is hardly going to change next year. These cuts are not being made for genuine reasons of economic necessity; they
are being made to satisfy the Liberals' ideological obsession with reducing the role of government in Australian society.

Significantly, the burdens in this budget are not equally shared. It is a wrong headed interpretation of this budget that it soaks the rich as well as the poor. Mr Costello has leaped to the challenge of the Commissioner of Taxation to collect $800 million of avoided tax by the wealthiest Australians with a slash of his feather duster—$100 million and a bit of a look. `Hopefully it will be collected voluntarily,' he said. `And have a bit of health insurance while you're at it,' he invites wealthy Australians, `or we'll give you a snip of a levy.' The burden is borne by the battlers, the job seekers, the students, the elderly and middle income Australia.

He offers tax cuts. For a dual income family earning up to a total of $79,000, these tax cuts amount to $3.85 a week for each dependent child. But families want to educate their children. They want to use child care. They are worried about their kids getting an opportunity to work. They want to know that, if their elderly parents need a nursing home bed, they will be able to afford it. They use public hospitals. They carry the burden of increased taxes and charges when the states are slashed.

A generation of women has grown up with successive Labor governments, with new expectations and hopes for the future: meaningful employment and ongoing careers—a totally different world from their mothers and grandmothers. The female labour force is over 50 per cent larger today than it was in 1983. The Prime Minister shows no sign of recognising this fact. But this fact is why successive Labor governments made available affordable, high quality child care. This recognised that many families do not have the means to allow one partner to leave the work force to care for their children, even if they would like to.

At the last election the Liberals were at pains to promise that this quality child care—affordable and available on an equal basis to all Australians—would remain. But what do we find in the budget? We find a range of mean‐spirited measures which will make child
care more expensive for all families. For those using community based care, it will be $14 per child per week more. And this won't be all: $500 million will be taken out of child care and it will be the parents who will have to make up the difference.

Families contain people of all ages. What does this budget do for families of older Australians? We see a proposal which may force older Australians who need nursing home care, or their children, to find around $26,000 in entry fees. Nursing home residents also face a new fee of up to $34 per day, or $12,000 per year, depending on their income.

Mr Howard says that children should pay for their elderly parents to have a nursing home bed. This is yet another way this government is getting families to pay more. But it gets worse. Many older families, frail but still living in their own homes, are dependent on services such as Meals on Wheels, provided by the home and community care, HACC, program. These families are to be stung by greatly increased user fees. That is code for increased charges for Meals on Wheels and the like. The Prime Minister gives with one hand and takes away even more with the other, like a man that comes up to you in the street and says, `Here's $5, now give me $7.'

In the health area, Mr Howard promised to `retain Medicare in its entirety' and to provide a net increase in health funding. Instead, we have indirect cuts through reductions in the financial assistance grants to the states and direct cuts to hospital funding grants. The combined effect is a cut of around $800 million dollars over four years.

The nastiest, if not the largest, of the government's health cuts is the abolition of the Commonwealth dental health program. This program spends around $110 million a year and is exclusively directed at the provision of basic and emergency dental services to health card holders. The abolition of this program will reproduce the two‐ to three‐year waiting lists which prompted the Commonwealth's intervention and which the program has substantially reduced. The budget speech contains the following explanation for the cuts:

break.para: . . . as waiting times for public dental health services have now been reduced, funding for the Commonwealth dental health program will cease—

As if your teeth can be fixed once, and that's the only time you need a dentist! Another of the coalition's major betrayals in health is big increases in the costs of prescription drugs. For a family with three children—and we all know how often they get sick at once—at $20 a script, that is $60 for a family for just one visit to the chemist. And the increased pharmaceutical charge for pensioners breaks Mr Howard's explicit promise to `maintain the real value of all pension benefits and other entitlements for low income earners'.

Above all, there is the threat to bulk‐billing. The government says that it will maintain it, yet eliminates the CPI adjustment to doctors fees. Bulk‐billing is voluntary. Hundreds of doctors will stop bulk‐billing with this change. With another budget next May, you just have to wonder how many more changes and how many fee increases there are going to be.

We do not equally share the burden of this budget. Those who live in regional Australia carry it disproportionately. Regional communities have already been hit by a big round of cuts. Many centres have lost their CES and their tax offices. Now they will lose their local Medicare offices and they will pay more for the services that continue.

During the recent election, the coalition asserted that regional communities were `Australia's forgotten people' and promised to `revitalise regional Australia'. Betrayal has been as swift as it is comprehensive. This government has abandoned regional Australia. In common with its approach to other issues of national importance, it has abandoned its responsibilities to lead, to coordinate and to cooperate with the people of Australia's heartland. When it comes to regional Australia, this coalition has quickly become a government in exile. They are absentee landlords with a big city focus—a government of capital city lawyers from leafy suburbs.

Roads are regional Australia's vital arteries, something that city dwellers often forget. Road funding through the national highway system has been slashed by $620 million.
Even with the Pacific Highway and the black spots programs, total road funding to the regions has been cut by $150 million over the next three years, and it will be hit with an additional $45 million cut the year after that.

Infrastructure projects in centres such as Townsville, Moe and Newcastle, with a total value of $150 million, have been abandoned. This signals the end of the effective and community‐building cooperation between business, all levels of government, local communities and unions that had become the hallmark of regional development under Labor.

Savage cuts to education spending and labour market programs will have a more than proportional impact in regional Australia. It is no wonder that the government's document
Rebuilding Regional Australia
makes no direct mention of education. Universities mean jobs and wages in regional areas. The impact of these education cuts on regional economies is huge. Yet this government intends to cut the funding for regional universities for every campus in every region in every state.
Slashing labour market programs will have a punitive impact on both regional unemployed and the local government authorities and organisations that have benefited from the programs under Labor.

The ABC will not be able to insulate regional Australia from their massive cuts. National sporting events, news, current affairs, vital local weather and radio services for rural and regional Australians are threatened by Mr Howard's decision to cut $65 million from the nation's public broadcaster.

Mr Fischer and his National Party have willingly collaborated with the Liberals in the betrayal of what they would have us believe is their constituency. These people are over‐represented in a ministry in which they lack the clout to stand up to ignorant Liberal colleagues and defend the interests of regional Australia. They deserve to share the retribution that awaits Liberals in regional seats at the next election.
EDUCATION

The proposals for education deserve outright condemnation, not only because they cut
off resources but also because they show the barrenness and prejudice in what passes for vision by this government. The government calls them `far‐sighted' and `equitable'. Those who are on the wrong end of them will call them vandalism. Labor set up and supported one of the most accessible higher education systems in the world. The government proposes to take so much funding out of universities that they will be harmed for years.

Look at what this budget has done to young people and their parents, and their expectations. Labor brought higher education within the reach of all young people in Australia, wherever they lived, whatever their circumstances. This has gone. If you or your parents are well‐off, you are okay; if not, you are not.

This vandalism goes on in school and vocational education. Funding for schools will be cut, including resources for capital and literacy programs. Assistance for students with disabilities will be stopped altogether. Vocational education will be cut, and the government has abandoned its agreement to fund growth in the TAFE system.

Remember this: we have crossed a line here. Now that universities, schools and TAFE are just other sources of revenue, who can be confident that there is not more of this to come? It is on for young and old. Mr Howard has asked you to mortgage your kid's university education, and he has told you to mortgage your old age accommodation.
INDUSTRY

This government has abdicated its responsibilities to Australian industry. Think of an industry where Australians have moved to the cutting edge; think of an industry that has made the hard yards in improved productivity and export competitiveness; think of key growth areas for small business—and you will be thinking of some sector, enterprise or activity that has been damaged in this budget.

The Liberals fail to comprehend the fact that innovative export oriented industries are central to any strategy for future prosperity and jobs growth. Their treatment of the Australian Made campaign is a powerful signal of the extent to which they have lost the plot. The green and gold logo symbolised
the emerging hope for the future of Australian industry, and the government has strangled it.

This budget does not slash programs to end rorts; it hacks away at success stories and punishes innovators. Support for the manufacturing sector is to be cut by $336 million, or 60 per cent over the next three years. Exporters—whose efforts are crucial to our whole economic future—will lose $500 million over the same period. Industries critical to our export competitiveness and employment growth have been singled out—for example, by the removal of the ship building bounty and the abolition of the computer bounty.

Research and development have been heavily set back by at least a decade. The broken promise that has seen the R&D tax concession cut back will cost industry some $1.25 billion. When combined with the abolition of syndicated research, a total of $2.2 billion will be removed from research and development to be replaced by a paltry $340 million in grants. The result will see Australian researchers and Australian ideas move offshore, whilst a range of activities from medical research to information technology and electronics will stall for want of support in this country.

Government support for exporters and industry has been crippled by cuts of $100 million from Austrade and of $30 million from Ausindustry. These all represent broken promises. They amount to dishonest government and, just as certainly, they amount to foolish government. Manufacturers, exporters and researchers have been ill‐served by this budget and, consequently, so have we all.

Above all, this budget also betrays the jobless. This is a budget that will commit itself to no job targets between now and the end of the century. This budget ends the public labour exchange started by Ben Chifley. It shoves the unemployed into the hands of the inexperienced at the same time as it cuts nearly all of the programs that made the long-term unemployed job‐ready.

Sheer ignorant prejudice has meant that the coalition has torn down the highly successful Working Nation employment and training programs—the very programs that were regularly praised by both major employer
groups and individual Australians assisted back into the work force. And do not think that unemployment is not a mainstream issue. Three decades of technological change and industrial restructuring have meant that many have experienced the shock of redundancy previously only experienced by a few.

Since the election of the Howard government, redundancy has been legion in the public sector, in Telstra and in a wide range of industries. Australians expect their prime ministers to stand up for the weak and forgotten; to stand above treasurers and the desire to please the financial markets when necessity dictates; and to have a sense of community. The unemployed, the Aboriginals, the young and the aged have always needed it. For Mr Costello's budget, the Prime Minister stood aside.

This is not a government for communities. It is a government for elite opinion leaders who do not get Meals on Wheels or use community child care; who can afford to pay for tertiary education, dental care, nursing home care; and who will not notice the burden of higher state taxes and charges. Australia is a cohesive community. We are an egalitarian community. Socially just communities are safe communities. Communities which deny opportunity are, in the end, denied security.

This government attacks security in public sector employment, in the safety net when you are out of work and in effective access to public hospitals. This budget lays down the path to a two‐tier society. The Prime Minister is driven to division. All that is public or shared is cut and will be cut again. The message is that, whatever you cannot pay for, you do not deserve. It is an old style tory budget, scapegoating the battlers and having a dead hand on the national tiller.

It will be up to business, Australian workers and our community to work their way back to the low inflationary growth they had and the opportunity we provided. It is a budget whose poisonous content will gradually seep out.

para.break: As a responsible opposition, we will subject its meanness to several tests. Where does a measure betray a promise? Where does it damage equity? Where does it fail to contri bute to national savings? The community demands no less. Many measures fail these tests. Many are locked away in the appropriations legislation immune in the end to defeat but not safe from rigorous criticism in our two houses of parliament.

break.para: Others, however, are about revenue raising or go to the heart of community entitlement programs. The government's measures on the higher education charges, on nursing home contributions and charges and on pharmaceutical benefits for pensions and families—these, for example, will be rigorously opposed. We will oppose them.

This Prime Minister was elected promising Australians that they could be `comfortable and relaxed' and that he would make their lives more secure. Instead, he has hit them with massive changes, making their lives less secure. He promised a zone of comfort but he has delivered a nation more fearful than ever. Australians now face changes they do not need—changes that will hit the family budget and will divide communities.

The budget is a mere irritant for the rich, but a disaster for the disadvantaged and a matter of despair for the unemployed. It is the first chapter in the story of a new, unfair Australia. For all those who had hoped for a secure future for themselves and their kids, this is a budget of betrayal.

speech.speaker: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

talker.name: Senator KERNOT
talker.role: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

talk.start.para: —The Democrats see three themes in this budget. The first is that it represents a calculated breach of faith with those Australians who elected the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and the coalition into government. The second is that it is built on the backs of the unemployed. The third—and possibly most important theme—is that it heralds a significant shift from the public to the private. It signals a move away from the notion of community responsibility and from the idea that governments have a role to play in ensuring that all Australians—irrespective of their wealth—have access to a good standard of health care, to quality and affordable education and to the opportunity to find and keep a job.

speech.para:
There is no doubt the political architecture surrounding this budget has been clever. It
has delivered some positives—and the tactic of doling out the bad news first has clearly left the budget surrounded by a kind of aura of relief. But the political architecture of this budget goes back a lot further than the past few weeks. It is, after all, the culmination of a long tactical march which began this time last year. It started with John Howard's reply to last year's budget where he said:
The real fiscal outcome of the 1995 Budget is not the surplus of $770 million. The real fiscal outcome is actually a deficit of $8.2 billion.
However, by the time the election rolled around, John Howard was saying he had to accept the government's figures. He went on to make billions of dollars worth of election promises on that basis.

When asked by journalists during the campaign what he would do if the deficit was higher than the government's figures, John Howard's response was clear and unequivocal. At the National Press Club on 28 February, he was asked:

What if you win the election and then you discover . . . a serious budget deficit blowout. At what point and under what circumstances will you see it as necessary to cancel some of the many . . . promises you've made?
John Howard said:

Well, the commitments that we've made in relation to reduced taxation and the other commitments we've made in our election policies, they will be delivered in full. I've been asked that question before and I repeat that answer.

He gave John Laws the same answer the day after the coalition's campaign launch. He said the same thing to Ray Martin on the first great debate. He was asked the question time and time again and time and time again he gave the same answer. Not only that, but he dressed it up in the language of trust. This is what John Howard had to say at the National Press Club three days before the election:
The final of the many challenges that I believe we face in this election is what I see in very broad terms as the sense of disillusionment and division within our community . . .
I would like to see in a few years time a situation where there was a re‐establishment of trust between the people of this country and their elected leaders . . .

The Democrats share that concern about disillusionment and division. We share that desire to see a re‐establishment of trust between Australians and their leaders. We apply the same test to whomever is in government. Restoring that trust requires breaking out of the cynical and dishonest election ritual where the major parties outbid each other to make unaffordable promises, then miraculously stumble across the true budget deficit a few days after they take office and use this discovery to break promises they knew they were not going to keep in the first place.

We welcome the Charter of Budget Honesty, but the problem for John Howard is that many Australians who voted for him truly believed him when he said he was not playing this particular game. This budget shows that he was playing that game—$6 billion worth of promises kept; $12 billion worth of promises broken. That represents a massive breach of trust—something John Howard and the Treasurer, Mr Costello, are now trying to disguise by telling us they are only obliged to meet core commitments. Even that notion has been downgraded with John Howard yesterday on
AM
trying to define core commitments as promises that people remember.

Well, I believe people have got better memories than the coalition is giving them credit for. I think they will remember the coalition's promise to make unemployment a priority. I think they will remember the promises to maintain funding to universities, to keep Medicare in its entirety, to not cut the ABC and to maintain labour market programs. I think they will remember the promises on child care, on regional development and on not imposing new taxes or increasing existing ones.

John Howard is also overlooking one important other consideration and that is this: alongside the written promises given during the campaign, there was one largely unspoken understanding. That was that the coalition's two central promises—the family tax package and the private health insurance rebates—would not be funded by massive cuts to other programs. There was an understanding that these two big‐ticket promises would actually be worth something: that they would not be
undermined by increased fees and charges for other services.

I had someone ring my office just this morning: the father of a young child whose wife works part time. He said he had voted for the coalition largely on the strength of its family tax package. He was angry because he had just worked out that, while he would get $4 a week out of that package, he was going to have to spend an extra $20 a week in child care. He said, `I will be about $16 a week worse off, and that's before I worry about having to pay extra for prescriptions.'

A woman rang another of our offices yesterday: she had also voted for the coalition after years of voting Labor. Both she and her son had a chronic illness. She said her family tax rebate was completely wiped out by the increase in the threshold for the medical expenses rebate and the extra cost of prescriptions. These people are not professional lobbyists.

talk.start.para: —The threshold is still there.

—I am not talking about the insurance. These are ordinary people who have done their figures and found they do not add up. These are people who voted for the coalition, not so much on the basis of the written promises, but on the basis of the understanding that they would be better off under a Howard government. They certainly did not expect to be worse off. I believe it is the breach of that unspoken, unwritten understanding that will ultimately do the most damage to the coalition.

speech.para: As I said earlier, the second theme in this budget is that it is built on the backs of unemployed Australians. The budget takes $7 billion out of the economy over two years.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish!
—They are your figures. It does. That will have an effect on employment. Even Treasury concedes it will have a `mild contractionary effect'.
—`Mild' is the operative word.

—I said that—`a mild contractionary effect'. In Treasury‐speak,
Senator Short, that means the economy will be hurt by this budget. It means that there will be fewer people in jobs, less money to spend in the shops and lower economic growth.

speech.para: The Democrats believe the government has read the economy wrongly. We are entitled to disagree. The national accounts released yesterday show the story. In the June quarter, our economy scarcely grew at all. It grew by just one‐tenth of one per cent—the most sluggish growth outcome since 1992. Employment growth has been virtually non‐existent for 12 months. Business confidence is down. Consumers and families are worried. Yet, in this sluggish and tense environment, the coalition has consciously chosen to pull $7 billion out of the economy. This is a decision which will set Australia back, both economically and socially. The proof of that is in the Treasury's own forecasts on jobs.

Treasury is forecasting a rise in employment of just 1.25 per cent this year. Given that our work force is growing by about two per cent a year, that means higher unemployment. In fact, it means unemployment this year will be 80,000 higher on average than last year. That is what the budget is built on. That is the choice you made—200 Australians a day, 1,500 Australians a week, 80,000 Australians a year losing their jobs. That is not sharing the pain; that is front‐end loading the pain to the vulnerable.

I want to restate the Democrat position on deficit reduction. The Democrats support the need for deficit reduction. In fact, it is worth noting that, when the coalition were in opposition, they opposed deficit reduction measures worth more than $6.5 billion over the past three budgets. If we had followed their lead—which we did not—the budget deficit now would be nearly twice its current level.

As I have said many times, the Democrats accept that the budget deficit is far too high. We agree that Australia needs to put in place a credible deficit reduction strategy. We disagree with the government on the questions of how, by what amount and over what period of time the deficit should be reduced.

The Democrats argue that the coalition has failed to acknowledge two very fundamental
