points: firstly, that unemployment is driving a significant proportion of the budget deficit; and, secondly, that the way in which the deficit is reduced is as important as the act of reduction. We believe the government should focus on two medium‐term goals: to halve unemployment and to achieve a structural budget surplus within the next two to three years.
Meeting the first goal would address the cyclical component of the budget deficit—that part which is due to excessive unemployment and which is about $4 billion.

talk.start.para: —That is what we are doing, but you say it is too fast.

—Just listen, please. The second goal focuses on reducing the structural deficit. The Democrats believe a deficit reduction of about $4 billion to $5 billion over the next two to three years represents a credible and responsible strategy not just in economic terms but also in fiscal and social terms. If we go any further than that, we believe that we will start to slice into the social fabric. We also run the risk of the budget not only failing to deliver more jobs but becoming in itself a cause of unemployment—and that is the very big risk underlying the architecture of this budget.

speech.para: The Democrats make no secret of our overall dissatisfaction with the budget. We make no secret of our dissatisfaction with Peter Costello's undisciplined and indiscriminate Scissorhands approach to deficit reduction—whirling through the expenditure side of the ledger, Scissorhands waving away, snipping and slashing at whatever wanders into his path. The result is a lopsided attempt at deficit reduction which well and truly earns the tag of `death by a thousand cuts'. The irony is that, as the details start to emerge, it may just be the government which ends up slowly bleeding to death.

Even before this budget came down, this week's
Bulletin
Morgan Gallup poll reported that 52 per cent of Australians would not have voted for the coalition on election day if they had known about its real plans. They are certainly not going to be any happier once they realise the true impact of the budget on their lives and pockets. So, while the general
initial reaction might look favourable, the fact is that you cannot suppress bad news forever. People are going to be pretty angry when they figure out that the value of the family tax package has been almost totally undermined by cuts to education, to unemployment assistance, to child care and to public health services.

I can say today that the Democrats will support the family tax package. We recognise that Australians clearly expected John Howard to deliver on that. I do not know that they expected him to deliver on that at the expense of support to the unemployed, higher education or Medicare. They did expect to get more money in their pockets. However, we are not happy about the loose targeting of the rebate. We warn the government that, unless it tightens up the income test, it will be paying out the rebate to some very well‐off families.

The other big sweetener, the private health insurance rebate, is a somewhat different matter. Not only is it paid for by massive cuts in health care but it also may threaten Australia's ability to keep a reasonable rein on our overall health care costs. There are a number of problems with the private health insurance rebate—not the least of them being how it stacks up alongside the other changes to Medicare. I can say at this stage that we are favourably disposed towards an increase in the Medicare levy for higher income earners, irrespective of whether or not they have private health insurance.

We are not favourably disposed towards the increase in the threshold for the medical expenses tax rebate. That increase simply penalises the growing number of Australians who are opting to self‐insure—who are, in the coalition's own terms, already being `self‐reliant'. It would be irresponsible of the Democrats to respond to these very significant changes in our health care system without consulting widely and without working carefully through the issues. We will announce our position on these changes within the next fortnight.

However, the Democrats will vote against increases in payments for prescriptions under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme—as we did on several occasions under the previous
Labor government. We will maintain our long‐held opposition to user‐pays education. We will oppose the cuts in operating subsidies to universities and we will vote against the changes to HECS and Austudy.

We are unhappy about the fact that the abolition of the new schools policy seems to have given the government the excuse to take $128 million out of a chronically underfunded state school system. This is one of those offsets which typify the `public to private' flavour of this budget. It will also result in parents of children in the state school system paying more in fees and charges for what should be basic educational entitlements. And that is something else which is going to cut into the family tax rebate.

We are opposed to funding cuts to the ABC and to ATSIC. We know they have been on the coalition's enemy list for years and years and now it is payback time. However, we know that these cuts will form part of the roughly $3 billion worth of measures which are parcelled up in the appropriation bills. The Democrats make no apologies for our ongoing commitment not to block supply. We do not believe in denying the government—and, through it, the public sector—the money it needs to run the country. This nation still bears the scars of the events of 1975—and they are events which should never be repeated.

But our pledge not to block supply does not stop us from requesting amendments to the appropriation bills. This is a tactic we intend to use, with the clear and specific aim of putting pressure on government backbenchers in marginal seats to stand up and be counted on the most damaging, mean and nasty aspects of this budget.

On a positive note, we welcome some of the measures for small business, in particular the long overdue reduction in the provisional tax uplift factor and the exemption from capital gains when the proceeds of the sale of a small business are rolled over into another business. But, yet again, the value of these measures will be undermined by massive cuts to research and development, to export assistance, to the DIFF scheme and to regional
infrastructure—all programs which help create jobs.

talk.start.para: —What about the CSIRO? Have you mentioned it?

—I mentioned that on budget night, Senator Panizza. The budget also proves the coalition's lack of commitment to the environment—this is particularly disappointing for us—with funding cuts to many programs showing that, even if the coalition's—
—It is a lot of money.

—Just listen to this, Senator Boswell, before you say it. We have done our sums, Senator Boswell. Even if the coalition's Natural Heritage Trust were up and running, the coalition would still be spending on the environment less per year for the next four years than the previous Labor government did in its last year—and goodness knows that was bad enough. After this budget, Australians will be spending about 2c a day on the environment—2c! That compares with the 22c a day spent on the diesel fuel rebate, for example. Two cents a day is a paltry commitment to the environment.

speech.para: There are many other measures in this budget and, as always, the Democrats will endeavour to minimise uncertainty by responding quickly to them. I have to say, however, that this is made more difficult by the fact that this budget is very thin on detail in many areas—with even ministers unable to shed light on the specifics of many budget measures.

At the end of the day, once the dust settles, this budget is probably best summed up by today's front page headline in the
Age
. Senator Hill spent so much time reading all the other headlines. He just happened to omit this one, just happened to leave this one out. This morning's
Age
—

Government senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para:
—I do not live in Melbourne. I do not carry any torch for the
Age
or any other paper. Today's
Age
—

speech.para:
Government senators interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Just let me say it. This was the headline—
—Is it just a random sample?

—No. I am not pretending it is a random sample. I have chosen this one because I think it sums up how people will remember this budget. The headline says `PM ducks pledge on jobless'. I read that because the Democrats believe that is how the first coalition budget in 14 years will pass into history.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: —These days Treasury rules, okay. Treasury rules on direction by the money market, and by that read money speculators of Europe and America. And isn't it amazing how many commentators are ticking the budget on the basis of what the speculators are saying. This is the basis of approval on how we run not just our economic policies but also our social and environment policies. In fact, in relation to every value policy, we look to see whether we get a tick by the money speculators of Europe and America.

speech.para: The real game with budgets is often very diffuse. In fact, around 70 per cent of appropriations are currently automatic appropriations, so many of the decisions that are taken in relation to spending are never in any way in the budget appropriation bills. While budget decisions are important and have real impacts on real people, a lot of the activity at budget time is theatre—a chance to create images. The budget books, I have noticed, are often written with the theatre of the period in mind.

One thing to note is that there are a lot of rubbery figures, especially in terms of forward projections. There are large variations—a billion up or down as a result of a variation in a single percentage point in prices. Treasurers like to dress up their budgets using these and a few other devices. One device we have noticed in the past is that the presentation of actual figures of the previous year allowed an appearance of a substantial increase in funding where the actuality was that the prior year's budget was not entirely spent. In some environmental areas, we noted in the past that a budget decrease appeared and was announced as an increase.

Another little trick of Treasury is to project declining funding into the future. Again,
environment budgets—in paragraph 7.4, `environmental protection', or in paragraph 8.4, `national estate and parks', or in paragraph 10.7, `natural resources development and management'—have for the last several years shown an increase in the current year budget with rapid decline in the future. The next year the same pattern would follow. Basically the declining forward projections allowed the forward outlays to be lower, bringing future budgets well back into the black, while the previous decline allowed a small increase to look like a substantial new initiative.

A very big example of this kind of ruse applied to the labour market programs of the previous government in 1993 which we identified in that year as a hole in the budget that would need to be filled. It simply was not realistic, at a time of high unemployment, to axe your entire labour market programs—and we said so, but we were the only ones saying so. Sure enough, 1994 included the Working Nation plan. The thing to recognise is that much of this was the simple replacement of programs that had fallen off the budget and which had been called a deficit reduction plan.

This year we again see a huge decline in labour market programs at a time when employment prospects are not looking good. It is one thing when this is just rubbery figures. It is another thing entirely when a government is actually content to allow programs and whole portfolio areas to fall into a pit—a black hole, which in physics is something that sucks everything into it and emits no light.

Our worry is that this government intends to stick to its forward estimates. In previous years when the forward estimates went down there was generally an increase in the environment and in other areas in some particular programs.

This government has presided over a real decline in environmental funding this year. Not only has environmental funding declined this year, but we are afraid that the government really intends to cut—in paragraph 10.7—natural resource management by about half; in the next few years it really intends to
cut—in paragraph 8.4—national estates and parks by a third; and it really intends to cut—in paragraph 7.4—environmental protection by 55 per cent. This is what it says in the budget papers. I am afraid in this case that it is not just a ruse to make the forward estimates look better; I am afraid the government really means to devastate the environment budget.

I want to note a few things in relation to environment spending. The government say in the budget papers on page 3‐125 that they will eliminate the wet tropics tree planting scheme, saving over $5 million, and cut over $24 million in each of the next three years from DEST. On page 3‐131 you will notice that they will eliminate the off‐reserve nature conservation and the ecologically sustainable natural resource management program, savings of between $11 million and $17 million per year in this year and each forward year.

They will eliminate initiatives to establish a world‐class, adequate and representative system of parks and reserves, a saving of between $16 million and $32 million per year in this year and each forward year. They will eliminate green volunteers, an Australian nature conservation volunteer program. On page 3‐142, it says that they will eliminate the national landcare program expansion, saving between $43 million and $59 million per year in this year and each forward year. They will eliminate the Murray-Darling Basin initiative, saving between $17 million and $34 million per year in this year and each forward year. They will even claw back $7 million from the drought recovery management facility.

I also point out from page 35 of the government's Investing in our Natural Heritage document that they plan to cut environment portfolio outlays by over half in the next four years. Yes, it says that there may be other spending if the Senate agrees to sell Telstra; but, bottom line, their commitment to the environment is to halve its funding unless the Senate buckles.

There is nothing here that says what the level of annual funding will be. The total funding is apparently slightly over $1 billion, but there is no indication over what period this will be distributed. On page 5 of the
Investing in our Natural Heritage document, it says:

The $1 billion received from the one third sale of Telstra will be supplemented both by interest earned and from consolidated revenue, so that overall, an additional $1.149 billion will be spent . . .

The plain English reading of this is that, from Telstra and interest from the trust and consolidated revenue, this is all the money you will give to the environment. I am pleased to see that Senator Kernot has also done the figures and has established the same reality—that is, even if Telstra is sold, no more money will be available on a per annum average basis than is available this year.

The reality is that when you look at the spending program in that Telstra package you see most of it is not even environmental spending. It is not even to be managed by the environment; it is to be managed by primary industry. It is a total ruse. The whole thing from beginning to end is a ruse.

talk.start.para: —A non-core promise.

—Yes, a non-core promise, as has been mentioned. I do not actually think this is a great deal. Maybe they meant something different. I stand to be corrected, I would love to be corrected on this, but that is not what they said in this budget paper.

speech.para: In terms of general social wellbeing, this is a disaster budget as well. For the aged the government will allow those of retirement age to keep contributing to superannuation and will allow them to get a rebate for contributions to the superannuation funds of an unemployed spouse. Given that few of the working poor can afford voluntary superannuation contributions, the idea that they would voluntarily contribute to a spouse is hard to see. The rich, however, may have a non-working spouse to contribute to.

The bank retirement savings accounts are the coalition's way of giving banks more economic power. On the other hand, the government is increasing the cost of prescriptions, increasing the cost of aged care, introducing fees for community care and eliminating the Commonwealth dental program. It will also eliminate the means test exemption for
superannuation for older people between the ages of 55 and 65.

For families there is a worsening situation for education, increased health costs and various changes to tertiary education designed to push adult students into dependency on their parents. Perhaps that means they should be staying home and somehow or other the coalition thinks they can point their finger at them and say, `If they were good and if they had a good family, they would all be at home until they were 26.'

Then there are the general changes to industrial relations and the fact that we are being pushed, perhaps, into the recession we did not have to have. Competition policy changes will also mean that a new range of services will become user pays or may increase in cost. What we have seen is the excuse of the budget to move from government to private providers, whether or not it leads to better outcomes.

There are a huge number of problems, for example, in relation to case management. Not a lot of private providers actually want to provide case management. There is not a lot of profit in it and, if you are going to promise more profit, that does not mean that it is going into the public sector. Quite frankly, the way to gain more profit is to cream off the employable and get the others off the books. That is going to be made a little easier by the coalition. It is going to be made easier because you tighten up the rules, make it harder for people to find enough money to pay their rent, take money from them if they happen to share a house with another person to survive; and then, if you find them breaking the rules, throw them off the system. That should save a lot of money and that should allow private providers of case management to make a bit more profit—throwing people off the books will make it more profitable for them to operate.

para.break: For young people, for whom unemployment is running at over 20 per cent, the government has made tertiary education much more expensive, has undercut Austudy and, as I mentioned, with the decrease in rent assistance, has hit those who are single and trying to reduce costs by sharing rent. The govern ment plans to make $40 million on this. In the meantime, it is guaranteeing that universities will increase their non‐HECS charges for course materials and, by so doing, reducing funding to universities.

speech.para: I would like to give a little summary of the winners and losers in education—a bit of an education scoresheet. Who gets the increases? There will be increased capital funding for private schools: they get $5 million extra up to $10 million per year. There is an increase to the apprentice and trainee program of $5 million to $8 million per year, an increase of $4.8 million per year in aid to isolated children and increases to English as a second language programs of $4.4 million per year.

What are the cuts? There will be overall cuts in total education in real terms of 0.1 per cent this year, 3.6 per cent next year and two per cent in the following year. And these cuts are greater on a per capita basis. Overall cuts in higher education in real terms will be two per cent this year, 10 per cent next year and seven per cent in the following year. And these cuts are greater on a per capita basis.

The overall cuts in funding for government primary and secondary schools in real terms are: 0.2 per cent this year, 2.4 per cent next year, 2.4 per cent the following year and 2.8 per cent in 1999‐2000. These cuts are also greater on a per capita basis. Reducing discretionary funds for universities represents a cut of $43 million per year. Cuts to higher education operating grants are $22.4 million, rising to $266 million, and targeting of Austudy will cut $63 million per year. Raising the age of independence for Austudy is a cut of $28 million, rising to $78 million, and reducing maximum Austudy rent assistance to students in shared houses is a cut of $0.4 million. I should mention that in Austudy we heard last year about student rent related poverty. I think that fell on deaf ears, so poverty will be the in thing for people who are game enough to go into tertiary education. I think fewer of our able students will do that.

Other cuts include: HECS increases—$22.6 million, rising to $123.5 million; earlier HECS repayments—$230 million to $318 million; unspecified savings—$14 million, increasing to $56 million; reducing cash
balances of statutory authorities—$15 million; eliminating case management of homeless secondary students on Austudy and Abstudy—$3.8 million; cutting homeless secondary students on Austudy and Abstudy schooling incidentals allowance—$2.8 million per year; eliminating Australian youthnet—$0.3 million per year; reducing vocational and training grants to states—between $10 million and $24 million in various years; cutting ANTA operating costs by 25 per cent—$3.6 million per year; cutting back indexing TAFE—$5.3 million, rising to $41.4 million; cutting funding for schools in external territories—$1 million per year; cutting migrant places for people under humanitarian programs on the ESL program—$1 million to $7 million; reduction in ESL for migrants—$5.5 million to $14.6 million; and the two‐year waiting period for migrants before Austudy—$12.5 million per year.

Who are the winners? Well, almost no‐one. There are slight benefits and no pain for those with children in private schools. The losers? The nation is the loser through reduction in education and industry will lose through reduction in the skilled work force. But industry will put the pressure on the government and the government will say, `Okay, let us get in some skilled migrants. Let us adjust the supply curve of the labour market because we do not want industry to have to pay too much for skilled workers.'

Who else loses? The economy loses through a reduction in people who might provide the basis for a clever country. Young people lose through a reduction in quality of education and vastly increased costs of tertiary education at a time when this is a requirement for a decent job. Families who assist their children at school will lose as a result of increased costs and a decreased ability of university aged children to be independent. The vulnerable lose: migrants and teenage secondary school students who are homeless.

That was just one example, one program. I would urge those people who read the headlines and said, `What a fair budget. They've cut their mates but they've been fair' to look at the details of what has actually been provided. To show exactly where the heart
and mind of the government is: there is a measure to take away the book allowance from homeless teenagers trying to stay in high school. This is mean, ugly and nasty. It is a vicious attack on those least able to defend themselves.
I thought and thought about these kinds of measures, about why there has been certain targeting, and I have decided that it was a very large case of opportunism.

A large number of people in our society, many of whom were blue‐collar workers, were, admittedly, feeling betrayed. They did not know what exactly was happening to them to change their lives—why they were feeling less certain; why they were on shorter contracts; why they were having to work harder for the same or lower salaries; why they suddenly found they were either out of work or working fewer paid hours; why they suddenly found themselves on split shifts in some states; or why they suddenly had to get two incomes just to survive. Those people were feeling betrayed yet they were being told by the previous government, `You've never had it so good.'

It was not explained that all of the benefits that were supposed to come from this great new internationalism in all these new markets was not actually happening. It was not explained that we had now lost a lot of our manufacturing industry and a lot of people had lost their jobs. It was not explained that we had made a big error. It was not explained that the new internationalism meant that Australian industries were no longer Australian industries and that there was almost a free rein on speculative investment whereby people could come in and do a bit of asset stripping and people would lose their jobs and production could go overseas. It was not explained that this was part of the big error we had made in accepting the new internationalism through the Uruguay Round of GATT.

But because both parties agreed to that error, and there was almost no debate, all those people in blue‐collar jobs in Australia felt betrayed and did not know who to blame. Guess what? They listened to John Laws, Alan Jones and those sorts of people saying,
`Ah, I've got a good idea. Let's blame the unemployed, young people, Aborigines, migrants and everybody else except those people who helped to make the decisions which changed people's lives so drastically in the last few years so it will now be a double whammy.'

The new government picked up that little window of opportunism and said, `Let's use this budget and cash in on the scapegoating that results from communities feeling disenchanted, disenfranchised and betrayed. And let's try to direct that against those people that the racists in our community direct people to hate.' That is exactly what this budget is about—directing the anger of the community away from the decision‐makers who have changed people's lives to the people who can least fight for themselves.

I can understand the disillusion amongst blue‐collar workers. But they were not told what was happening to them through the new internationalism, world's best practice and the fight to the bottom. They did not have explained to them the implications of the wide‐ranging impacts of competition policy which will continue for years to come when values go out the window in exchange for the short‐term dollar and making profits for some corporations and companies in our society at the expense of values and outcomes.

Other people targeted in this budget include indigenous people and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander programs are also being cut. Somebody must have seen a poll indicating that attacking indigenous people would be less electorally damaging than attacking middle‐class Australians—and, of course, the poor whom the government has targeted for its wonderful unaccounted savings.

For example, there is the increased activity test on the jobsearch allowance and newstart. Somehow this will net the government up to $116 million, and it must be pretty heavily increased to cut all those people off. The government will simply save up to $127 million on some ATSIC programs and, I believe, up to $400 million on others altogether. How? What will be the human outcomes? What on earth do you expect to save from that level of human suffering?

break.para: What was the goal of this budget? To reduce the deficit? Is this what governments should take as their sole aim for budgets? I do not believe so because somehow or other if you say you are going to reduce the deficit, it is what Paul Keating used to call `getting a good set of numbers'.

Somehow there must be a goal for benefiting the community. What were the long‐term goals for benefiting the community? Before the election the government said it would increase employment opportunities for young people. Frankly, this budget will do the exact opposite. So what was the goal of this budget if it was simply to reduce the deficit? Affordable tax cuts have caused much of the deficit. Basically, when you cut tax and you cannot afford to do so, you get into a deficit.

Instead of looking at the tax system and wondering how you can increase the revenue and make the tax system more fair again, the only goal of this budget is cutting programs and expenditure and cutting from the most vulnerable in our society. There was less than $1 billion worth of changes to revenue and the rest came from cutting.

Can this be justified only by cutting? A number of economists of highstanding in Australia do not believe so. But what are the choices? If we do not have enough money in the government coffers for the programs we need to provide in a decent, fair society then we look, amongst other things, at revenue measures. We look at whether our tax system is fair and, if not, how we can increase that fairness. We look at revenue measures which will redress the growing gap between rich and poor which the coalition mentioned again and again during the last parliament. That is what the Greens (WA) will be working towards—not letting this government off the hook; not letting them pretend in any way, shape or form that they have given any gift whatsoever to this nation by way of this budget. We will not let them forget that there are options they chose not to take, that they used this budget as a ruse and that we do not now or ever accept they should make the sole goal of their budget pleasing the money speculators of this world.

The real role of governments in budgets should be towards some goal about community; improving something within the community. This budget has not done a cracker for that. The Greens will be working hard to make sure that you understand at every turn what the options are. I can tell you that, where we can improve the situation, we will be working hard to achieve that.

proctext.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

debate.sub1.title:
Mr Alan Platt: Retirement
Parliament House: Demonstration

speech.speaker: McKiernan, Sen James

talk.start.para: —I do not intend to delay the Senate a great deal tonight on this adjournment debate but I do want to put a few things on the record. One is the retirement of Mr Alan Platt and I also want to say a few words about the very ugly demonstration that occurred outside this place earlier this week.

speech.para: Firstly, I will deal with what for some people is the good news; that is, the retirement of Alan Platt. The President paid tribute to Alan yesterday morning here in the chamber and, in paying tribute to his service to the Senate and the parliament, she mentioned that Alan had been awarded the prestigious meritorious service medallion and certificate from the Senate. I would have thought that the work that Alan has done for this chamber deserved at least a trip to Government House. I know lots of others who have made the trip to Government House for a heck of a lot less than the work Alan has done in this place. I join with the President and many others who have paid tribute to him and wish him and his family all the very best in his retirement. This is the last night that he will serve the Senate while it is sitting.

para.break: But he is not alone in departing this place. From the list of the scores of attendants who service us and this chamber, Natalie Campbell, an attendant, will also be leaving the services of the Senate next Monday as will Victor Amsteins, together with Terry Widdi combe, Anna Machado and Brian Agnew—six people who have with dedication, cheerfulness and faithfulness served us and who will depart from their permanent duties as attendants who service this place.

speech.para: It is sad because I think each and every senator would know each of the individuals who will not be around when we return in September. We will miss them but I guess we won't know we are missing most of them until we don't see them around any more. These are six human beings, six individuals, out of the tens of thousands of people in the Public Service of this country who will no longer be in jobs because of the actions of the current government in Canberra, many as a direct result of decisions announced in this place and the other place on Tuesday night and as a result of some of the earlier announcements.

It is all very fine to talk about a thousand going from that department and another thousand from a different department, and adding up the numbers and saying, `Isn't it dreadful; it's 15,000, now it's 20,000 or 30,000.' Quite often, even some of us on this side of the chamber forget that the thousands of people we are talking about are human beings, workers, people who have families who are dependent on the income that is gained from the services rendered in doing the job for us.

Certain decisions have been made in the Department of the Senate that have led to the retirement of Alan Platt and his colleagues. We wish Alan well in retirement. He is probably going on to better things but for lots of others of those thousands of people there will be no enjoyment. For the others sitting out there in the Public Service now who don't know whether that fateful telephone call will come tomorrow we should have some empathy—we, above all, who as politicians generally do not have certainty in our occupations and our lives.

para.break: It should be a joyous occasion for Alan. He certainly will be missed. I hope the local politicians, not least the President of the Senate and also my colleague who is in the chamber and who will be speaking a little later, will take the hint in my opening re marks about the trip to Government House. I mean it sincerely because I am very firmly of the opinion that many others have made the trip to Government House to receive awards, having contributed a lot less than Alan Platt and his colleagues have.

speech.para: My colleague Senator Cooney last night on the adjournment also mentioned Alan and, by way of diversion, mentioned it was his daughter's birthday yesterday. We all joined in wishing Megan a happy birthday as another Leo. Not to be outdone, I have to announce to the chamber and the world that it is my stepdaughter's birthday. Kate Watkins is also a Leo and she is celebrating her birthday. She, in turn, is now very embarrassed as was Megan Cooney last evening.

The final thing I wanted to comment on—I want to hold to my word about not delaying the Senate too long—is the demonstration that occurred outside this place on Monday. A few people got out of control and, in turn, caused the very good behaviour of the vast majority of the people in attendance at the demonstration to be brought into some degree of disrepute. Everybody I have heard has condemned the behaviour of the few individuals who caused the very violent scenes outside and immediately inside the front entrance of the building. They are condemned unequivocally.

talk.start.para: —Except Kelty; he said it was the best demonstration ever.

—The demonstration was the best ever, but I am condemning the behaviour of a few individuals, some of whom probably came in prepared to be troublemakers. I have also publicly brought into question the behaviour of some members of the police force who were controlling the demonstration. I would hope that when an inquiry is conducted it will reveal the reasons, the causes and the names of the persons who gave the orders to block the access of those people who approached the body of the demonstration from Civic. They came up the roadway from Civic and tried to enter the demonstration and were blocked by a line of policemen. I witnessed that personally. I was in the vicinity when it happened. Some people peeled off and went up the entrance.

break.para: I expressed the view before the trouble developed that things could get ugly and that some people went up there to deliberately cause trouble. I hope that when the inquiry is conducted—there ought to be an inquiry, if it has not already been announced—the reasons for the police behaviour will come out.

In making these comments, I am not pointing the finger or putting the blame directly on the police force. The people who caused the problems were the ones who came prepared for the demonstration and who instigated violence—violence that is condemned by all sectors of the community. If somebody made an error of judgment by blocking the passage of certain demonstrators to the demonstration, indeed, the cause for that has to be found out and it must never be allowed to happen again.

speech.speaker: Ellison, Sen Chris

talk.start.para: —I am glad that Senator McKiernan is here tonight to hear what I have to say because it is largely in reply to what he said last night. I will just summarise the allegations made by Senator McKiernan, as I recall them. He said that the current royal commission in Western Australia, which is looking into the Wanneroo matter, was biased, that it was aggressively discrediting whistleblowers—namely, Mr David King—that the counsel assisting the royal commission was engaging in an attack on the ministry of justice, and that the royal commission was artificially interpreting evidence before it. I will deal with those allegations in turn.

speech.para:
Suffice to say, Senator McKiernan's comments were reported in the
West Australian
today. The heading was entitled `Commission under attack'. At the outset, Narelle Johnson, counsel assisting the royal commission, was reported as not making any comment. Of course, that was entirely appropriate for her because the royal commission is continuing and any comment from her, as well as from the commission, would be entirely inappropriate. Therefore, I think the record needs to be clarified on that point. Where the
West Australian
reports that there was no comment forthcoming from the commission or Ms Johnson, it must be understood that the only
thing they could do was to remain silent. It cannot be interpreted in any way that the commission or Ms Johnson agreed with anything that Senator McKiernan said.
Let me go to the allegation made that the commission was aggressively discrediting whistleblowers—namely, Mr King. Narelle Johnson, counsel assisting, stated:
King was ultimately forced to concede that he had no evidence to support the allegation he had made against Mr and Mrs Edwardes.

That was based on the facts as presented to the royal commission. King himself had made the concession. There was no artificial interpretation of the evidence by Ms Johnson. Ms Johnson is a lawyer of experience and great reputation. She is not the sort of person, I would submit to the Senate, who is prone to making artificial interpretations of evidence. Furthermore, Senator McKiernan stated that Ms Johnson went on to attack the intelligence unit of the ministry of justice. This is not true. What Ms Johnson said before the royal commission was:

. . . the intelligence unit was not supposed to gather information in relation to the wider ministry. Its role was limited to prison-related activities and that must clearly be the case. The concept of intelligence gathering units within the public service departments as a general proposition must be anathema to any sensible member of the community. The potential for abuse is manifest.

Ms Johnson was saying that the unit concerned had obviously exceeded its charter. I would take her point that to have such intelligence gathering units within a department could well be the subject for potential abuse. This does not have the ramifications for the fight against crime and corruption that Senator McKiernan says it has. Really, the investigation of crime and corruption is not up to some unit in a department of the public service; it is up to the police. Indeed, the police force in Western Australia has been investigating this matter surrounding events in Wanneroo competently, so much so that people have now been gaoled and further charges have been laid against others.

What I am saying to the Senate is that a properly constituted royal commission is fulfilling its duties to the state of Western Australia and the people of that state and that,
furthermore, the law is taking its course. There are those in Western Australia who simply are not happy with the interim report of the royal commission which cleared Cheryl Edwardes, the Minister for Family Services, and her husband of any wrongdoing whatsoever. In fact, Norm Marlborough told the Western Australian parliament on 4 August 1996:
I am one of the majority who wants to see her—
Mrs Edwardes—
banished. I want to see her out of Parliament, and I will. That will happen.

Obviously, people of that sort are not happy with the result, so they are now attacking the people who are working in the royal commission. We saw a similar attack in relation to the royal commission dealing with Carmen Lawrence. If you don't like the decision, you attack the integrity of the royal commission and the commissioner involved.

The record has to be set straight. Ms Johnson is not at liberty to say anything at this stage, nor is the royal commissioner, Mr Davis. I defend the way in which that royal commission is being conducted and the integrity of the people involved in that. I say to the Labor Party in Western Australia that, if it intends winning the next state election, it should stick to arguing policies and not attack members of the judiciary or the police force.

Finally, the true political motive in this whole matter is revealed when one looks at Senator McKiernan's attempts to link the Howard government with playing a role in any alleged cover up of corruption in Western Australia. I say to Senator McKiernan: that really is drawing a very long bow indeed. Such a flimsy allegation will be seen for what it is and rejected out of hand by the people of Australia.

I thoroughly condemn the corruption which has been found to exist in certain aspects of this matter pertaining to Wanneroo. However, I fully support the due process of the law, which no‐one is able to show is not taking place in that state.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para:
—I wish to speak briefly on the
comprehensive test ban treaty and its recent developments. For some time India has been reticent to sign the comprehensive test ban treaty along with the group of 21 developing nations. India's position has been the most publicised because they are in a problematic position due to being one of the nuclear weapons states, alongside Pakistan and Israel, who have not acceded to the non-proliferation treaty. However, their position should not detract from their message, theirs or that of the group of 21 nations.

speech.para: The concerns of these 22 nations are that the CTBT is a hollow agreement without a timetable for disarmament. On top of this, the CTBT has been designed almost to fail, needing signatures of 44 named countries including Pakistan, Israel and India before it even enters into force. The strategy is akin to allowing the big players to force the little players into an agreement without making any concessions whatsoever themselves.

The group of five acknowledged nuclear nations—China, the United States, the United Kingdom, France and Russia—forced the non-proliferation treaty through without a timetable for disarmament and are now finding it even more difficult with the CTBT because the non‐nuclear nations are becoming more resistant. The nuclear club deny that in fact it is their possession of the largest nuclear arsenals in the world that affects continuing nuclear acquisition within the group of five and outside it amongst the so-called nuclear threshold states. For any real cessation of the nuclear arms race, of which nuclear testing is a part, a timetable for disarmament is critical.

The CTBT is problematic in itself and will only be effective with a timetable for disarmament. This is because, even with a zero threshold, states will continue testing via computer simulated testing. Voluntary disarmament that has largely occurred between the United States and Russia with by far the largest arsenals has been tokenistic and insignificant. The oldest and less advanced warheads are being dismantled while newer, more powerful and sophisticated weapons are being developed. Testing will occur, albeit invisible to international monitoring and inspection agencies, at a fast pace while a
timetable for disarmament is stopped from forcing a pause in the nuclear arms race.

Australia can now play a role in bringing this timetable for disarmament to the fore in the comprehensive test ban treaty negotiations. Apparently, the group of five nuclear nations have today asked Australia to put the CTBT before the United Nations General Assembly in order to bypass the Indian veto in the disarmament committee in Geneva. This is because the P5 nations apparently consider Australia to be the best placed country to sponsor the treaty.

Because the P5 have been largely responsible for the fact that the current entry into force provision of the treaty is delayed, therefore crippling the treaty, Australia should use its position to strengthen the treaty preamble and the entry into force provision. The way to do this is that Australia should take action to impose preferably a timetable for disarmament or, as the Canberra Commission has called for, a timetable for negotiations for disarmament—perhaps just as a first step. Australia must be proactive on this issue to focus on a better outcome for all, rather than the nuclear weapons states that our policies usually pander to. I believe we are still waiting for a response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) to the Canberra Commission. I hope that there is some recognition of what is currently happening in relation to international treaties.

On behalf of my staff and on my own behalf, I give my personal thanks to Alan Platt for all his assistance over the years that I have been a senator. My staff especially asked me to thank Alan for all the help that he has given them over the time that they have been working with me. We are very grateful for the work he has put in and wish him a very happy retirement.

speech.speaker: Lundy, Sen Kate

talk.start.para:
—Today is the last opportunity to put on the public record our appreciation of those people who have spent their lives in the service of the public. The CPSU estimates that about twenty‐seven and a half thousand jobs will go just through
administrative cuts to date, and thousands more as a result of the budget handed down by this government two days ago.

speech.para: The ACT, the people that I represent, will bear a significant proportion of these job losses, but many others around Australia will bear the burden as well. With respect to the administrative cuts, many of those people are taking up the offer of redundancy and this week represents their last week of employment in the Public Service. On behalf of Labor, I extend our gratitude to each and every person who has given of themselves to the Commonwealth Public Service. Work in the public sector is incredibly diverse. Whether you are a painter, a landscaper or an administrative officer, it is crucial that each and every contribution is recognised.

So what are the options for these people who are taking redundancy packages? If we look at it in the context of this budget, things are not very rosy at all. Contemplating small business? This government has actively denied this country at least half a percentage point of growth and that is not good business in anybody's language. Contemplating retirement? Feel sure that there will be a user‐pays principle for home and community care services, and an increase in nursing home fees to boot. Looking for other work? The problem with living in Canberra at the moment is that the impact of the public sector cuts on our local economy goes far beyond just that of the public sector; it eats into the private sector and into all of the support services that exist in our town. What about retraining? Sorry, all the labour market programs have gone. What about returning to higher education; perhaps a change in career? Just in case that seemed like an option, there will be fewer places, higher fees and far less opportunity.

The only other option is to contemplate leaving this place. Anybody who has grown up here or lived here will know that is something that is not a preferred option. Canberra is a beautiful city and the people who live here are very proud of it. Being forced to leave this city will be too high a price for many, but, faced with the option of the poverty line, perhaps it will just be enough to force these people out of town. I am talking
about people I know. They are people with children, with parents, and many of their families have been here for a number of generations. My colleague Senator McKiernan has already spoken this evening about the six attendants who are faced with a situation similar to the one I am describing.

This government is quite obviously anti‐public sector. It has an ideology that does not go along with a public sector that provides genuine services. It seems to think that Canberra, in particular, is a place that can withstand a bit of harsh treatment and almost deserves a bit of a beating. Canberra does not seem to fit with this government's ideological picture of a market driven, dry, harsh world. For many, as I said, this week is their last week of employment with the Commonwealth public sector and all of these people need some hope, some future. They deserve it. Their work has contributed to the quality of all Australians' lives and, indeed, to the lives of many less fortunate overseas. I am referring to the work of people in AusAID and other agencies who have provided much support and assistance to people right around the world. Because of this government, their path will be so much more difficult and they know it. We saw how much they know it when they demonstrated here on Monday.

I wish these people and their families all the best in their future endeavours. Please be assured that many Australians not only recognise your contributions but also appreciate them. They see the need for your work. A
sincere thankyou to you all for your dedicated service. People around the country will experience the loss of your services and this government will, no doubt, learn the hard way the true value of your work.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

question.speaker: Evans, Sen Chris

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 April 1996:

question.para: (1) For each financial year for the past 10 years, how many migrants (excluding refugees and special humanitarian migrants) applied for and were granted social security benefits during their first 2 years in Australia.
(2) What was the average length of time these migrants received social security benefits.
(3) What was the average financial outlay in social security benefits to these migrants.
(4) How many of these migrants were still receiving social security benefits after 2 years following their arrival in Australia.
(5) How many of these migrants are still receiving social security benefits.
(6) What budgetary savings does the Minister anticipate by extending the time limit from 26 weeks to 2 years.
(7) What is the extra cost, financially and in working hours, in administering the new 2‐year limit.
(8) How many prospective migrants have withdrawn or not proceeded with applications to immigrate to Australia since the new time limit was introduced on 1 April 1996.
(9) From which countries did these prospective migrants make their applications.
(10) What cost was incurred, financially and in working hours, by these applications.
(11) What social security time limits are applied to migrants from Organisation for Economic Co‐operation and Development nations.

answer.speaker: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para:
(1) The information in respect of migrants receiving social security benefits during the past ten years, referred to in the honourable Senator's question, is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not
prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information.

In the period from 1 October 1993 to 1 October 1995, 52,997 migrants were granted a social security allowance or benefit (that is, Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance, Sickness Allowance, Widow Allowance, Partner Allowance, Youth Training Allowance or Special Benefit) within their first two years of permanent residence in Australia. This data is based on grants of payment, and therefore includes people who received only one payment, as well as longer‐term beneficiaries.

(2) The average length of time for which a person received a benefit is measured differently, depending on whether the person is still receiving a payment or not. Of the 52,997 migrants described in (1) above, a total of 18,138 were receiving an allowance or benefit at May 1996, while the balance of 34,859 were no longer receiving an allowance or benefit.

Of those who were still in receipt of an allowance or benefit at May 1996, the average duration on payment was 365 days. Of those who were no longer receiving an allowance or benefit at May 1996, the average duration on payment was 171 days.
Note that a break of more than 13 weeks in the continuity of a payment results in the measurement of payment duration being started again from zero when a person reclaims.

(3) The information in respect of financial outlays in social security benefits to migrants, referred to in the honourable Senator's question, is not readily available. To collect and assemble it would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in assembling such information.

(4) Of the 52,997 migrants described in (1), above, 17,131 had been permanent residents of Australia for two or more years at May 1996. Of those, 4,626 were receiving an allowance or benefit at May 1996.

(5) Of the 52,997 migrants in the 1993‐1995 sample, 18,138 were still receiving an allowance or benefit at May 1996 (the most recent data available). As described in (4), above, 4,626 of these had been permanent residents of Australia for two or more years at that time. A total of 13,512 of the migrants in the sample were receiving an allowance
or benefit at May 1996, but had been permanent residents of Australia for less than two years.
(6) The program savings from the initiative to extend the waiting period to two years are expected to be $31.4 million in 1996/97; $143.5 million in 1997/98; and $185.6 million in 1998/99.
(7) The administrative cost of the initiative has yet to be finalised by the Government.
(8), (9) and (10) The answers to these questions were provided by my colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural & Affairs, on 17 June 1996 as part of Question No. 28.

(11) The social security waiting period of 26 weeks applies to migrants from the OECD countries. The waiting period is applied unilaterally by Australia under the domestic law. In the case of New Zealand citizens who enter Australia under the Trans Tasman Travel Arrangements the waiting period is applied under the social security agreement between Australia and New Zealand.

question.speaker: Colston, Sen Malcolm

talk.start.para: asked the President, upon notice, on 2 May 1996:

question.para: (1) Why are travelling allowance payments to Senate chairs and members of committees tabled in the Senate?
(2) Why are other travelling allowance payments to senators not tabled in the Senate?
(3) Have the views of the Privacy Commissioner been sought in relation to the tabling of travelling allowance payments to Senate chairs and members of committees; if not, will they be sought?

answer.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Travelling allowance payments made to Senate committee chairs have been tabled annually since 11 November 1991 when the Acting Deputy President (Senator Giles) first tabled them on behalf of President Sibraa, following a question on notice of 17 October 1991 by Senator Vanstone. Senator Giles informed the Senate: 1In keeping with the principle of making details of the remuneration and allowances of members of the Parliament publicly available, the President proposes in future to table this information at the end of each financial year. He has informed senators who chair committees of these arrangements'.

In his answer to Senator Vanstone's question on notice about such tabling, President Sibraa said `I propose to table this material each year since I consider that it should be publicly available in the same way as many other details of parliamentarians' remuneration and allowances are now made
public at the end of each financial year. (Senate Hansard, 12 November 1991, page 2993.)

On 16 September 1992, the Deputy President (Senator Colston) in tabling details of travelling allowance paid to Senate committee chairs also tabled similar details for committee members. He informed the Senate that `In the interests of completeness and in keeping with the principle of making details of the remuneration and allowances of members of the Parliament publicly available, I also table on behalf of the President details of allowances paid to senators who are not chairs of committees.'

(2) Following a question on notice from Senator Colston of 26 September 1995 to President Beahan, there is a proposal to table details of the travelling allowance paid to senators. This is in keeping with the principle of public disclosure which senators require of public officials at estimates hearings and in the Senate, and would increase the accountability of senators to the taxpaying public. Party leaders and independent senators are being consulted before the proposal is finalised.

(3) The views of the Privacy Commissioner have not been sought nor is it proposed to seek them as the practice of tabling details of travelling allowance payments accords with the principle that there should be maximum disclosure of the entitlements received by parliamentarians.

question.speaker: Bourne, Sen Vicki

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 8 May 1996:

question.para: What steps will the Government take immediately to: (a) improve local councils' knowledge of their rights under the Telecommunications National Code; (b) improve information supplied by carriers to councils about planned infrastructure; (c) give councils greater time to consult with carriers and affected residents about planned infrastructure; (d) encourage carriers to comply as much as possible with all relevant planning, environmental and heritage protection rules; (e) ensure carriers better inform the public about the possible health risks of infrastructure; and (f) require carrier co‐location of telecommunications infrastructure wherever possible.

answer.speaker: Alston, Sen Richard

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para:
(a) Steps were taken in early 1995 to improve local councils' knowledge of their rights under the Telecommunications National Code (the Code). An information package containing a detailed plain English Guide to the provisions of the Code, a copy
of the Code, a copy of the regulations and a list of contacts was mailed to local councils and has been made available on request to councils and the general public. In addition the Government is in the process of revising the Telecommunications National Code. This follows an AUSTEL review of the Code. This process has enhanced the understanding by parties of the operations of the Code. I have recently published a new draft Code and directed AUSTEL to conduct a public inquiry into this Code. Once the new Code is introduced the Government intends to produce explanatory material which will be provided to each council. Consideration will also be given to whether there are any additional measures necessary to improve local councils' understanding of their rights and responsibilities under the new Code.
(b) The new draft Code contains stricter notification and consultation requirements and specifies information requirements for notification of councils.
(c) The new draft Code contains longer time frames in which councils can consult with the carriers, particularly where public notification and consultation is required.

(d) The current regulatory framework governing the way in which carriers install their networks, including the carriers' current exemptions from State and Territory planning laws will continue until replaced by another scheme of proper planning processes, preferably from 1 July 1997. However, the new draft Telecommunications National Code require carriers to have regard to protection of the environment and heritage, particularly in declared areas. It also encourages dialogue between carrier and councils with regard to planning of telecommunications infrastructure.

(e) The new draft Code requires carriers to provide information to be specified with regard to the electromagnetic energy (EME) emissions expected from radio facilities. With regard to the health effects of EME I am advised that the weight of national and international scientific opinion seems to be that there is no substantiated evidence of adverse health effects from EME emissions at typical levels. However, as science cannot prove a negative, the possibility cannot be ruled out. For this reason the Government takes community concerns about this issue seriously.

A joint committee of officials has been set up to study EME public health issues and to ensure that health and safety concerns of the general public are addressed. Included in the committee's work are community information and dissemination programs.

The telecommunications carriers are required, under the Telecommunications National Code, to comply with industry standards likely to reduce risk
to the safety of the public, including Australian Standard 2772.1, which establishes EME exposure levels that are considered, on the basis of current national and international scientific knowledge, to be safe. The Government has maintained this requirement in the new draft Code.

(f) The Code contains provisions which encourage carriers to co‐locate towers and similar structures to help minimise the environmental impact of these structures. The new draft includes provisions to encourage co‐location of telecommunications infrastructure including mobile telephone towers and cabling.

question.speaker: Collins, Sen Bob

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 25 May 1996:

question.para: With reference to the document `Reviving the Heartland', in which the Government stated it was committed to reviews of:
(a) the Rural Adjustment Scheme;

(b) the effectiveness of Exceptional Circumstances provisions of the Government's drought policy for intensive animal industries in situations where they draw their feed supplies from areas affected by drought;
(c) the effectiveness of the Farm Household Support Scheme;
(d) the Countrylink service;
(e) the assets test as it applies to social security payments for primary producers;
(f) the structure and effectiveness of the Meat Industry Council;
(g) anti-dumping and countervailing laws and food labelling laws;
(h) management of the Wheat Industry Fund;
(i) efficacy of taxation write-off arrangements for expenditure on new horticultural plantations;
(j) operations of the Australian Horticultural Corporation;
(k) the use of funds by the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation; and
(l) fisheries research:
(1) What is the proposed commencement date for each review.
(2) Who will undertake each review.
(3) What is the proposed completion date for each review.
(4) What is the estimated cost of undertaking each review and will the Government meet the cost.

answer.speaker: Parer, Sen Warwick

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: In relation to the commitment to reviews given in `Reviving the Heartland', the Government will be proceeding with its program in an orderly way consistent with its policy priorities and the resource constraints it faces as a result of the budget position it inherited. Against that background, the Government is considering its options with respect to a number of the reviews listed and will take decisions in due course consistent with its commitments. A range of critical issues to rural and regional Australia will be progressed through the work of the Activating Committee established following the Rural Finance Summit. Following is the situation with respect to those reviews on which action has been taken to this point:

(i) The Countrylink review has been incorporated into a full review of the Rural Communities Access Program, which will be undertaken in two phases and which has commenced. The review will be undertaken by an outside consultant who has not yet been identified. The proposed completion date is early in 1997. The cost is yet to be determined but will be dependent on the tenders received. The Government will meet the cost.

(ii) As part of the Government's policy commitment in relation to farm families' access to social security payments, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Jocelyn Newman, is to establish a Special Rural Task Force to investigate the ongoing hardship and anomalies created by the application of the assets test in rural areas. I have been liaising with the Minister on the composition of the Task Force. The Minister for Social Security will shortly be announcing arrangements in relation to the Task Force.

(iii) I announced in May a review into the structure and effectiveness of the Meat Industry Council. It is being undertaken by a Meat Reform Steering Committee and Meat Reform Task Force. It is proposed that the work of this group will be concluded by September.

Consultancy costs (including a financial efficiency audit) are being determined by the Steering Committee. These costs are expected to be between $200,000 and $250,000 and will be split between Meat Industry Council, Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation. The Government will meet the costs of Departmental staff involvement in the joint review as part of existing DPIE running costs and incidental
expenditure on external advice expected at about $40,000.

(iv) The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs announced a review of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing procedures on 26 June. The Chairman of the Review, Mr Lawrie Willett, is to report by the end of August.

(v) The Government has indicated it will require (1) that all imported products meet the same quarantine, hygiene, health and labelling standards as domestically produced goods and; (2) truth and accuracy in advertising, packaging and labelling, particularly in relation to country of origin.

Changes to country of origin labelling for all products had been proposed through an amendment to the Trade Practices Act 1974. (The amendment Bill lapsed when Parliament was dissolved.) The issue of country of origin labelling for food was referred to the National Food Authority (now Australia New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) from 1 July 1996) in 1994.

The ANZFA is continuing to develop a draft standard (for the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code) for labelling requirements based on a three tiered system to describe country of origin for food products.

The ANZFA Board will consider the draft standard, when it has been finalised, and decide on a submission to the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council (of all Commonwealth and State Health Ministers plus the NZ Health Minister) seeking approval for the new labelling requirements. If agreed to, the new requirements will be adopted by reference into State and Territory food law.
(vi) The Wheat Industry Fund (WIF) is a statutory fund administered by the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) under the Wheat Marketing Act 1989.

The WIF will be an integral component of the new structural arrangements for wheat marketing and the AWB which are currently being considered by the grains industry. Recommendations are expected to be made to Government during 1996/97.
I would expect the commitment to review the management of the WIF to be satisfied by the broader consideration of a new AWB structure.

The grains industry, mainly through the AWB, is meeting its costs associated with the restructuring discussions and the Government is meeting its own costs. It is not possible to separate costs associated with the WIF from other costs of the restructuring discussions.

(vii)Issues surrounding the taxation write-off arrangements for new horticultural plantations will be the subject of advice to me from the Australian
Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) in the period up to December 1996. The cost of the advice will be met through ABARE running costs.

(viii) The operations of the Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) are the subject of ongoing review by the Horticulture 2000 Group which has been given the task of monitoring the role of the AHC as the designated `change agency' for the implementation of an export based growth strategy for the horticulture industry. The Horticulture 2000 Group was established in 1994.

question.speaker: Collins, Sen Bob

question.para: (1) Does section 45(1) of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act require that no public moneys of the Northern Territory be issued or expended except as authorised by enactment.

(2) Was proper process followed under the provisions of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act in respect of payments made to the Minister for Housing and Local Government (Mr Manzie) for a defamation action taken by him against the publisher of the

(3) Was proper process followed under the provisions of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act in respect of payments made to the Northern Territory Minister for Health (Mr Finch) for a defamation action taken by him against the Northern Territory Member for MacDonnell (Mr Bell).

question.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 1 July 1996:

question.para:
(1) Has a statement been made that a social and cultural impact study would be concluded as part
of Energy Resources of Australia's (ERA) proposal to mine uranium at Jabiluka; if so, what are the details of the statement.
(2)(a) Is it a fact that the planned social and cultural impact study may be funded up to 50 per cent by ERA; (b) would such a study be independent of ERA.

(3)(a) Is it a fact that statements made by traditional owners declare that mining in the Kakadu region is responsible for many alcohol-related deaths and social breakdowns in the Aboriginal community and that this is the reason for many traditional owners opposing mining at Jabiluka; and (b) does the Minister agree with these comments.

(4) Can it be confirmed that there will be no approval for the Koongarra uranium mine and the Jabiluka mine: (a) without the consent of the Northern Land Council; and (b) without the consent of the traditional owners that speak for the area.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I released a statement to the media on 28 June 1996 which announced that the application by ERA to mine uranium at Jabiluka would be subject to a full Environmental Impact Statement (EIS). In that media release I confirmed my support for a comprehensive social impact study of development on Aboriginal communities to be run parallel with but independent of the EIS. A copy of the media release has been provided to the honourable senator and additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(2)(a) ERA have offered to fund half the cost of the study and I envisage that the balance will be met by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory Governments; (b) I will support the establishment of a steering committee made up of representatives of the Traditional Owners, the NLC, the NT Government, ERA, ANCA and the Supervising Scientist but arrangements for management of the study have not yet been finalised.

(3)(a) These views have been expressed by some traditional owners; (b) It is difficult to ascertain if social problems are directly related to mining development, or have other controlling factors. I have supported a social impact study to help clarify this.
There is no current proposal before Government to mine at Koongarra. Any decisions on Jabiluka will be taken only after the proper environment impact assessment procedures have been followed.

question.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

(2) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency, within my portfolio, is currently engaged in discussions concerning the future management of the Creery Wetland.

question.speaker: Collins, Sen Bob

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 July 1996:

question.para: (1) Does AusAID retain the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation as its procurement consultant for goods and services purchased as aid to countries such as Papua New Guinea (PNG).
(2) Is a stated aim of the aid program to assist recipient countries through the provision of goods and services manufactured in Australia or New Zealand.
(3) Was a recent tender let under this program for the provision of large fire vehicles for the PNG Office of Civil Aviation.
(4) Was a minimum local content requirement one of the conditions of the tender, if so, what level of local content was specified.
(5) Has the contract been awarded; if so: (a) to whom; and (b) did the successful bidder have ISO 9001 accreditation for quality systems.

answer.speaker: Hill, Sen Robert

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC) is currently under contract to AusAID to procure goods and related services under the Commodities Assistance Program (CASP). CASP is a form of aid delivery whereby manufactured equipment and commodities, including related training, commissioning and after sales requirements, are purchased for aid recipient countries such as Papua New Guinea.

(2) No, goods procured under CASP do not have to be manufactured in Australia or New Zealand. Procurement follows Commonwealth purchasing guidelines. These guidelines require SMEC to arrange for an open and fair competitive selection process and to obtain value for money. Factors taken into account include price, technical merit and conformity, delivery time, after sales service and maintenance and warranty cover. Australian suppliers should not however be disadvantaged in the selection process.
(3) Yes, a tender was let under CASP arrangements for the provision of 4 large fire vehicles for the PNG Office of Civil Aviation.
(4) No, a minimum of local content requirement was not one of the conditions of tender.
(5) Yes.
(a) The contract has been awarded to an Australian company, CI and D Industries, the Australian agent for the vehicle component supplier.

(b) CI and D Industries have ASO 9002 accreditation. The vehicle component supplier has ISO 9001 accreditation and the 4 fire vehicles will be assembled in Australia under the supervision of the vehicle component supplier.
